question_text: A 3-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother 2 days after developing a rash. The mother reports that the redness appeared suddenly about an hour after bathing. Two weeks ago, the patient was diagnosed with a skin infection and was treated with penicillin V. She has been otherwise healthy but has missed several well-child examinations. She lives with her mother, who recently lost her job. The patient's maternal aunt has systemic lupus erythematosus. During the visit, the mother expresses frustration, stating that her daughter "never listens and is hard to control.” The patient’s temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 112/min, and blood pressure is 108/62 mm Hg. She appears quiet and withdrawn. Physical examination shows sharply delineated erythema from above the knees to just above the umbilicus, with sparing of the buttocks. Further evaluation is most likely to reveal which of the following?
content_preview: A 3-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother 2 days after developing a rash. The mother reports that the redness appeared suddenly about an hour after bathing. Two weeks ago, the patient was diagnosed with a skin infection and was treated with penicillin V. She has been otherwise healthy but has missed several well-child examinations. She lives with her mother, who recently lost her job. The patient's maternal aunt has systemic lupus erythematosus. During the visit, the mother expresses frustration, stating that her daughter "never listens and is hard to control.” The patient’s temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 112/min, and blood pressure is 108/62 mm Hg. She appears quiet and withdrawn. Physical examination shows sharply delineated erythema from above the knees to just above the umbilicus, with sparing of the buttocks. Further evaluation is most likely to reveal which of the following?
hint: The distribution of injuries in this 3-year-old child should raise concern for child abuse.
learning_objective: Recognize signs suggestive of child abuse, and recall the diagnostic findings indicative of non-accidental injury.

answers.content: Multiple injuries in different stages of healing
answers.explanation_why:
This patient presents with sharply delineated erythema on the lower extremities and abdomen with sparing of the buttocks (doughnut pattern) in combination with sharp burn borders and no splash marks, suggesting a scald injury due to forced immersion in hot water. During forced immersion, the victim reflexively flexes their legs, leading to characteristic sparing of flexor surfaces (see “Overview of scalds” table). Additional concerning findings in this scenario include the delayed presentation (seeking medical care 2 days later), missed well-child visits, and the mother's expressed frustration with her child.

Children who experience physical abuse often present with multiple injuries in different stages of healing. Risk factors for perpetrating child maltreatment include history of experiencing childhood abuse or domestic violence, psychiatric conditions, and socioeconomic factors such as recent job loss and financial hardship. Physicians are legally obligated to report suspected child abuse to Child Protective Services, even if it requires breaking patient-physician confidentiality.

Dermatographism is seen in some patients with urticaria. Patients with certain forms of physical urticaria (e.g., aquagenic urticaria, cholinergic urticaria) may present with sharply-demarcated erythematous lesions (rather than uniform erythema) that appear after a bath, as seen here. However, these lesions tend to be raised (wheals) and are intensely itchy. Moreover, wheals associated with most physical urticaria usually disappear within an hour after the stimulus is removed; the persistence of the lesion for two days indicates a different diagnosis.

images.title: Urticaria
images.description: Well-circumscribed, partially confluent erythematous lesions are visible on the torso and limbs.This is the typical presentation of urticaria (hives).

answers.explanation_why: A positive Nikolsky sign can be seen in staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS). Although this patient does have a rash, it is sharply demarcated, involving only the lower part of the body, with sparing of the flexor surfaces, which is not typical of the diffuse rash seen in SSSS. Furthermore, she lacks other signs of infection (e.g., fever, malaise) that occur with SSSS.

images.title: Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS)
images.description: There is diffuse erythema of all visible skin. Large ruptured blisters are visible on the left lower leg, and a large flaccid unruptured blister can be seen on the left buttock.

answers.content: Malar rash with sparing of the nasolabial folds
answers.explanation_why: Malar rash with sparing of the nasolabial folds can be seen in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). SLE typically affects women of child-bearing age and manifests with other rheumatological symptoms (e.g., fever, fatigue, myalgias, arthritis). Although this patient's maternal aunt has SLE, the girl's age makes SLE less likely. Also, a sharply demarcated erythema of the lower body is not a feature of SLE and suggests another etiology of this girl's symptoms.

images.title: Malar rash in systemic lupus erythematosus
images.description: An erythematous macular rash is visible over the nasal bridge, right cheek (malar eminence), and the right brow. The rash has spared the nasolabial fold.This is the characteristic appearance of the malar rash typically seen in systemic lupus erythematosus. This rash is also referred to as a “butterfly rash” because it typically affects both malar eminences symmetrically and resembles the wings of a butterfly.

answers.explanation_why: Ulcers of the oral mucosa with erythematous skin lesions can be seen in Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS), which can be triggered by certain medications (e.g., antiepileptics, sulfonamides) or infections (e.g., CMV, herpes). The recent skin infection and the antibiotics put this girl at risk for SJS. However, the rash characteristic of SJS is diffuse and involves the entire body without well-demarcated borders.

images.title: Stevens-Johnson syndrome
images.description: Back, buttocks, thighs, and legs of an 8-month-old infant 2 weeks after primary vaccinationIrregularly shaped, partially confluent, erythematous macules with bullae are visible.Patient history suggests Stevens-Johnson syndrome triggered by vaccination.

question_text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of inability to concentrate and difficulties completing assignments at school. His mother says that he frequently interrupts others during conversations at home and that his teachers often reprimand him for talking excessively in school. He refuses to play with the other children and often has physical altercations with his classmates. He can jump up and down, but he cannot hop on one foot. He eats without assistance but has difficulty using silverware. He cannot follow three-step directions. There is no family history of serious illness. Examination shows a small head, wide-spaced eyes, and short palpebral fissures. His upper lip is thin and flat. He has a sunken nasal bridge and a small jaw. There is a grade 3/6 pansystolic murmur heard best along the left lower sternal border. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
content_preview: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of inability to concentrate and difficulties completing assignments at school. His mother says that he frequently interrupts others during conversations at home and that his teachers often reprimand him for talking excessively in school. He refuses to play with the other children and often has physical altercations with his classmates. He can jump up and down, but he cannot hop on one foot. He eats without assistance but has difficulty using silverware. He cannot follow three-step directions. There is no family history of serious illness. Examination shows a small head, wide-spaced eyes, and short palpebral fissures. His upper lip is thin and flat. He has a sunken nasal bridge and a small jaw. There is a grade 3/6 pansystolic murmur heard best along the left lower sternal border. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
hint: This patient's presenting findings are due to the most common preventable cause of intellectual disability in the United States.
learning_objective: Recognize fetal alcohol syndrome.

answers.explanation_why: Trisomy 21 (Down syndrome) is most commonly due to meiotic nondisjunction of chromosome 21 and frequently results in intellectual disability, behavioral disorders, delayed developmental milestones, congenital heart defects, and a depressed nasal bridge. Patients may also appear to have short palpebral fissures and hypertelorism due to epicanthal folds (pseudohypertelorism). However, patients with Down syndrome also typically have other manifestations, such as upslanting palpebral fissures, low-set ears, a short neck, furrowed protruding tongue, abnormal dentition, and a transverse palmar crease, which are all absent in this patient. A flat philtrum, thin upper lip, and microcephaly suggest a different cause of this patient's findings.

answers.content: Deletion of long arm of chromosome 7
answers.explanation_why: Deletion of the long arm of chromosome 7 leads to Williams syndrome, which usually causes intellectual disability in affected individuals. Although patients with Williams syndrome typically manifest with facial dysmorphism (“elfin facies”), which may include midfacial hypoplasia and short palpebral fissures, some facial features differ from those seen in this patient (e.g., wide forehead, periorbital fullness, long philtrum, and dental hypoplasia). Patients with Williams syndrome do commonly have supravalvular aortic stenosis, which could result in a systolic heart murmur. In contrast to this patient, who has difficulty with social interactions, patients with Williams syndrome classically have an overfriendly demeanor and lack stranger anxiety.

Prenatal alcohol exposure results in fetal alcohol syndrome (FAS), which often manifests with microcephaly, flat philtrum, short palpebral fissures, hypertelorism, depressed nasal bridge, and micrognathia. This patient's difficulties at school are due to the behavioral problems (e.g., hyperactivity and inattention) and intellectual disability (e.g., learning disabilities, memory and reasoning deficits, impaired language development) associated with FAS. This patient's pansystolic murmur heard best along the left lower sternal border is caused by a ventricular septal defect, which is often seen in patients with FAS.

images.title: Clinical findings in fetal alcohol syndrome

answers.explanation_why: Maternal hypothyroidism may be associated with congenital hypothyroidism, which results in intellectual disability and microcephaly. However, congenital hypothyroidism is typically identified by neonatal screening. Moreover, patients usually have dry, scaly skin, myxedematous facies, macroglossia, and a failure to thrive. Other classical features include hypotonia and umbilical hernias, neither of which is seen in this patient.

FMR1 gene mutation is responsible for fragile X syndrome, which may result in intellectual disability, behavioral disturbances, delayed developmental milestones, and a systolic murmur (due to mitral valve prolapse). However, patients are usually macrocephalic and have long narrow faces with prominent ears. Other classical features include a high arched palate, hypotonia, joint laxity, and flat feet.

Maternal intake of phenytoin may result in fetal hydantoin syndrome, which manifests with intellectual disability, microcephaly, hypertelorism, a sunken nasal bridge, and congenital heart defects. However, there is no history of a seizure disorder in the mother to suggest that she might have been prescribed phenytoin. Other common features of this condition include hypoplastic fingers and a cleft lip or palate. A flat philtrum and a thin upper lip suggest a different cause of this patient's findings.

question_text: A 2-week-old male newborn is brought to the physician by his 33-year-old mother for a well-child examination. He was born at term and delivered at home because his parents wanted a natural childbirth. The mother did not receive prenatal care. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. According to the mother, delivery was fast and without complications. He is being exclusively breastfed. He appears healthy. He is at 35^th percentile for length and at 40^th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. This patient is at increased risk for which of the following complications at this time?
content_preview: A 2-week-old male newborn is brought to the physician by his 33-year-old mother for a well-child examination. He was born at term and delivered at home because his parents wanted a natural childbirth. The mother did not receive prenatal care. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. According to the mother, delivery was fast and without complications. He is being exclusively breastfed. He appears healthy. He is at 35th percentile for length and at 40th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. This patient is at increased risk for which of the following complications at this time?
hint: Natural childbirth is childbirth without routine medical intervention. This patient most likely did not receive the standard postpartum care.
learning_objective: Recall the importance of vitamin K prophylaxis in newborns.

answers.explanation_why: Secondary hyperparathyroidism is caused by hypocalcemia, which can result from maternal hypocalcemia or diabetes, preterm birth, newborn sepsis, asphyxia, or vitamin D deficiency. Vitamin D deficiency is a concern in exclusively breastfed infants who do not receive vitamin D prophylaxis. However, only a prolonged and severe vitamin D deficiency would result in hypocalcemia, and this condition is therefore unlikely in a 2-week-old patient. Furthermore, breast milk supplies the infant with abundant calcium, which makes hypocalcemia and secondary hyperparathyroidism very unlikely.

Newborns have an increased risk of hemorrhage resulting from low vitamin K values, due to the lack of vitamin K-producing gut flora, limited liver capacity, and poor placental transfer of vitamin K. Breast milk contains very low amounts of vitamin K, so the risk of bleeding does not decrease with breastfeeding. All newborns typically receive an intramuscular vitamin K shot at birth to mitigate this risk. Because this child was delivered at home without any medical intervention, it is very likely that he did not receive vitamin K prophylaxis and is consequently at increased risk of bleeding, including potentially severe brain hemorrhage.

Breastfeeding is associated with a decreased risk of gastroenteritis. Breast milk contains antibodies and is therefore an important source of protection against numerous infectious diseases. The most abundant antibody found in breast milk is IgA, an integral part of mucosal immunity, which also helps to protect the gastrointestinal mucosa of the infant against gastroenteritis.
Breastfeeding is associated with a decreased risk of childhood cancers, including leukemias and lymphomas.

Iron deficiency anemia (IDA) is primarily a concern in preterm infants because of their lower stores of iron, although it can also be caused by blood loss during or after birth. However, this newborn was born at term and the delivery did not involve any complications. Breastfed infants are also at risk of IDA because breast milk contains only limited amounts of iron. To prevent IDA in breastfed infants, they should receive an additional iron source starting by 4 months of age in full-term infants and by 2 weeks of age in premature infants. Although this infant is being exclusively breastfed, he is not at increased risk of IDA at this time, as most full-term newborns have sufficient iron stores for up to 4 months.
Breastfeeding is associated with a decreased risk of both type 1 diabetes mellitus and type 2 diabetes mellitus.

Scurvy is the clinical manifestation of vitamin C deficiency and is an extremely rare disease in high-income countries. Symptoms include swollen gums, poor wound healing, mucosal bleeding, corkscrew hair on the body, and generalized weakness and fatigue. Because this newborn is being breastfed and breast milk contains sufficient vitamin C, he does not have an increased risk of scurvy.

Subacute combined degeneration is caused by vitamin B_12 deficiency and can lead to severe neural tube defects and developmental disability. Unless the mother already had a deficiency during pregnancy or has a lack of vitamin B_12 now, her breast milk should supply enough vitamin B_12 to the child.

Intussusception is generally an idiopathic condition, but is often associated with a triggering viral gastrointestinal infection or less often with lead points. Since this infant is currently being breastfed, he has a decreased risk of gastrointestinal infections, which thereby also decreases his chances of developing intussusception

question_text: A 27-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She feels well. A Pap smear 4 years ago showed no abnormalities. She was treated for a chlamydia infection at 22 years of age. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 6 years. She is sexually active with 3 male partners and uses condoms inconsistently. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A Pap smear shows atypical squamous cells of undetermined significance. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 27-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She feels well. A Pap smear 4 years ago showed no abnormalities. She was treated for a chlamydia infection at 22 years of age. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 6 years. She is sexually active with 3 male partners and uses condoms inconsistently. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A Pap smear shows atypical squamous cells of undetermined significance. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: In patients with positive cytology, an additional step is required to assess the immediate risk of CIN3+.
learning_objective: Recognize atypical squamous cells of undetermined significance on Pap smear, and choose the most appropriate follow-up test.

answers.explanation_why: An endometrial biopsy is recommended for all nonpregnant individuals ≥ 35 years of age with atypical glandular cells (AGCs) or adenocarcinoma in situ (AIS) to rule out endometrial cancer. Endometrial biopsy is also recommended for nonpregnant individuals < 35 years of age with AGCs or AIS and abnormal uterine bleeding or risk factors for endometrial cancer. This patient has atypical squamous cells of undetermined significance, and therefore endometrial biopsy is not indicated.

Expedited excisional treatment (e.g., with loop electrosurgical excision procedure) is indicated for women with a high immediate risk of CIN3+. This patient's immediate risk of CIN3+ has not been assessed, and therefore a different step in management is required. In addition, as this patient has a low-grade cervical cytology, it is unlikely that excisional treatment will be required.

If the initial primary HPV test or cytology-alone test is positive, reflex triage testing (i.e., cytology if HPV testing is positive and HPV testing if cytology is positive) should be performed for risk stratification. In patients with positive cytology-alone screening, reflex high-risk HPV genotyping is indicated to assess for HPV 16 or HPV 18 infection. Recommendations for further follow-up are based on the estimated risk for CIN3+.

If atypical glandular cells are found on initial cytology, reflex HPV testing is not required, as management is independent of HPV status.

Performing cytology in 3 years is the standard screening interval for cytology-alone screening for cervical cancer. This would be appropriate if this patient's cytology results were normal. However, this patient has positive cytology and the immediate risk of CIN3+ must be determined before deciding whether it is appropriate to resume routine screening.

Colposcopy and cervical biopsy may be considered for women with a high immediate risk of CIN3+. This patient's immediate risk of CIN3+ has not been assessed, and therefore a different step in management is required.

question_text: A 61-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She feels well. She has no history of serious illness. Menopause occurred 7 years ago. Colonoscopy 4 years ago disclosed no abnormalities. A serum lipid profile obtained last year was within the reference range. Two years ago, a Pap smear with testing for human papillomavirus showed no abnormalities. Mammography performed 10 months ago showed no abnormalities. She is a retired university professor and lives with her husband. She has no children. Her father developed colon cancer at the age of 75 years. She has no family history of hip fracture. She does not smoke cigarettes or drink alcohol. Her only medication is a daily multivitamin. She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 58 kg (128 lb); BMI is 22 kg/m^2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A fasting serum glucose level is 102 mg/dL. Screening for depression with a validated questionnaire is negative. Which of the following health maintenance recommendations is most appropriate at this time?
content_preview: A 61-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She feels well. She has no history of serious illness. Menopause occurred 7 years ago. Colonoscopy 4 years ago disclosed no abnormalities. A serum lipid profile obtained last year was within the reference range. Two years ago, a Pap smear with testing for human papillomavirus showed no abnormalities. Mammography performed 10 months ago showed no abnormalities. She is a retired university professor and lives with her husband. She has no children. Her father developed colon cancer at the age of 75 years. She has no family history of hip fracture. She does not smoke cigarettes or drink alcohol. Her only medication is a daily multivitamin. She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 58 kg (128 lb); BMI is 22 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A fasting serum glucose level is 102 mg/dL. Screening for depression with a validated questionnaire is negative. Which of the following health maintenance recommendations is most appropriate at this time?
hint: This patient's history and physical examination findings do not suggest that she has a higher risk of morbidity than average.
learning_objective: Recognize the appropriate health maintenance recommendations based on patient history and screening guidelines, and choose the correct follow-up action.

answers.explanation_why: The US Preventive Services Task Force recommends screening mammography every 2 years in women aged 40–74 years with average risk for breast cancer. This patient had a normal mammogram 10 months ago, so she does not require further screening at this time.

Screening for lipid disorders is recommended in all adults aged 20–75 years at least every 4–6 years. In adults aged 40–75 years, the screening interval can be shortened based on the individual ASCVD risk. Given that this patient had a normal serum lipid profile 1 year ago and has no significant risk factors for cardiovascular disease (e.g., history of diabetes mellitus, hypertension, or smoking), her ASCVD risk is likely low. A repeat serum lipid profile is not warranted at this time.

The US Preventive Services Task Force recommends screening for colorectal cancer in all asymptomatic adults between 45 and 75 years of age who have an average risk (e.g., no inflammatory bowel disease, adenomatous polyps, or family history of an inherited cancer syndrome). Colonoscopy every 10 years is an appropriate strategy. Individuals with a first-degree relative (FDR) with a history of colorectal cancer, like this patient, are generally recommended to obtain screening more frequently (every 5 years) and start earlier (40 years of age or 10 years before the youngest FDR's age at diagnosis). Because her last colonoscopy 4 years ago was normal and she lacks symptoms suggestive of colorectal cancer (e.g., weight loss, hematochezia), she does not require repeat screening at this time.

The US Preventive Services Task Force recommends screening women ≥ 65 years of age for osteoporosis with bone measurement testing (e.g., dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry). For postmenopausal women < 65 years of age, the decision to screen should be based on an assessment of the patient's overall risk for osteoporosis. This patient has no significant risk factors for osteoporosis (e.g., family history of hip fracture, smoking, alcohol consumption, low BMI), so screening is not indicated at this time.

answers.content: No specific health maintenance recommendation is needed
answers.explanation_why:
No specific health maintenance recommendation is needed at this time for this 61-year-old woman who is currently up to date with all recommended screening tests based on her age, history, and physical examination findings. The recommendations that this patient has followed include screening for cervical cancer (Pap smear and human papillomavirus testing every 5 years), colon cancer (every 5 years in patients with a first-degree relative with a history of colorectal cancer, every 10 years in the general population), and breast cancer (mammography every 1–2 years). Moreover, she does not have identifiable risk factors for cardiovascular disease (e.g., history of dyslipidemia, diabetes, hypertension, or smoking) or osteoporosis (e.g., family history of hip fracture, smoking, alcohol consumption, low BMI), which would warrant enhanced screening for these conditions.

See “Screening recommendations for nonpregnant women by age” table.

The US Preventive Services Task Force recommends screening women between 30 and 65 years of age for cervical cancer using any of the following strategies: every 3 years with cervical cytology, every 5 years with testing for high-risk human papillomavirus (hrHPV) testing, or every 5 years with hrHPV testing in combination with cytology. This patient had a normal Pap smear with testing for human papillomavirus 2 years ago, so she does not require further screening at this time.

question_text: A 30-year-old nulligravid woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She has no history of serious illness. Menses have occurred at regular 28-day intervals since menarche at the age of 11 years and last for 5 days. The first day of her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. She is sexually active with her husband and takes oral contraceptive pills. Her last Pap smear was 3 years ago. She has never had a mammogram. Her mother and maternal aunt died of breast cancer in their early 50s. Pelvic examination shows a normal vagina and cervix. Bimanual examination shows a normal-sized uterus and no palpable adnexal masses. Which of the following health maintenance recommendations is most appropriate at this time?
content_preview: A 30-year-old nulligravid woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She has no history of serious illness. Menses have occurred at regular 28-day intervals since menarche at the age of 11 years and last for 5 days. The first day of her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. She is sexually active with her husband and takes oral contraceptive pills. Her last Pap smear was 3 years ago. She has never had a mammogram. Her mother and maternal aunt died of breast cancer in their early 50s. Pelvic examination shows a normal vagina and cervix. Bimanual examination shows a normal-sized uterus and no palpable adnexal masses. Which of the following health maintenance recommendations is most appropriate at this time?
hint: This patient is healthy and requires the standard screening tests for her age group and risk stratification according to USPSTF guidelines.
learning_objective: Choose the appropriate cancer screening tests and intervals for a woman based on age and risk factors.

answers.content: Pap smear now and every 3 years, mammography at age 50 years
answers.explanation_why: According to the USPSTF, a Pap smear every 3 years in individuals with a cervix who are 21–29 years of age is an acceptable screening method for cervical cancer. However, an additional test is required as a part of cervical cancer screening starting at the age of 30 years. In addition, breast cancer screening is typically started at 40 years of age.

answers.content: Pap smear and human papillomavirus testing now and every year, mammography at age 40 years
answers.explanation_why: Mammography at the age of 40 years is appropriate for this patient since the USPSTF recommends breast cancer screening with mammography every 2 years from 40–74 years of age. Also, this patient should now receive HPV testing along with a Pap smear to screen for cervical cancer. However, HPV/Pap cotesting should not be repeated annually because more frequent testing does not increase the cancer detection rate and is associated with a higher rate of unnecessary colposcopies.

answers.content: Pap smear now and every 5 years, mammography at age 40 years
answers.explanation_why: Mammography at the age of 40 years is appropriate for this patient since the USPSTF recommends breast cancer screening with mammography every 2 years from 40–74 years of age. Also, the USPSTF recommends cervical cancer screening every 5 years starting at 30 years of age. However, when screening every 5 years, the protocol requires another test in addition to the Pap smear. If the additional test cannot be performed, a Pap smear should be taken every 3 years.

answers.content: Pap smear and human papillomavirus testing now and every 3 years, mammography at age 40 years
answers.explanation_why: Mammography at the age of 40 years is appropriate for this patient since the USPSTF recommends breast cancer screening with mammography every 2 years between 40–74 years of age. Also, the USPSTF recommends an HPV test along with a Pap smear to screen for cervical cancer, starting at 30 years of age. However, HPV/Pap cotesting should be repeated every 5 years rather than every 3 years because more frequent screening does not increase the cancer detection rate and is associated with a higher rate of unnecessary colposcopies.

answers.content: Pap smear and human papillomavirus testing now and every 5 years, mammography at age 40 years
answers.explanation_why:
The USPSTF recommends HPV/Pap cotesting every 5 years for individuals with a cervix who are 30–65 years of age and a solitary Pap smear every 3 years for those between 21–29 years of age. This guidance differs from the recently updated ASCCP, ACS, and ACOG guidelines, which recommend that those aged 25–65 years undergo cervical cancer screening with primary HPV testing (where available) or HPV/Pap cotesting every 5 years. All guidelines recommend a solitary Pap smear every 3 years if HPV testing is unavailable.

Regarding breast cancer, mammography is rarely useful in younger patients, who have naturally denser breast tissue. According to the USPSTF, breast cancer screening with mammography should be performed every 2 years between 40–74 years of age. Screening can be started earlier in patients with first-degree relatives with breast cancer. Breast cancer screening recommendations may differ between medical organizations (e.g., ACOG, ACS). Consult our table “Breast cancer screening for individuals at average risk” for the most up-to-date information on breast cancer screening recommendations.

Whenever the information required to determine the correct answer for an NBME question involves a discrepancy between screening guidelines, we recommend following USPSTF recommendations.

answers.content: Pap smear and human papillomavirus testing now and every 3 years, mammography at age 50 years
answers.explanation_why: The USPSTF recommends an HPV test along with a Pap smear to screen for cervical cancer, starting at 30 years of age. However, HPV/Pap cotesting should be repeated every 5 years rather than every 3 years because more frequent screening does not increase the cancer detection rate and is associated with a higher rate of unnecessary colposcopies. Moreover, breast cancer screening is typically started at 40 years of age.

question_text: A 24-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine pelvic examination. She feels well. Menses occur at 30-day intervals and last 7 days. Her last menstrual period was 6 days ago. Her last Pap smear was 13 months ago and there is no history of abnormal findings. She is sexually active with three male partners and uses condoms consistently. She has never been tested for sexually transmitted infections. Her 54-year-old mother has breast cancer. She did not receive a human papillomavirus vaccine. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 68/min, and blood pressure is 108/68 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. In addition to HIV, gonorrhea, chlamydia, and syphilis testing, which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation at this time?
content_preview: A 24-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine pelvic examination. She feels well. Menses occur at 30-day intervals and last 7 days. Her last menstrual period was 6 days ago. Her last Pap smear was 13 months ago and there is no history of abnormal findings. She is sexually active with three male partners and uses condoms consistently. She has never been tested for sexually transmitted infections. Her 54-year-old mother has breast cancer. She did not receive a human papillomavirus vaccine. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 68/min, and blood pressure is 108/68 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. In addition to HIV, gonorrhea, chlamydia, and syphilis testing, which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation at this time?
hint: This patient's history and age determine the most appropriate recommendation at this time.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate vaccination for a sexually active young adult woman.

answers.explanation_why:
As part of the routine immunization schedule, the CDC states that two doses of the nine-valent human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine should be administered six to twelve months apart to all individuals aged 9–14 years. For all unvaccinated female individuals aged 15–26 years, the CDC recommends vaccination with three doses of the nine-valent HPV vaccine at 0, 2, and 6 months. The HPV vaccine is approved by the FDA for individuals up to the age of 45 years, but it is not routinely recommended by the CDC for individuals aged > 26 years.

Condoms lower the risk of, but do not protect against, HPV infection because HPV can still be transmitted via genital skin-to-skin contact or oral sex.

For women aged between 21 and 29 years, the USPSTF recommends a Pap smear every three years. Since this patient had a normal Pap smear 13 months ago, another Pap smear is not required for nearly another two years.

The most common indication for a pregnancy test is recent-onset secondary amenorrhea in a patient of childbearing age. Because her last menstrual period was six days ago, this patient does not have amenorrhea. If this 24-year-old woman had acute lower abdominal pain, a pregnancy test would be indicated to rule out an ectopic pregnancy. However, there is currently no indication for performing a pregnancy test in this asymptomatic patient presenting for a routine pelvic examination.

Cotesting refers to simultaneous Pap smear and HPV testing. It is the USPSTF's recommended cervical cancer screening of choice for women aged between 30 and 65 years every five years. In this 24-year-old patient, the USPSTF instead recommends a Pap smear every three years. Unfortunately, cancer screening recommendations can be confusing because the USPSTF guidelines differ from the recently updated ASCCP/ACS/ACOG guidelines, which recommend that women aged 25–65 years should undergo cervical cancer screening with primary HPV testing (preferred where available) every five years, cotesting (HPV testing and Pap smear) every five years, or a solitary Pap smear every three years. But this patient is not yet 25 years of age and also had a normal Pap smear 13 months ago. Regardless, if the information required to determine the correct option for NBME questions is associated with a discrepancy between screening guidelines, we recommend following USPSTF guidelines.

HPV testing and a simultaneous Pap smear, known as cotesting, is recommended by the USPSTF for cervical cancer screening for patients aged 30–65 years every five years. Unfortunately, cancer screening recommendations can be confusing because the USPSTF guidelines differ from the recently updated ASCCP/ACS/ACOG guidelines, which recommend women aged 25–65 years should undergo cervical cancer screening with primary HPV testing alone (preferred where available) every five years, cotesting (HPV testing and Pap smear) every five years, or a solitary Pap smear every three years. But this patient is not yet 25 years of age and also had a normal Pap smear 13 months ago. Regardless, if the information required to determine the correct option for NBME questions is associated with a discrepancy between screening guidelines, we recommend following USPSTF guidelines.

question_text: A 25-year-old primigravid woman at 10 weeks' gestation comes to her physician accompanied by her husband for her first prenatal visit. She has no personal or family history of serious illness. Her vaccinations are up-to-date and she takes no medications. She has no history of illicit drug use and does not drink alcohol. Her vital signs are within normal limits. She is 167 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 68 kg (150 lb); BMI is 24 kg/m^2. She tested negative for HIV, Chlamydia trachomatis, and Neisseria gonorrhoeae 4 years ago. Testing for which of the following infections should be performed at this visit?
content_preview: A 25-year-old primigravid woman at 10 weeks' gestation comes to her physician accompanied by her husband for her first prenatal visit. She has no personal or family history of serious illness. Her vaccinations are up-to-date and she takes no medications. She has no history of illicit drug use and does not drink alcohol. Her vital signs are within normal limits. She is 167 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 68 kg (150 lb); BMI is 24 kg/m2. She tested negative for HIV, Chlamydia trachomatis, and Neisseria gonorrhoeae 4 years ago. Testing for which of the following infections should be performed at this visit?
hint: Sexually transmitted infections (STIs) can have serious consequences for both the mother and the baby.
learning_objective: Recognize the recommended prenatal infection screenings, and choose the appropriate tests for a first prenatal visit.

answers.content: Group B streptococci, syphilis, tuberculosis, and HIV
answers.explanation_why: Screening for syphilis and HIV is recommended for all pregnant individuals at the first prenatal visit. Prenatal screening for Group B streptococcus is performed between 36 0/7 and 37 6/7 weeks of gestation. Screening for tuberculosis is recommended only in patients with risk factors for TB.

answers.content: Hepatitis C, hepatitis B, cytomegalovirus, and herpes simplex virus
answers.explanation_why: Screening for hepatitis C and hepatitis B is recommended in all pregnant individuals at the first prenatal visit. Screening for herpes simplex virus is not routinely performed; testing is indicated in patients with active genital ulcers. Screening for cytomegalovirus is not recommended during pregnancy because serological tests cannot distinguish between recurrent and primary infection (which poses a greater risk to the fetus), antibody titers cannot predict transmission to the fetus, and treatment of the mother does not prevent neonatal infection.

answers.content: Group B streptococci, tuberculosis, cytomegalovirus, and herpes simplex virus
answers.explanation_why: Prenatal screening for Group B streptococcus is performed between 36 0/7 and 37 6/7 weeks of gestation. Screening for tuberculosis is recommended only in patients with risk factors for TB. Screening for herpes simplex virus is not routinely performed; testing is indicated in patients with active genital ulcers. Screening for cytomegalovirus is not recommended during pregnancy because serological tests cannot distinguish between recurrent and primary infection (which poses a greater risk to the fetus), antibody titers cannot predict transmission to the fetus, and treatment of the mother does not prevent neonatal infection.

answers.content: HIV, syphilis, hepatitis B, and hepatitis C
answers.explanation_why:
The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists recommend testing all pregnant individuals for HIV (using fourth-generation HIV test), syphilis (using nontreponemal tests, such as VDRL or rapid plasma reagin tests), hepatitis B infection (using HBsAg), and hepatitis C infection (using anti-HCV antibody). All pregnant individuals who are < 25 years or have high risk of infection with Chlamydia and N. gonorrhea should also be screened at the first prenatal visit for Chlamydia and N. gonorrhea infection by PCR of vaginal swabs. All of the tests should be performed at the first prenatal visit, even if any prior test results for these infections were negative.

Pregnant individuals who have not had chickenpox (or have not received the varicella vaccine) and/or those without documentation of seropositivity against rubella should have their anti-varicella and anti-rubella IgG titers measured. Routine prenatal screening for Mycobacterium tuberculosis, cytomegalovirus, herpes simplex virus, Toxoplasma gondii, or parvovirus B19 infections, or routine prenatal serological testing for immunity against these infections, is not recommended.

answers.content: No infection testing is necessary at this visit
answers.explanation_why: Screening for certain infections should be performed during the first trimester at the first prenatal visit so that the patient can be counseled on the risk and prevention of vertical transmission.

question_text: A 33-year-old woman comes to the physician because she had a positive pregnancy test at home. She reports feeling nauseated and has vomited several times over the past week. During this period, she has also had increased urinary frequency. She is sexually active with her boyfriend and they use condoms inconsistently. Her last menstrual period was 5 weeks ago. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A serum pregnancy test is positive. HPV testing is positive. A Pap smear shows a high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion. Colposcopy and cervical biopsy show cervical intraepithelial neoplasia grade II and III. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 33-year-old woman comes to the physician because she had a positive pregnancy test at home. She reports feeling nauseated and has vomited several times over the past week. During this period, she has also had increased urinary frequency. She is sexually active with her boyfriend and they use condoms inconsistently. Her last menstrual period was 5 weeks ago. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A serum pregnancy test is positive. HPV testing is positive. A Pap smear shows a high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion. Colposcopy and cervical biopsy show cervical intraepithelial neoplasia grade II and III. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This pregnant patient presents with a high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL) on Pap smear and cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) II and CIN III on histology.
learning_objective: Recognize high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion in pregnancy, and choose the most appropriate surveillance method.

answers.content: Colposcopy and HPV-based testing in 12 weeks
answers.explanation_why:
In pregnant women with high-grade precancerous lesions (i.e., CIN2 or CIN3), colposcopic surveillance with HPV-based testing every 12–24 weeks is preferred. Deferring colposcopy until ≥ 4 weeks after delivery is also an acceptable approach. The management of pregnant individuals with high-grade lesions differs from that of nonpregnant patients: treatment of premalignant lesions can safely be deferred until the postpartum period; expedited treatment for HSIL is contraindicated during pregnancy. A repeat biopsy should be performed if the cervical lesion appears to be worsening on colposcopic surveillance. An excisional procedure should be considered only if invasive cancer is suspected.

Colposcopy and biopsy are safe during pregnancy but endocervical curettage and endometrial biopsies are contraindicated.

Cold-knife conization is used in the management of high-grade cervical abnormalities and early-stage cervical cancer. Cold-knife conization is contraindicated during pregnancy but can be safely performed 4 weeks after birth. However, before any cervical excision procedure, repeat colposcopic evaluation needs to re-confirm the need for excision.

Endocervical curettage (ECC) is usually performed in women with high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL) to allow sampling of the endocervical canal. The procedure may identify contiguous and noncontiguous ("skip") lesions. ECC is contraindicated during pregnancy because it may cause potential trauma to the gestational sac and heavy bleeding.

answers.content: Expedited treatment with loop electrosurgical excision
answers.explanation_why: Expedited treatment (e.g., with loop surgical excision) is indicated in nonpregnant women with a high immediate risk of CIN III+ risk (e.g., patients with high-grade cervical lesions and positive HPV testing). However, during pregnancy, excisional treatment is only considered if cancer is suspected as excisional procedures increase the risk of poor pregnancy outcomes (e.g., abortion, preterm labor).
In pregnancy, repeat cervical biopsy is only indicated if invasion is suspected, which is not the case here, or if the cervical lesion appears to be worsening on surveillance.

question_text: A 43-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine gynecological examination. She feels well. Menses occur at regular 28-day intervals and last for 3 to 5 days with normal flow. Her last menstrual period was 20 days ago. She is sexually active with one male partner and uses condoms inconsistently. Her sister was diagnosed with breast cancer at the age of 40 years. She has smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for the past 15 years and occasionally drinks a glass of wine with dinner. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination, including pelvic examination, shows no abnormalities. A urine pregnancy test is negative. A Pap smear shows atypical glandular cells. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 43-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine gynecological examination. She feels well. Menses occur at regular 28-day intervals and last for 3 to 5 days with normal flow. Her last menstrual period was 20 days ago. She is sexually active with one male partner and uses condoms inconsistently. Her sister was diagnosed with breast cancer at the age of 40 years. She has smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for the past 15 years and occasionally drinks a glass of wine with dinner. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination, including pelvic examination, shows no abnormalities. A urine pregnancy test is negative. A Pap smear shows atypical glandular cells. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Consider the age of the patient and the cytology findings of atypical glandular cells (AGCs) to determine the next best step.
learning_objective: Recognize atypical glandular cells on a Pap smear, and choose the most appropriate next step in management.

answers.explanation_why: One-year follow-up is appropriate for patients with a low immediate risk of CIN3+ lesions (e.g., patients with low-grade cytology and negative HPV testing) but should include both cytology and HPV testing. Additionally, the presence of AGCs on cytology should raise concern for endometrial cancer, making a different step more appropriate.

answers.content: Perform colposcopy with endocervical and endometrial sampling
answers.explanation_why:
Colposcopy with endocervical sampling is appropriate for all nonpregnant patients with AGCs to rule out cervical cancer, regardless of HPV test results. In addition, endometrial sampling should be performed in nonpregnant patients with AGCs who are ≥ 35 years of age and in nonpregnant patients aged < 35 years with AGCs and abnormal uterine bleeding or risk factors for endometrial neoplasia (e.g., obesity, chronic anovulation) to rule out endometrial cancer.

Endocervical and endometrial sampling are contraindicated in pregnancy because of the increased risk of complications (e.g., cervical or membrane perforation, pregnancy loss).

answers.content: Perform a diagnostic loop electrosurgical excision
answers.explanation_why: Diagnostic excisional procedures such as loop electrosurgical excision procedure (LEEP) are indicated in patients with a very high immediate risk of CIN 3+ lesions based on initial cytology and HPV testing. This patient has AGCs and therefore a different step should be performed before an excisional procedure is considered.
HPV testing is not required for patients with AGCs, as HPV status does not influence the course of management. HPV testing may be performed during the initial routine screening for cervical cancer.

Patients with AGCs on Pap smear should urgently undergo colposcopy with endocervical sampling to rule out cervical squamous intraepithelial lesions and cervical adenocarcinoma in situ. However, in patients ≥ 35 years of age with AGCs on Pap smear, an additional procedure should be performed.

question_text: A 34-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She has gastroesophageal reflux disease. She recently moved to a new city. Her father was diagnosed with colon cancer at the age of 46 years. Her paternal uncle died because of small bowel cancer. Her paternal grandfather died because of stomach cancer. Current medications include esomeprazole and a multivitamin. She smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 6 years but quit 2 years ago. She drinks one to two alcoholic beverages on weekends. She appears healthy. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Colonoscopy is unremarkable. Germline testing via DNA sequencing in this patient shows mutations in DNA repair genes MLH1 and MSH2. Which of the following will this patient most likely require at some point in her life?
content_preview: A 34-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She has gastroesophageal reflux disease. She recently moved to a new city. Her father was diagnosed with colon cancer at the age of 46 years. Her paternal uncle died because of small bowel cancer. Her paternal grandfather died because of stomach cancer. Current medications include esomeprazole and a multivitamin. She smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 6 years but quit 2 years ago. She drinks one to two alcoholic beverages on weekends. She appears healthy. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Colonoscopy is unremarkable. Germline testing via DNA sequencing in this patient shows mutations in DNA repair genes MLH1 and MSH2. Which of the following will this patient most likely require at some point in her life?
hint: This woman has three family members with gastrointestinal cancers in two different generations, and one relative was under the age of 50 when diagnosed (3-2-1 rule). These findings fulfill the Amsterdam II criteria for Lynch syndrome, which is caused by mutations in various DNA mismatch repair genes (e.g., MLH1, MSH2).
learning_objective: Recognize Lynch syndrome, and recall its recommended cancer prevention strategies.

answers.explanation_why: The most common extracolonic malignancy associated with Lynch syndrome is endometrial cancer. Female patients with Lynch syndrome have a ∼ 40% lifetime risk of developing endometrial cancer, with most cases occurring in premenopausal women. Lynch syndrome is also associated with an increased lifetime risk of developing ovarian cancer (∼ 10%). Hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy at the end of childbearing age (∼ 40 years) is therefore recommended. In addition, women with Lynch syndrome should receive annual pelvic examination with transvaginal ultrasonography and endometrial biopsy starting at the age of 30–35 years. Patients with Lynch syndrome should also undergo annual colonoscopy beginning at 20–25 years of age to screen for colorectal cancer.

answers.content: Surgical removal of a desmoid tumor
answers.explanation_why: Desmoid tumors are an extracolonic manifestation of Gardner syndrome. If the tumor is symptomatic and resectable, surgical excision with a tumor free margin is the treatment of choice; desmoid tumors are locally aggressive in nature and carry a risk of local recurrence. Patients with Gardner syndrome would already have polyps on colonoscopy by adolescence, however, and germline testing would show a mutation in the adenomatous polyposis coli (APC) gene.

A pylorus-preserving pancreaticoduodenectomy is a surgical option for pancreatic carcinomas located in the pancreatic head. While pancreatic cancer has been found to be associated with Lynch syndrome in rare cases, another malignancy that necessitates a different form of management is much more commonly associated with Lynch syndrome.

Bilateral prophylactic mastectomy is a risk-reducing surgery offered to women with a high lifetime risk of developing breast cancer (e.g., those with a BRCA mutation). Currently, there is insufficient evidence to suggest that individuals with Lynch syndrome have an increased lifetime risk of developing breast cancer, making bilateral prophylactic mastectomy inappropriate.

Prophylactic subtotal or total proctocolectomy with ileoanal anastomosis is recommended in patients with familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP). A family history of gastrointestinal malignancy is also seen in FAP. However, patients with FAP would have numerous polyps on colonoscopy by adolescence, and germline testing would show a mutation in the adenomatous polyposis coli (APC) gene rather than in MLH1 and MSH2. Patients with Lynch syndrome are at high risk of gastrointestinal malignancies and should receive an annual colonoscopy beginning at 20–25 years of age to screen for colorectal cancer, but prophylactic proctocolectomy is not recommended.

answers.content: Annual measurement of carcinoembryonic antigen and CA 19-9
answers.explanation_why: Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) and CA 19-9 are tumor markers for colorectal and endometrial cancers. CEA and CA 19-9 are mainly tested to monitor treatment response and to detect tumor recurrence (by recording the rise/fall of tumor markers) if levels are elevated at cancer diagnosis. Although individuals with Lynch syndrome show an increased risk of developing these malignancies, screening with CEA and CA 19-9 is not done because they are neither specific nor sensitive enough.

question_text: A 68-year-old man comes to the physician 3 months after noticing skin changes on his scalp. When he scrapes off the crust of the lesion, it reappears after a few days. Occasionally, his scalp itches or he notices a burning sensation. He had a mole removed on his right forearm 5 years ago. He is a retired winemaker. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows multiple rough patches on his scalp. A photograph is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 68-year-old man comes to the physician 3 months after noticing skin changes on his scalp. When he scrapes off the crust of the lesion, it reappears after a few days. Occasionally, his scalp itches or he notices a burning sensation. He had a mole removed on his right forearm 5 years ago. He is a retired winemaker. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows multiple rough patches on his scalp. A photograph is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: The scalp is covered with telangiectasias, light brown papules, and erythematous, hyperkeratotic plaques. This condition is the result of chronic, unprotected sun exposure (e.g., from working outdoors).
learning_objective: Recognize actinic keratosis.

answers.explanation_why: Seborrheic keratosis is the most common benign skin tumor in the older population. However, in contrast to this patient's rough, patchy lesions, it manifests as darkly pigmented papules or plaques that are soft, sharply demarcated, and appear greasy, wax-like, and “stuck-on.” Also, the lesions tend to involve the trunk, back of the hands, face and neck, and forearms, rather than the scalp.

images.title: Seborrheic keratosis
images.description: Photograph of the upper body of an older adult (dorsal view)Multiple sharply demarcated, darkly pigmented hyperkeratotic papules are visible. The papules have a characteristic stuck on appearance.Seborrheic keratosis is a benign skin tumor that arises from keratinocytes and is common in older adults.

answers.explanation_why: Basal cell carcinomas (BCCs) are the most common skin tumors and occur on areas of skin exposed to sun. Given his former occupation, this patient is at increased risk of developing BCCs. However, in contrast to this patient's lesions, which manifest as erythematous, hyperkeratotic plaques, BCCs present as pearly, indurated, and nodular lesions with a rolled border and a central depression (crater) with ulceration.

images.title: Nodular basal cell carcinoma
images.description: An asymmetric nodule (approx. 1 cm in diameter) with central ulceration, and rolled-out edges is visible on the right medial canthus.This appearance is typical of nodular basal cell carcinoma.

answers.explanation_why: While keratoacanthomas tend to occur in older patients who have had chronic sun exposure, such as this patient, they manifest as a round erythematous nodule with a central crater that grows rapidly, usually within weeks to months. In this patient, the multiple erythematous lesions with scales found on the scalp are more suggestive of a different diagnosis.

images.title: Preauricular keratoacanthoma
images.description: An erythematous nodule with a central indentation that developed in the course of 7 weeks.These findings are consistent with keratoacanthoma, which typically manifests with a central hyperkeratotic plug, leaving an indentation after removal (as seen here).

answers.explanation_why: Tinea capitis affects the scalp and manifests as round, scaly plaques with broken hair shafts or alopecia in the affected areas. Although this patient has mild itching, tinea capitis is usually associated with intense pruritus. Also, tinea capitis mainly affects small children and generally occurs in areas that contain hair follicles, making it an unlikely diagnosis in this 68-year-old bald man.

images.title: Tinea capitis
images.description:
Localization: scalp
Primary lesion: nodule
Description: slightly elevated, reddened, papular, and pustular nodule with scaling and hair loss, caused by the dermatophyte Microsporum gypseum

answers.explanation_why:
Actinic keratosis is a precancerous lesion that occurs on sun-exposed skin (e.g., the scalp, face, ears, dorsal aspects of the hands or arms) and predominantly affects light-skinned individuals over 50 years of age. The lesions typically grow back after they are scraped off. Initially, actinic keratosis manifests as small lesions with a central scale and a rough surface, giving them a sandpaper-like texture on palpation. Later, the lesions may grow and become erythematous and scaly, as seen in this patient. The risk of progression to invasive squamous cell carcinoma depends on the degree of epithelial dysplasia, but it is < 1% per year. Occasionally, hyperkeratosis may turn preexisting actinic keratosis lesions into cutaneous horns.

Actinic keratosis is usually a clinical diagnosis, although for lesions that are ≥ 1 cm, grow rapidly, or do not respond to treatment, a biopsy is necessary to distinguish it from squamous cell carcinoma. Treatment options include cryotherapy for isolated lesions, or 5-fluorouracil, imiquimod, or photodynamic therapy in patients with multiple lesions.

images.title: Actinic keratosis of the scalp
images.description: Frontal and parietal scalp of a male older adultMultiple, partially confluent, hyperpigmented and hypopigmented macules of different size are visible. Some of these lesions have scaling, and some are covered in yellow to black-brown crusts.These findings are characteristic of actinic keratosis.

answers.explanation_why: Bowen disease is commonly associated with sun exposure and may be similar in appearance to this patient's lesion. However, it usually manifests as a solitary lesion rather than the multiple ill-defined, confluent lesions seen on this patient's scalp. While Bowen disease cannot be entirely excluded without pathologic examination, based on the appearance of the lesions, another diagnosis is more likely in this patient.

Amelanotic melanomas are associated with UV exposure and may be difficult to recognize, but they usually manifest as a pink or red macule, plaque, or nodule. Multiple erythematous, hyperkeratotic plaques with a rough texture suggest a different diagnosis.

images.title: Amelanotic melanoma
images.description: A solitary, red nodule on an erythematous base with slight hyperpigmentation on the bottom-right is visible.Full-thickness excisional biopsy confirmed the diagnosis of amelanotic melanoma.

images.title: Actinic keratosis
images.description: The entire hairless portion of the scalp is covered with telangiectasia, light brown papules, and yellow-brownish, hyperkeratotic plaques.This appearance is typical of actinic keratoses.

question_text: A 57-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of increasing shortness of breath on exertion and a cough productive of a small amount of grayish-white phlegm. The cough had been initially nonproductive. He has not had fever or chest pain. He is originally from China and visits his family there once every year. He has worked as a car salesman for 15 years and worked in a shipyard before that for 22 years. He smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for 13 years but stopped 25 years ago. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 86/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Fine expiratory crackles are heard at both lung bases. An x-ray of the chest shows patchy infiltrates and supradiaphragmatic pleural thickening in both lungs. A photomicrograph from a sputum sample is shown. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
content_preview: A 57-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of increasing shortness of breath on exertion and a cough productive of a small amount of grayish-white phlegm. The cough had been initially nonproductive. He has not had fever or chest pain. He is originally from China and visits his family there once every year. He has worked as a car salesman for 15 years and worked in a shipyard before that for 22 years. He smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for 13 years but stopped 25 years ago. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 86/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Fine expiratory crackles are heard at both lung bases. An x-ray of the chest shows patchy infiltrates and supradiaphragmatic pleural thickening in both lungs. A photomicrograph from a sputum sample is shown. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
hint: This patient sputum sample shows an elongated, yellow rod (i.e., an asbestos body).
learning_objective: Recognize asbestosis, and recall its expected pulmonary function test finding.

answers.explanation_why: This patient’s presentation (exertional dyspnea, cough, bibasilar crackles) and diagnostic test findings (asbestos bodies on sputum analysis, pleural thickening on chest x-ray) indicate asbestosis. Patients with asbestosis may develop interstitial lung disease with parenchymal fibrosis, which impairs the diffusion of oxygen across the alveolocapillary membrane, causing an increase in the alveolar-arterial gradient.

A bloody pleural effusion could be seen in mesothelioma caused by asbestosis. This patient's occupational history certainly puts him at risk for developing malignancy. However, he is currently not exhibiting signs associated with mesothelioma, such as fever, sweats, weight loss, or fatigue. Also, there are no signs on the physical exam or imaging that indicate effusion in this patient.

A positive interferon-γ release assay would indicate infection with M. tuberculosis. This patient has a considerable risk of tuberculosis since he is originally from China, a country with a high incidence of the disease, and visits yearly. However, active pulmonary tuberculosis typically manifests with a productive cough (possibly hemoptysis), as well as fever and weight loss. Furthermore, pleural thickening and the absence of hilar lymphadenopathy or cavitation on x-ray are not consistent with this diagnosis.

images.title: Pulmonary tuberculosis
images.description:
Active pulmonary tuberculosis (TB) typically manifests with systemic (e.g., low-grade fever, night sweats, weight loss, decreased appetite, and malaise) and pulmonary symptoms (e.g., dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain due to pleural effusion, productive cough, and possibly hemoptysis in advanced stages).
Symptomatic TB can occur as a result of primary infection (primary active TB) or reactivation of latent infection (reactivation TB). While symptoms are similar in both conditions, radiographic presentation differs.
Radiographic imaging in primary TB commonly shows a Ghon complex (Ghon focus with its associated lymph node), unilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, and homogenous consolidation with ill-defined borders in the middle and lower lobes. Chest x-ray in reactivation TB typically shows multiple cavities in the upper lobes, calcifications, patchy consolidations, and features fibroproliferative disease (e.g, scarring) due to inflammatory tissue destruction.

answers.explanation_why: Lung capacity can be increased in obstructive lung diseases such as emphysema. This patient may have mild obstructive lung changes from his smoking history. However, the findings on x-ray and from the sputum sample indicate a restrictive disease that would result in a decreased lung capacity.

A concave flow-volume loop is seen in obstructive lung disease and is due to increased resistance during expiration. In a patient with suspected asbestosis, the flow-volume loop would be expected to show a restrictive pattern. This means it would have a normal shape, but a decreased overall volume.

Diffusing capacity (DL_CO) is increased when gases like oxygen, or carbon monoxide in the pulmonary test, are easily transported across the capillary membrane within the alveoli. This can be seen in bronchial asthma, obesity, and polycythemia vera. However, this patient's interstitial lung disease causes fibrosis and therefore thickening of capillary membrane, which reduces diffusing capacity.

images.title: Asbestosis
images.description: Photomicrograph of a sputum sample (H&E stain; high magnification)A yellow-brown asbestos body is visible (green overlay). It is coated by iron-containing proteinaceous material and has a characteristic dumbbell shape (illustration).

question_text: A 3-month-old girl is brought to the physician because of a 5-day history of a productive cough. Over the past month, she has had several episodes of watery stools. She is exclusively breastfed every 3–4 hours for 15–20 minutes. She was delivered vaginally at 38 weeks' gestation at home and has not yet been evaluated by a physician. The mother reports that her child is not gaining weight. The mother had no prenatal care. The infant has not received any immunizations. She is at the 5^th percentile for height and weight. Her temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 155/min, respirations are 45/min, and blood pressure is 88/50 mm Hg. Physical examination shows white plaques covering the tongue and the palate. Cervical and inguinal lymphadenopathy is present. On pulmonary examination, crackles are heard over the lung fields bilaterally. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
content_preview: A 3-month-old girl is brought to the physician because of a 5-day history of a productive cough. Over the past month, she has had several episodes of watery stools. She is exclusively breastfed every 3–4 hours for 15–20 minutes. She was delivered vaginally at 38 weeks' gestation at home and has not yet been evaluated by a physician. The mother reports that her child is not gaining weight. The mother had no prenatal care. The infant has not received any immunizations. She is at the 5th percentile for height and weight. Her temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 155/min, respirations are 45/min, and blood pressure is 88/50 mm Hg. Physical examination shows white plaques covering the tongue and the palate. Cervical and inguinal lymphadenopathy is present. On pulmonary examination, crackles are heard over the lung fields bilaterally. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
hint: This patient's symptoms (respiratory infection, chronic diarrhea, failure to thrive, lymphadenopathy, thrush) are most likely the result of an impaired immune system. Her mother did not attend any prenatal visits, increasing the possibility of a congenital infection.
learning_objective: Recognize congenital HIV infection, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic study.

answers.explanation_why: Karyotyping can confirm the diagnosis of several genetic disorders such as Down syndrome. Patients with Down syndrome have a higher susceptibility to respiratory infections, but cervical and inguinal lymphadenopathy, white plaques on the tongue, and chronic diarrhea indicate a more generalized immunodeficiency. In addition, this patient lacks characteristic physical findings of Down syndrome such as micrognathia, flat nasal bridge, hypertelorism, and epicanthal folds.

The dihydrorhodamine test is positive in patients with chronic granulomatous disease (CGD). CGD commonly manifests with failure to thrive, lymphadenopathy, respiratory infections, and diarrhea in the first year of life. However, infections in CGD are typically recurrent and other manifestations such as skin, gastrointestinal, or genitourinary granulomas are expected. In addition, this disorder is caused by an X-linked recessive defect, but the patient is female, which makes a diagnosis of CGD very unlikely.

DNA testing for CFTR mutation is used for the diagnosis of cystic fibrosis (CF). Although patients with CF also have failure to thrive and pulmonary infections, they additionally often develop meconium ileus, and foul-smelling diarrhea due to fat malabsorption, in contrast to this patient's watery diarrhea. Moreover, CF alone would not explain this patient's inguinal and cervical lymphadenopathy and thrush.

Fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption test is used in the diagnosis of congenital syphilis. Although this patient's mother did not have any prenatal care, and syphilis is a possible congenital infection (TORCH), it typically presents with nasal discharge, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, skeletal abnormalities, and skin manifestations, none of which are present in this patient.

Flow cytometry of B lymphocytes is used for diagnosing immunodeficiencies due to B-cell abnormalities, such as X-linked agammaglobulinemia (XLA), which usually manifests 3–6 months after birth with recurrent bacterial infections (e.g., pneumonia). However, fungal infections, such as candida, are not typical in XLA. Furthermore, lymphoid tissue is not found in patients with XLA, whereas this patient has lymphadenopathy. In addition, XLA is an X-linked recessive disease that typically appears in boys and is therefore not the most likely diagnosis for this female patient.

images.title: Bruton agammaglobulinemia fact sheet
images.description: BTK: B-cell tyrosine kinase

answers.content: Polymerase chain reaction for viral genes
answers.explanation_why:
This patient's presentation suggests vertical transmission of HIV, for which lack of prenatal care, vaginal delivery, and breastfeeding are risk factors. A polymerase chain reaction test (PCR test) is used to diagnose HIV in children < 18 months of age. An enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) cannot be used in children < 18 months of age, because maternal HIV IgG antibodies are able to cross the placenta, possibly leading to false-positive results.

HIV testing is recommended for all pregnant women in the first trimester. In pregnant patients with HIV and an unknown viral load, scheduled cesarean delivery is usually recommended at 38 weeks' gestation to decrease the risk of vertical transmission. In mothers with HIV who have infants without HIV, breastfeeding should be avoided if possible. However, in resource-limited countries, breastfeeding may be considered. Maternal adherence to antiretroviral therapy decreases the risk of HIV transmission from breast milk.

Analysis of T-cell receptor excision circles is used for the diagnosis of severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID). Although SCID typically manifests with respiratory infections, chronic diarrhea, thrush, and failure to thrive, it is most often inherited in an X-linked pattern and thus unlikely in a female patient. In addition, lymph nodes and tonsils may be absent in SCID, unlike the lymphadenopathy seen in this girl.
