question_text: A 32-year-old nulliparous woman with polycystic ovary syndrome comes to the physician for a pelvic examination and cervical cancer screening. Last year she had a progestin-releasing intrauterine device placed. Menarche occurred at the age of 10 years. She became sexually active at the age of 14 years. Her mother had breast cancer at the age of 51 years. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 79 kg (174 lb); BMI is 29 kg/m^2. Examination shows mild facial acne. HPV testing is positive. Cytology shows high-grade cervical intraepithelial neoplasia. Colposcopy with biopsy shows cervical intraepithelial neoplasia grade II. Which of the following is this patient's strongest predisposing factor for developing this condition?
content_preview: A 32-year-old nulliparous woman with polycystic ovary syndrome comes to the physician for a pelvic examination and cervical cancer screening. Last year she had a progestin-releasing intrauterine device placed. Menarche occurred at the age of 10 years. She became sexually active at the age of 14 years. Her mother had breast cancer at the age of 51 years. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 79 kg (174 lb); BMI is 29 kg/m2. Examination shows mild facial acne. HPV testing is positive. Cytology shows high-grade cervical intraepithelial neoplasia. Colposcopy with biopsy shows cervical intraepithelial neoplasia grade II. Which of the following is this patient's strongest predisposing factor for developing this condition?
hint: Cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) is strongly associated with human papillomavirus (HPV) infection, especially the high-risk HPV types 16 and 18.
learning_objective: Recall the risk factors for cervical intraepithelial neoplasia.

answers.explanation_why: HPV serotypes 16 and 18 are oncogenic viruses that increase the risk of CIN by producing the oncogenic proteins E6 and E7. The strongest predisposing factors for HPV infection are the early onset of sexual activity and multiple sexual partners. Women who engage in sexual activity before the age of 18 years are at twice the risk of cervical cancer compared to women who are 21 years or older when they first have intercourse. The risk of cervical cancer in women who have had ≥ 6 sexual partners is increased threefold compared with one partner. Other HPV-related risk factors include high-risk sexual behavior, a history of STIs, a history of immunosuppression, and intrauterine exposure to diethylstilbestrol. Higher rates of cervical cancer have also been observed in women of low socioeconomic status and smokers (for squamous cell cancer types only).

images.title: Pathophysiology of the development of cervical cancer
images.description: Almost all cases of cervical cancer are caused by an infection of the transformation zone (rectangular box) with high-risk types of human papillomavirus (HPV).HPVs infect the stem cells of the basal cell epithelium. Cell proliferation and migration of virus-infected daughter cells into the suprabasal cell layer allow the infection to spread. At the beginning of the process, the DNA of the virus is episomal. As the disease progresses, the DNA is integrated into the cervical epithelium's DNA. A noninvasive precursor lesion, cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN), may develop from an HPV infection over months to years, which may ultimately progress to invasive carcinoma.In most cases, complete recovery will occur during the early stages of an HPV infection.

answers.explanation_why: Oral contraceptive use > 5 years is associated with an increased risk of cervical cancer, whereas intrauterine device use actually decreases the risk.

Obesity increases the risk of endometrial cancer, not cervical cancer. This is due to increased aromatase activity in the abundant adipose tissue, which leads to increased levels of circulating estrogens.

Nulliparity increases the risk of developing endometrial cancer, not cervical cancer because nulliparous women are not exposed to the significant increase in progesterone that occurs during pregnancy. In contrast, both high parity and early age of first birth (< 20 years old), increase the risk for cervical cancer, although these factors may be mediated by increased exposure to HPV.

Early menarche is not a known risk factor for developing cervical cancer, but it is associated with an increased incidence of endometrial cancer due to the increased lifetime exposure to estrogen (similarly to late menopause).
While a family history of gynecological cancers does increase this patient's risk of developing cervical cancer, it is not the strongest predisposing factor.

While PCOS is likely the cause of this woman's acne, it is not an established risk factor for the development of cervical cancer. It is, however, associated with an increased risk of endometrial cancer due to the excess circulating estrogen, a direct result of decreased production of sex hormone-binding globulin.

question_text: A 3-month-old male infant with HIV infection is brought to the physician for evaluation. The physician recommends monthly intramuscular injections of a monoclonal antibody to protect against infection caused by an enveloped virus with a helical capsid and negative-sense, single-stranded RNA. The causal pathogen for this infection is most likely transmitted by which of the following routes?
content_preview: A 3-month-old male infant with HIV infection is brought to the physician for evaluation. The physician recommends monthly intramuscular injections of a monoclonal antibody to protect against infection caused by an enveloped virus with a helical capsid and negative-sense, single-stranded RNA. The causal pathogen for this infection is most likely transmitted by which of the following routes?
hint: Palivizumab is an FDA-approved monoclonal antibody used for infection prophylaxis. Palivizumab prevents infection by a particular pneumovirus.
learning_objective: Recognize the use of palivizumab in immunocompromised infants, and recall the transmission route of RSV.

answers.explanation_why:
Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) is a pneumovirus that can cause bronchiolitis in infants. Pneumoviruses are enveloped viruses with a helical capsid and single-stranded, negative-sense, non-segmented, linear RNA. RSV is usually spread via droplet transmission or fomites (indirect contact transmission).

RSV prophylaxis with nirsevimab or palivizumab is recommended during RSV season in children ≤ 2 years of age at high risk of developing severe infection (e.g., those with chronic lung disease of prematurity).

The hepatitis C virus (HCV) is an enveloped RNA virus that can be transmitted by blood transfusion. However, HCV has an icosahedral capsid and positive sense RNA, and there is currently no FDA-approved monoclonal antibody to prevent HCV infection. The virus targeted by palivizumab is not blood-borne.

Rabies and Ebola fever are transmitted by inoculation of the virus into broken or damaged skin and caused by enveloped, single-stranded, negative-sense RNA viruses with a helical capsid. However, there is currently no FDA-approved monoclonal antibody to prevent either of these infections. The virus targeted by palivizumab is not transmitted via inoculation into the skin.

Human T-cell lymphotropic virus-1 (HTLV-1), which causes T-cell leukemia in patients with HIV infection, is an enveloped RNA virus that can be transmitted through breast milk. However, HTLV-1 has an icosahedral capsid and positive sense RNA, and there is currently no FDA-approved monoclonal antibody to prevent HTLV-1 infection. The virus targeted by palivizumab is not transmitted via breast milk.

Enveloped viruses are generally not transmitted via the fecal-oral route because these viruses are destroyed in the stomach's acidic environment. RNA viruses that are transmitted via the fecal-oral route include rotavirus, norovirus, poliovirus, coxsackievirus, echovirus, hepatitis A virus, and hepatitis E virus, which are all nonenveloped viruses with icosahedral capsids. Moreover, there is currently no FDA-approved monoclonal antibody to prevent infection by any of these nonenveloped RNA viruses.

question_text: A 22-year-old man dies of an overdose. Statistically, in the United States, overdose with which of the following substances is the most likely cause of death?
content_preview: A 22-year-old man dies of an overdose. Statistically, in the United States, overdose with which of the following substances is the most likely cause of death?
hint: Naloxone can quickly reverse an overdose of these agents.
learning_objective: Recall synthetic opioids as the most common causative agent for overdose-related death.

answers.explanation_why: The incidence of opioid overdose has increased dramatically over the last few decades. Overdose-related death is also far more common with opioids than with other drugs, such as cocaine, psychostimulants, and benzodiazepines. Illegally manufactured synthetic opioids (primarily fentanyl) cause more overdose-related deaths than prescription opioids (e.g., methadone) and heroin.
Methamphetamine and other psychostimulants that are used recreationally are the second most common cause of overdose-related deaths.

Deaths from heroin overdose have declined in recent years and have been surpassed by deaths due to prescription opioid overdose. Neither prescription opioids nor heroin is the leading cause of overdose-related deaths.
Deaths from cocaine overdose have been rising over the past 20 years, but this substance is currently only the third most common cause of overdose-related deaths.

Intentional or unintentional acetaminophen overdose is the leading cause of acute hepatic failure in the United States. However, the vast majority of overdose-related deaths are caused by other substances.

Recreational use of benzodiazepines is common. When taken in excess, these drugs cause CNS and respiratory depression. However, benzodiazepine overdose is life-threatening only when coingested with other respiratory or CNS depressants (e.g., alcohol, opioids). Overdose-related death from another substance is more likely.

question_text: A 54-year-old man comes to the physician for an annual health maintenance examination. He reports that he feels well. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 22 years and drinks three 12 oz bottles of beer each night. He works as an accountant and says he does not have time to exercise regularly. He is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 98 kg (216 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m^2. His blood pressure is 146/90 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. His serum cholesterol concentration is 252 mg/dL and hemoglobin A_1C is 6.9%. Which of the following preventative measures is likely to have the greatest impact on this patient's all-cause mortality risk?
content_preview: A 54-year-old man comes to the physician for an annual health maintenance examination. He reports that he feels well. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 22 years and drinks three 12 oz bottles of beer each night. He works as an accountant and says he does not have time to exercise regularly. He is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 98 kg (216 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. His blood pressure is 146/90 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. His serum cholesterol concentration is 252 mg/dL and hemoglobin A1C is 6.9%. Which of the following preventative measures is likely to have the greatest impact on this patient's all-cause mortality risk?
hint: This man has several modifiable risk factors that increase his mortality risk. Although he should be encouraged to make several important lifestyle changes, only one of the patient's risk factors is the single greatest preventable cause of death.
learning_objective: Choose the preventative measure with the greatest impact on reducing all-cause mortality risk in smokers.

answers.explanation_why: Increased physical activity provides a protective effect against cardiovascular and all-cause mortality with a dose-response relationship. However, the magnitude of this protection for all-cause mortality is less than the magnitude of protection from another behavioral modification that this patient could make.

Weight loss would be beneficial in this patient who meets the criteria for World Health Organization Class I obesity (BMI > 30 kg/m^2). However, for patients in this BMI category, the all-cause mortality benefits of weight loss are less than the magnitude of protection from another behavioral modification that this patient could make.

Lipid-lowering therapy, most commonly achieved with the use of statins, provides a protective effect against cardiovascular and all-cause mortality with a dose-response relationship. However, even with high-dose statin therapy, the all-cause mortality risk reduction is less than the magnitude of protection from another behavioral modification that this patient could make.

Antidiabetic medication would be helpful in this patient who meets diagnostic criteria for type 2 diabetes mellitus given his hemoglobin A_1C > 6.5%. Glycemic control can prevent some adverse events such as limb amputation or progression of diabetic nephropathy and diabetic retinopathy. However, there is little evidence to suggest that these interventions lead to a significant reduction of all-cause mortality.

Reduced alcohol intake will likely enhance this patient's overall health. His current alcohol intake is about 40 grams per day. Although the exact effect of reduced alcohol intake on all-cause mortality is subject to ongoing debate, most experts agree that if a benefit exists, it is small.

Blood pressure reduction can reduce the risk of all-cause mortality and cardiovascular disease in this patient. Tight blood pressure control (< 130/90 mm Hg) is the single most important intervention to reduce the risk of stroke. However, the magnitude of this protection for all-cause mortality is less than the magnitude of protection from another behavioral modification that this patient could make.

Smoking cessation will confer the greatest protection against all-cause mortality for this patient. Smoking is the single greatest preventable cause of death worldwide, regardless of age at quitting or the number of previous pack years. 

When in doubt, the most commonly tested risk factor on exam questions is cigarette smoking, and smoking cessation is the best way to improve overall health!

question_text: A 16-year-old boy comes to the emergency department because of painful urination and urethral discharge for 3 days. He has multiple sexual partners and only occasionally uses condoms. His vital signs are within normal limits. The result of nucleic acid amplification testing for Neisseria gonorrhoeae is positive. The patient requests that his parents not be informed of the diagnosis. Which of the following initial actions by the physician is most appropriate?
content_preview: A 16-year-old boy comes to the emergency department because of painful urination and urethral discharge for 3 days. He has multiple sexual partners and only occasionally uses condoms. His vital signs are within normal limits. The result of nucleic acid amplification testing for Neisseria gonorrhoeae is positive. The patient requests that his parents not be informed of the diagnosis. Which of the following initial actions by the physician is most appropriate?
hint: There are both medical guidelines and legal implications that should be considered in this case given that the patient is a minor (< 18 years old, in most states).
learning_objective: Recognize the treatment for gonorrhea and confidentiality rights for minors seeking sexual health services.

answers.content: Order urinary PCR testing in two weeks
answers.explanation_why: Nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) for gonorrhea (both from a urine sample or urethral swab) has high sensitivity (99%) and specificity (96%), and repeat testing is not indicated. A gonococcal culture or repeat NAAT can be obtained if treatment failure or recurrent infection is suspected.

answers.content: Perform urethral swab culture for antibiotic sensitivities
answers.explanation_why: Urethral swab cultures can be helpful to assess antibiotic susceptibility but are not recommended on a routine basis when Neisseria gonorrhoeae is suspected. A gonococcal culture can be obtained if nucleic acid amplification testing is unavailable or if treatment failure is suspected.

answers.content: Request parental consent prior to prescribing antibiotics
answers.explanation_why: Requesting parental consent for treatment is not appropriate at this time, as this patient has already requested that his parents not be informed of the diagnosis. In accordance with most states' minors' consent laws, minors may consent to sexually transmitted infection services without parental permission.

answers.content: Discuss results with patient's primary care physician
answers.explanation_why: Sharing confidential medical information among providers should only occur with the patient's consent or if the other provider is immediately involved in the patient's care. In this situation, there is no urgent reason to notify the patient's primary care physician. The physician is required to notify the public health office, as Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a notifiable disease.

The physician's priority should be to initiate treatment with antibiotics, which is usually done as an outpatient in uncomplicated gonorrhea. Intramuscular ceftriaxone is the first-line treatment, and oral doxycycline should be added if coinfection with Chlamydia trachomatis is present or has not been excluded. Although this patient is a minor, most states do not require parental consent when an adolescent is seeking care related to sexual health (e.g., contraception, pregnancy care, or sexually transmitted infections) or substance abuse. In addition, this should be reported to the local department of health, as gonorrhea is a notifiable disease.

question_text: A previously healthy 38-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation of several hours of severe, right-sided, colicky flank pain that radiates to the groin. He drinks 2–3 energy drinks daily. An x-ray of the abdomen shows a 4-mm radiopaque mass in the right ureter. Microscopic examination of the urine shows biconcave, dumbbell-shaped crystals. Which of the following is most likely to prevent future episodes of flank pain?
content_preview: A previously healthy 38-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation of several hours of severe, right-sided, colicky flank pain that radiates to the groin. He drinks 2–3 energy drinks daily. An x-ray of the abdomen shows a 4-mm radiopaque mass in the right ureter. Microscopic examination of the urine shows biconcave, dumbbell-shaped crystals. Which of the following is most likely to prevent future episodes of flank pain?
hint: The radiopaque mass in the area of the ureter and biconcave dumbbells on urinalysis confirm the diagnosis of calcium oxalate stones.
learning_objective: Recognize calcium oxalate nephrolithiasis, and choose the most effective step to prevent recurrence.

answers.explanation_why: Loop diuretics inhibit reabsorption of calcium in the loop of Henle, causing hypercalciuria, which promotes calcium stone formation. Thiazide diuretics, however, increase calcium reabsorption in the renal tubules and decrease urinary calcium levels, which prevents the formation of calcium stones.

Calcium oxalate crystallizes in an acidic environment and is soluble in an alkaline environment. In a patient with calcium oxalate stones, alkalinization of urine would prevent recurrent stone formation. This can be achieved with a diet rich in fruits and vegetables or potassium citrate. Urinary acidification is recommended for prevention of calcium phosphate or struvite stones.

Inadequate hydration causes supersaturation of solutes in urine, which increases the risk of stone formation. Fluid intake of ≥ 2.5 L/day reduces the risk of recurrent nephrolithiasis because it decreases the urinary solute concentration and increases the frequency of urination. Adequate hydration prevents recurrence of all types of urinary stones. This patient should also be advised against excessive consumption of energy drinks, which often contain oxalate and contribute to the formation of calcium oxalate stones.

Calcium oxalate stones can also appear as bipyramidal envelopes on urinalysis.

images.title: Calcium oxalate crystals in urine
images.description: Photomicrograph of a urine sample (urine sediment wet mount, intermediate magnification)Multiple envelope-shaped crystals can be seen (cf. illustration; examples indicated by yellow overlay) throughout the sample. These are composed of calcium oxalate dihydrate and have an octahedral structure.

answers.explanation_why: Vitamin C is metabolized to oxalate, which is then excreted in urine. High doses of supplemental vitamin C cause oxalate supersaturation in urine, which promotes the formation of calcium oxalate stones. Starting this patient on supplemental vitamin C is therefore not the best course of action.

Restricting normal dietary calcium intake (approx. 1000 mg/day) enhances the intestinal absorption of oxalate. This increases urinary oxalate excretion and the risk of recurrent calcium oxalate stones. In addition, prolonged low dietary calcium can decrease bone mineral density and cause osteoporosis. However, supplemental calcium intake (above the normal daily requirements) should be restricted in patients with calcium stones.

Although the association between caffeinated beverages and formation of renal stones is not entirely clear, increased (not decreased) caffeine consumption (either coffee or tea) decreases the recurrence rate of nephrolithiasis, most likely by improving urinary flow and decreasing urinary supersaturation. Coffee and tea also have antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties that potentially reduce the risk of stone formation.

question_text: An 82-year-old man with alcohol use disorder is brought to the emergency department from his assisted living facility because of fever and cough for 1 week. The cough is productive of thick, mucoid, blood-tinged sputum. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F) and respirations are 20/min. Physical examination shows coarse inspiratory crackles over the right lung field. Sputum cultures grow gram-negative, encapsulated bacilli that are resistant to amoxicillin, ceftriaxone, and aztreonam. Which of the following infection control measures is most appropriate for preventing transmission of this organism to other patients in the hospital?
content_preview: An 82-year-old man with alcohol use disorder is brought to the emergency department from his assisted living facility because of fever and cough for 1 week. The cough is productive of thick, mucoid, blood-tinged sputum. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F) and respirations are 20/min. Physical examination shows coarse inspiratory crackles over the right lung field. Sputum cultures grow gram-negative, encapsulated bacilli that are resistant to amoxicillin, ceftriaxone, and aztreonam. Which of the following infection control measures is most appropriate for preventing transmission of this organism to other patients in the hospital?
hint: Fever, productive cough, and localized crackles are suggestive of pneumonia. The patient's currant jelly sputum, residency in an assisted living facility, alcohol use disorder, and findings of gram-negative, encapsulated bacilli make healthcare-associated Klebsiella pneumonia a likely diagnosis. Sputum cultures show multi-drug resistance, raising suspicion for an extended-spectrum beta-lactamase-producing (ESBL) strain of this bacteria.
learning_objective: Recognize the need for single-occupancy room isolation for multidrug-resistant organisms.

answers.content: Require all staff and visitors to wear droplet masks
answers.explanation_why: Droplet precautions are used for highly contagious diseases that are transmitted through particles of respiratory secretions. These include Neisseria meningitidis, influenza, Bordetella pertussis, and others. ESBL-producing bacteria are not transmitted through droplets and therefore droplet precautions are not indicated in this patient.

answers.content: Transfer patient to a positive pressure room
answers.explanation_why: Positive pressure rooms can be used for immunocompromised patients. They have a ventilation system that creates positive pressure in the room, allowing air to flow out of and preventing air from being drawn into the room. This is not indicated in this patient as he is not immunocompromised, and it would not help reduce transmission of ESBL-producing bacteria.

answers.content: Require autoclave sterilization of all medical instruments
answers.explanation_why: Autoclave sterilization of all medical instruments is used in prion diseases, such as Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, as well as in spore-forming bacteria or fungi. It is not necessary to prevent transmission of ESBL-producing bacteria.

answers.content: Isolate patient to a single-occupancy room
answers.explanation_why: Multidrug-resistant strains of bacteria, such as ESBL-producing strains, are a greater public health hazard than infections with organisms of a normal resistance spectrum, and thus need stricter infection control measures. In addition to the standard contact precautions and strict hand hygiene, patients should be isolated in single-occupancy rooms.

answers.content: Transfer patient to a negative pressure room
answers.explanation_why: Negative pressure rooms are used for highly contagious airborne diseases (e.g., tuberculosis, measles, varicella, smallpox). They have a ventilation system that creates negative pressure in the room, allowing air to flow into and preventing air from flowing out of the room. Moving the patient to a negative pressure room is not necessary to prevent transmission of ESBL-producing bacteria.

question_text: A 65-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 10-month history of progressive shortness of breath and a cough productive of a small amount of white phlegm. Bilateral end-expiratory wheezing is heard on auscultation of the chest. Pulmonary function tests show total lung capacity that is 108% of predicted, an FEV_1 that is 56% of predicted, and an FEV_1:FVC ratio of 62%. Which of the following interventions is most likely to slow the decline in FEV_1 in individuals with this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 65-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 10-month history of progressive shortness of breath and a cough productive of a small amount of white phlegm. Bilateral end-expiratory wheezing is heard on auscultation of the chest. Pulmonary function tests show total lung capacity that is 108% of predicted, an FEV1 that is 56% of predicted, and an FEV1:FVC ratio of 62%. Which of the following interventions is most likely to slow the decline in FEV1 in individuals with this patient's condition?
hint: This patient's history of dyspnea and productive cough combined with a decreased FEV_1, decreased FEV_1:FVC ratio, and increased total lung capacity make chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) the most likely diagnosis.
learning_objective: Recognize chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, and choose the intervention most likely to slow the decline in lung function.

answers.explanation_why: COPD is a preventable lung disease characterized by airway obstruction due to inflammation of the small airways and is primarily caused by long-term smoking. Smoking cessation is the single most important measure to slow the decline in lung function at all stages of COPD. It has been shown that the earlier the cessation is achieved, the greater the benefit for lung function. Other measures that improve lung function of COPD patients include treatment with inhaled corticosteroids and bronchodilators.

Physiotherapy with breathing exercises as part of pulmonary rehabilitation is a supportive measure in the treatment of COPD patients. It has been shown to improve symptoms, exercise capacity, and quality of life. However, there is an intervention with a greater impact on the rate of decline in FEV_1..

Salmeterol is a long-acting beta agonist used as combination or monotherapy in patients with COPD. This drug has been shown to significantly decrease exacerbation rates and improve lung function. However, there is an intervention with a greater impact on the rate of decline in FEV_1..

Fluticasone is an inhaled corticosteroid used in combination with a long-acting bronchodilator in patients with severe COPD. Even though this combination therapy has been shown to improve lung function and exacerbations rates, fluticasone monotherapy seems to have little impact on the rate of decline in FEV_1..

Intravenous alpha-1 antitrypsin (AAT) replacement therapy is used in patients with COPD due to severe AAT deficiency, a genetic disorder presenting with liver disease as well as early-onset panacinar emphysema. However, severe AAT deficiency is rare and would usually manifest earlier in life with hepatic involvement (e.g., hepatitis, cirrhosis, hepatocellular carcinoma).

question_text: A 53-year-old woman with hypertension is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after having a generalized, tonic-clonic seizure. She has had recurrent headaches and dizziness in the last 3 months. One year ago, she had a diarrheal illness following a trip to Ecuador that resolved without treatment. She has not received any medical care in the last five years. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years. Her temperature is 36.0°C (96.8°F) and blood pressure is 159/77 mm Hg. Physical examination shows dysarthria and hyperreflexia. She is confused and oriented only to name and place. On a CT scan of the head with contrast, four brain lesions are seen; one of the lesions is shown. Which of the following would have been most likely to prevent this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 53-year-old woman with hypertension is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after having a generalized, tonic-clonic seizure. She has had recurrent headaches and dizziness in the last 3 months. One year ago, she had a diarrheal illness following a trip to Ecuador that resolved without treatment. She has not received any medical care in the last five years. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years. Her temperature is 36.0°C (96.8°F) and blood pressure is 159/77 mm Hg. Physical examination shows dysarthria and hyperreflexia. She is confused and oriented only to name and place. On a CT scan of the head with contrast, four brain lesions are seen; one of the lesions is shown. Which of the following would have been most likely to prevent this patient's condition?
hint: This patient's combination of seizure, headache, dizziness, dysarthria, hyperreflexia, confusion, recent travel to South America, and ring-enhancing brain cysts on head CT scan indicates a diagnosis of neurocysticercosis.
learning_objective: Recognize neurocysticercosis, and choose the primary preventive measure for this parasitic infection.

answers.explanation_why:
Avoidance of food contaminated by the eggs of Taenia solium reduces the risk of neurocysticercosis, which is the most common parasitic disease of the nervous system and the most important cause of adult-onset seizures in Asia, Africa, Central and South America. Neurocysticercosis is a fecal-oral transmitted disease that results from ingestion of eggs of Taenia solium, which can be found in food and water contaminated by the feces of people with intestinal taeniasis. Several strategies have been described to prevent the infection, which include washing food prior to consumption, proper hand hygiene, and avoidance of raw pork meat, as well as adequate freezing and cooking of food to destroy the parasite.

Neurocysticercosis is characterized by seizures, increased intracranial pressure, and focal neurologic deficits. Depending on the stage of disease, multiple ring-enhancing, cystic, and eventually calcified lesions can be seen on brain CT scan, some of which may show a scolex.

Vaccination against meningococcus is routinely recommended in adolescents 11–18 years old and high-risk groups to reduce the risk of infection with Neisseria meningitidis, a gram-negative diplococcus responsible for most of the cases of community-acquired meningitis in children and young adults. Although meningococcal meningitis can also cause neurological deficits as in this patient, other important signs such as neck stiffness and signs of infection (e.g., fever) are not present. In addition, meningococcal meningitis does not cause ring-enhancing lesions but instead presents with inflamed meninges on imaging. Therefore, vaccination would not have prevented this patient's condition.

Avoidance of cat feces reduces the risk of infection with Toxoplasma gondii, a ubiquitous intracellular parasite acquired by ingestion of oocytes from water, fruits, vegetables or contaminated meat. Cerebral toxoplasmosis can also cause neurological deficits and ring-enhancing lesions on brain CT scan. This diagnosis is very unlikely in an immunocompetent patient. Given the patient's gastrointestinal infection acquired in South America, another diagnosis is more likely. Therefore, avoidance of cat feces would not have prevented this patient's condition.
answers.explanation_but: Echinococcus spp. can also be transmitted by ingestion of eggs shed in feline feces. However, the clinical manifestations of echinococcosis are mostly gastrointestinal and pulmonary rather than neurologic.

answers.explanation_why: Smoking cessation is the best strategy to reduce the risk of lung cancer, which is the most common cause of brain metastases. In a patient with a history of smoking and symptoms of elevated intracranial pressure, ring-enhancing lesions are concerning for metastatic lung cancer. However, brain metastasis manifests with vasogenic edema, which is not seen here, and this patient's history of a diarrheal illness following a trip to Ecuador a year ago makes another diagnosis more likely. Therefore, smoking cessation would not have prevented this patient's condition.

Mammography screening is routinely performed in women 40–74 years old with an average risk of breast cancer, the most common malignant disease in postmenopausal women. Although breast cancer has a high risk of metastasizing, most patients have a previous diagnosis of primary disease and < 5% present with brain involvement. Additionally, brain metastasis on CT scan appears as multiple, well-circumscribed lesions at the gray-white matter junction, and not as ring-enhancing, cystic lesions like those observed in this patient. Therefore, breast cancer screening would not have prevented this patient's condition.

Improved blood pressure control minimizes the chances of stroke in patients with elevated cardiovascular risk. Although this patient presents with a history of untreated hypertension, her blood pressure at the time of evaluation is not high enough to produce acute end-organ damage. Additionally, the morphologic features of the lesions on brain CT scan are not characteristic of ischemic or hemorrhagic stroke. Therefore, improving blood pressure would not have prevented this patient's condition.

images.title: Ring-enhancing lesion in the brain
images.description: CT head (with contrast; axial plane) of a patient with neurocysticercosisA rounded peripheral lesion in the right temporoparietal region has a hypodense center (yellow overlay) and thickened enhancing wall (red overlay). There is perilesional low-attenuation edema (green overlay).These findings are typical of the colloidal-vesicular stage of neurocysticercosis.

question_text: A 47-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. He has no complaints and has no history of serious illness. He works as a forklift operator in a factory. His brother died of malignant melanoma. He smokes occasionally and drinks a glass of wine once a week. His pulse is 79/min and blood pressure is 129/84 mm Hg. Which of the following causes of death is this patient most at risk for over the next 15 years?
content_preview: A 47-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. He has no complaints and has no history of serious illness. He works as a forklift operator in a factory. His brother died of malignant melanoma. He smokes occasionally and drinks a glass of wine once a week. His pulse is 79/min and blood pressure is 129/84 mm Hg. Which of the following causes of death is this patient most at risk for over the next 15 years?
hint: What is the leading cause of death in men in the United States?
learning_objective: Recall the leading causes of death in men in the United States.

answers.explanation_why: Lung cancer is the second most common cancer among men as well as women and the leading cause of cancer deaths worldwide. Although this patient's occasional smoking slightly increases his risk of lung cancer-related death, his risk of death due to another cause is higher.

Coronary heart disease (CHD) is the leading cause of death in the US and worldwide, and the death rate is higher in men than in women. This patient's risk for coronary heart disease is higher than a non-smoker due to his occasional smoking. Overall, malignancy is the most common cause of death among patients 45–64 years of age. However, heart disease is a more common cause of death than any single type of cancer in the United States.

Malignant melanoma is a life-threatening dermatologic disease and the fifth most common cancer in men. While this patient's family history increases his risk of developing melanoma (around 10% of melanoma cases are familial), his risk of death due to another cause is higher.

Industrial accidents are the third most common cause of death in American men. Although this patient's occupation as a forklift operator increases his risk of accident-related injuries, his risk of death due to another cause is higher.

Prostate cancer is the most common cause of cancer in men in the US and the second most common cause of cancer-related death. Although the fact that this patient is male means he is at risk of developing prostate cancer, his risk of death due to another cause is higher.

Suicide or intentional self-harm is currently the tenth leading cause of death in the US. This patient does not express any suicidal intention and has no signs of depression; his risk of death due to another cause is higher.

question_text: A 29-year-old man with post-traumatic stress disorder is admitted to the hospital following an intentional opioid overdose. He is a soldier who returned from a deployment in Afghanistan 3 months ago. He is divorced and lives alone. His mother died by suicide when he was 8 years of age. He states that he intended to end his life as painlessly as possible and has also contemplated using his service firearm to end his life. He asks the physician if assisted suicide is legal in his state. He does not smoke or drink alcohol but uses medical marijuana daily. Mental status examination shows a depressed mood and constricted affect. Which of the following is the strongest risk factor for suicide in this patient?
content_preview: A 29-year-old man with post-traumatic stress disorder is admitted to the hospital following an intentional opioid overdose. He is a soldier who returned from a deployment in Afghanistan 3 months ago. He is divorced and lives alone. His mother died by suicide when he was 8 years of age. He states that he intended to end his life as painlessly as possible and has also contemplated using his service firearm to end his life. He asks the physician if assisted suicide is legal in his state. He does not smoke or drink alcohol but uses medical marijuana daily. Mental status examination shows a depressed mood and constricted affect. Which of the following is the strongest risk factor for suicide in this patient?
hint: Though all of the following increase the risk for suicide, one factor has been identified in several studies to be associated with a significantly higher risk compared to the others (up to 370-fold increased risk compared to the general population).
learning_objective: Recall the strongest risk factor for suicide.

answers.explanation_why: Though the rate of completed suicide is significantly higher among men compared to women, male sex is not the strongest risk factor for suicide. The difference in the rate of completed suicide appears to be related to the lethality of the method chosen (e.g., suicide by firearm compared to attempted suicide by overdose). The rate of suicide attempts is higher among women compared to men.
Post-traumatic stress disorder, like other mental health disorders, is a significant risk factor for suicide; however, it is not the strongest risk factor.
Family history of completed suicide is a significant risk factor for suicide; however, it is not the strongest risk factor.

Previously attempted suicide is the single strongest risk factor for suicide. A popular mnemonic for common risk factors for suicide is SADPERSONS: Sex (male), Age (> 45 years), Depression, Previous suicide attempt, Ethanol/substance use disorder, Rational thinking loss, Sickness (chronic disease), Organized plan (e.g., access to weapons), No spouse, Social support lacking.
Use of medical marijuana is not an established risk factor for suicide.

Lack of social support is a significant risk factor for suicide; however, it is not the strongest risk factor. The risk of suicide varies with marital status (e.g., single, separated, divorced, widowed) and other social factors, such as living alone, social isolation, and subjective feelings of loneliness.
Suicide is one of the most common causes of death among individuals between 15–34 years of age. However, young age is not the strongest risk factor for suicide.

The rate of suicide among military veterans is higher than that of the general population, though age- and gender-adjusted rates are comparable. The incidence of suicide among military veterans is increasing (particularly among younger men), but a history of military service is not the strongest risk factor for suicide.

question_text: A 27-year-old man comes to the physician 2 weeks after undergoing successful repair of a torn medial collateral ligament in his left knee. There were no complications. He was discharged with prescriptions for oxycodone and acetaminophen. He reports severe pain that prevents him from participating in physical therapy and wakes him from sleep. He has a history of illicit drug use. Physical examination of the left knee shows a healing incision; there is no joint effusion, erythema, or evidence of wound dehiscence, and his gait is normal. When the physician recommends switching to ibuprofen for pain, the patient becomes visibly angry and demands a refill of oxycodone. Which of the following is the most appropriate response to this patient's request?
content_preview: A 27-year-old man comes to the physician 2 weeks after undergoing successful repair of a torn medial collateral ligament in his left knee. There were no complications. He was discharged with prescriptions for oxycodone and acetaminophen. He reports severe pain that prevents him from participating in physical therapy and wakes him from sleep. He has a history of illicit drug use. Physical examination of the left knee shows a healing incision; there is no joint effusion, erythema, or evidence of wound dehiscence, and his gait is normal. When the physician recommends switching to ibuprofen for pain, the patient becomes visibly angry and demands a refill of oxycodone. Which of the following is the most appropriate response to this patient's request?
hint: This patient has appropriately been prescribed opioids for a limited postoperative time, but he complains of persisting severe pain. Together with a history of illicit drug use and the patient's emotional demand for an oxycodone refill, this is concerning for substance use disorder.
learning_objective: Recognize signs of potential substance use disorder, and choose the appropriate initial step in managing a patient's medication request.

answers.content: Prescribe a long-acting opioid for better pain relief if he is willing to sign a pain contract
answers.explanation_why: A pain contract aims to control opioid administration by ensuring that patients take opioids exactly as prescribed. Pain contracts may be indicated for patients undergoing narcotic therapy, especially for chronic pain. It is not clear from this patient's presentation whether he requires pain management with opioids. His behavior and presentation raise concern for substance use disorder, and prescribing a long-acting opioid may increase the risk of drug misuse. A different response is more appropriate at this time.

answers.content: Request further information about which drugs he has taken recently and in the past
answers.explanation_why:
This patient's behavior and history of illicit drug use raise suspicion for substance use disorder. It is the physician's responsibility to guard against misuse of prescription drugs while properly assessing and treating the patient's pain. To do so, they must avoid prejudice and cognitive bias. It is therefore appropriate in this case to request further information regarding the patient's drug use, to determine whether he has a history of substance use disorder and/or aberrant drug-related behaviors (e.g., actively receiving narcotic prescriptions from multiple physicians).

Online federal resources may be of use to determine if a patient has a history of opioid use disorder, or if the patient is actively receiving narcotic prescriptions from multiple physicians.

answers.content: Request consent for urine test to assess current drug use
answers.explanation_why: A urine test could be helpful in determining whether the patient is currently using illicit drugs. However, because the patient was recently prescribed opioids, the test would not be helpful for determining whether the patient has been using opioids recreationally. Moreover, requesting consent for a urine drug test would likely alienate this patient. A different response is more appropriate at this time.

answers.content: Prescribe a short course of oxycodone and schedule a follow-up appointment in one week
answers.explanation_why: A short-course prescription for oxycodone with follow up may be indicated for patients requiring management of severe pain. It is not clear from this patient's presentation whether he still requires pain management with opioids. His behavior and presentation raise concern for substance use disorder, and prescribing oxycodone may increase the risk of drug misuse. A different response is more appropriate at this time.

answers.content: Refer to a substance use counselor for addiction counseling
answers.explanation_why: A substance use counselor can be helpful in counseling individuals with substance use disorders. This patient's behavior and history of illicit drug use raise suspicion for substance use disorder, but it is too early to determine whether this is actually the case. Referring the patient to a substance use counselor at this point would not be appropriate and could result in a loss of rapport with the patient.

question_text:
A 46-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 10-day history of right upper quadrant abdominal pain. He has also been feeling tired and nauseous for the past 6 weeks. On examination, scleral icterus is present. Abdominal examination shows tenderness to palpation in the right upper quadrant. The liver edge is palpated 2 cm below the right costal margin. Laboratory studies show:

Aspartate aminotransferase
1780 U/L

Alanine aminotransferase
2520 U/L

Hepatitis A IgM antibody
negative

Hepatitis B surface antigen
negative

Hepatitis B surface antibody
negative

Hepatitis B core IgM antibody
positive

Hepatitis C antibody
positive

Hepatitis C RNA
negative

Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
content_preview: A 46-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 10-day history of right upper quadrant abdominal pain. He has also been feeling tired and nauseous for the past 6 weeks. On examination, scleral icterus is present. Abdominal examination shows tenderness to palpation in the right upper quadrant. The liver edge is palpated 2 cm below the right costal margin. Laboratory studies show: Aspartate aminotransferase 1780 U/L Alanine aminotransferase 2520 U/L Hepatitis A IgM antibody negative Hepatitis B surface antigen negative Hepatitis B surface antibody negative Hepatitis B core IgM antibody positive Hepatitis C antibody positive Hepatitis C RNA negative Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
hint: Sudden onset of nausea, jaundice, fever, and right upper quadrant pain with massively elevated serum transaminase levels (> 1000 U/L) suggests a diagnosis of acute viral hepatitis. The presence of anti-HBc IgM antibodies without concurrent HBsAg or anti-HBs antibodies indicates that this patient is in the window period of acute hepatitis B infection.
learning_objective: Recognize acute viral hepatitis B in the window period, and choose the most appropriate treatment.

answers.explanation_why: A combination of ribavirin and interferon can be used to treat chronic hepatitis C caused by genotypes 2 and 3. A patient with a chronic hepatitis C infection will have increased levels of antibodies against HCV and possibly elevated serum transaminase levels. However, the serum transaminase levels would only be mildly to moderately increased (< 500 U/L) and HCV RNA would be detectable. The absence of HCV RNA most likely indicates a past hepatitis C infection that has resolved.

Supportive therapy is all that is required for a patient with acute hepatitis B infection. A negative HBsAg with positive anti-HBc IgM antibodies indicate that the infection is resolving. Anti-HBs antibody titers may not increase for up to 1–2 weeks following the disappearance of HbsAg from serum (window period), which is why measuring anti-HBc antibody titers in patients with suspected acute hepatitis B infection is important.

The presence of HBsAg on serology denotes an acute hepatitis B infection. While anti-HBc is the first antibody to be made, it does not offer immune clearance of hepatitis B. However, anti-HBc may be the only marker of infection during the seroconversion of HBsAg to anti-HBs (i.e., during the window period). During this time, all HBsAgs and anti-HBs are in antigen-antibody complexes, so they cannot be detected in the serum. Immune clearance is established when additional unbound anti-HBs becomes detectable on serology.

images.title: Serology time course of acute and resolved hepatitis B infection
images.description: Schematic depiction of the time frames in which HBV DNA, antigens, and antibodies are measurable (and transaminases elevated) during acute HBV infection and resolution. Note that the timing can vary significantly between patients and that the pattern in chronic infection differs.The window period is an interval in which HBsAg is no longer measurable, anti-HBs is not yet measurable, and only Anti-HBc and Anti-HBe can be detected.HBV DNA: hepatitis B virus DNA; HBsAg: hepatitis B surface antigen; HBeAg: hepatitis B e antigen; Anti-HBc IgM: anti-hepatitis B core antigen IgM antibody; Anti-HBc total: anti-HBc IgM + anti-HBc IgG (conventionally measured together); Anti-HBs: anti-hepatitis B surface antigen antibody; Anti-HBe: anti-hepatitis Be antigen antibody

answers.explanation_why: A combination of ledipasvir and sofosbuvir can be used to treat chronic hepatitis C infection caused by genotypes 1, 4, 5, and 6 of HCV. A patient with chronic hepatitis C infection will have increased levels of antibodies against HCV and may have elevated serum transaminase levels. However, the serum transaminase levels would only be mildly or moderately increased (< 500 U/L), and HCV RNA would be detectable. The absence of HCV RNA most likely indicates a past hepatitis C infection that has resolved.

Tenofovir is used to treat immune-active chronic hepatitis B (CHB). A patient with immune-active CHB would have elevated serum transaminase levels and negative anti-HBs antibodies. However, in CHB, anti-HBc IgG antibodies would be expected instead of anti-HBc IgM antibodies, HbsAg would be present, and the serum transaminase levels would only be mildly or moderately increased (< 500 U/L).

In a patient with acute viral hepatitis, emergency liver transplantation is indicated if acute liver failure occurs. While acute liver failure manifests with elevated transaminases, features of hepatic encephalopathy (e.g., altered mental status, asterixis) and coagulopathy are also expected, neither of which is seen in this patient.

question_text: A 49-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. He feels well and has no history of serious illness. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 25 years and drinks two to three glasses of wine weekly. This patient should be counseled about increased risk for which of the following conditions?
content_preview: A 49-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. He feels well and has no history of serious illness. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 25 years and drinks two to three glasses of wine weekly. This patient should be counseled about increased risk for which of the following conditions?
hint: Other risk factors for this condition include diabetes mellitus and obesity.
learning_objective: Recognize the increased risk for specific conditions associated with long-term tobacco smoking.

answers.explanation_why: Tobacco smoking accounts for ∼ 25% of pancreatic cancers and is associated with up to 6-fold increased risk of developing a malignancy, especially in individuals with a long history of smoking, as this patient. Moreover, disease onset has been found to be at a younger age in smokers compared to nonsmokers. The underlying mechanism of this is not well understood. Further risk factors for pancreatic cancer include chronic pancreatitis (esp. > 20 years), age > 50 years, and hereditary genetic syndromes.

Extensive alcohol consumption is a major risk factor for chronic liver diseases, including hepatic steatosis. Extensive alcohol consumption is defined as consuming more than 210 g of pure alcohol (∼ 15 glasses of wine) per week in men and more than 140 g (∼ 10 glasses of wine) per week in women. However, this patient consumes 3 glasses of wine per week, which is not considered a significant risk factor for developing alcohol-induced hepatic steatosis.

Gastric MALT lymphoma is associated with Helicobacter pylori infection in up to 90% of cases. Since this patient lacks any of the clinical features of H. pylori infection (e.g., epigastric pain, nausea, vomiting), he is not expected to be at increased risk for this malignancy.

Genetic predisposition (e.g., HLA-B27 association) is a major risk factor for ulcerative colitis (UC). However, this patient does not report a family history of inflammatory bowel disease. Moreover, current tobacco smoking, as seen in this patient, may decrease the risk of UC and have a positive effect on the course of the disease. This mechanism is not fully understood but is thought to be due to the ability of nicotine to stimulate the synthesis of cortisol, decrease the permeability of bowel walls, and reduce the blood flow in the rectum.

Esophageal varices can develop due to portal hypertension, which is typically seen in patients with liver cirrhosis and a history of extensive alcohol use. Extensive alcohol consumption is defined as consuming more than ≥ 3 drinks per day or ≥ 21 per week in men and more than ≥ 2 drinks per day or ≥ 14 per week in women. This patient, however, consumes three glasses of wine per week, which is not considered a significant risk factor for developing esophageal varices due to alcohol-associated liver disease.

Porcelain gallbladder is a complication of chronic gallbladder inflammation (e.g., chronic cholecystitis). This patient, however, lacks a history of cholecystitis and thus is not expected to be at increased risk for porcelain gallbladder.

question_text: A 35-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife because of a 1-week history of progressive confusion, myalgia, and nausea. His wife says that he first reported headaches and fatigue 10 days ago, and since then “he has not been himself”. He has refused to drink any liquids for the last day. Two months ago, he helped his neighbor remove a raccoon's den from her backyard. He appears agitated. His temperature is 100.8°F (38.2°C). Examination shows excessive drooling. Muscle tone and deep tendon reflexes are increased bilaterally. Administration of which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 35-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife because of a 1-week history of progressive confusion, myalgia, and nausea. His wife says that he first reported headaches and fatigue 10 days ago, and since then “he has not been himself”. He has refused to drink any liquids for the last day. Two months ago, he helped his neighbor remove a raccoon's den from her backyard. He appears agitated. His temperature is 100.8°F (38.2°C). Examination shows excessive drooling. Muscle tone and deep tendon reflexes are increased bilaterally. Administration of which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's condition?
hint: The patient has had flulike illness followed by agitation, confusion, hydrophobia, hypersalivation, and increased muscle tone and reflexes 2 months following exposure to raccoons. These symptoms are highly suggestive of rabies infection due to a bite by a raccoon, which are a major animal reservoir of rabies.
learning_objective: Recognize rabies infection, and recall the appropriate postexposure prophylaxis.

answers.explanation_why: NRTIs and NNRTIs are RNA-dependent DNA polymerase inhibitors and are used in antiretroviral HIV therapy. An acute HIV infection can manifest with fever, headache, and fatigue, as seen in this patient. However, hydrophobia, hypersalivation, and increased muscle tone and reflexes are not associated with HIV. RNA-dependent DNA polymerase inhibitors are not effective against rabies virus.

Administration of a chemically-inactivated virus (i.e., killed vaccine) along with rabies immunoglobulin is recommended as postexposure prophylaxis for patients exposed to suspected rabies. The immunoglobulin provides immediate protection by binding to the rabies virus and neutralizing it (i.e., passive immunity). However, protection is only temporary, since antibodies degrade over time. Simultaneous administration of the rabies vaccine stimulates the body's immune system, which reacts by producing antibodies (i.e., active immunity). Preventive active immunization with rabies vaccine is indicated for people with frequent occupational contact with potentially rabid animals and travelers to regions in which rabies is widespread.

Treatment with postexposure prophylaxis in suspected cases of a rabid animal bite should take place immediately, as the disease is fatal once it has become symptomatic. At this patient's stage of the disease, only palliative treatment is available.
Immunization with live attenuated vaccine usually provides lifelong protection against a virus or bacterium (e.g., MMR vaccine). However, there is no live vaccine available against rabies virus.

Administration of immunoglobulins is an integral part of rabies postexposure prophylaxis; immunoglobulins provide immediate protection by binding to the rabies virus and thereby neutralizing it. However, rabies is a virus that belongs to the Rhabdoviridae. Therefore, an immunoglobulin against a bacterial protein would not be effective.

Corticosteroids are NF-κB inhibitors that are usually administered for a variety of autoimmune conditions, as well as to prevent complications due to scarring after community-acquired bacterial meningitis. However, the clinical presentation of this patient is consistent with encephalitic rabies, which is not treated with corticosteroids, as they cannot halt the neurological damage caused by the rabies virus.

Ribavirin, an inosine monophosphate dehydrogenase inhibitor, is used for the treatment of hepatitis C and RSV infection. None of these conditions is consistent with this patient's clinical presentation, which is suggestive of encephalitic rabies. There is no available antiviral therapy that stops the replication of rabies virus.

question_text: Two months after giving birth to a boy, a 27-year-old woman comes to the physician with her infant for a well-child examination. She was not seen by a physician during her pregnancy. Physical examination of the mother and the boy shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show elevated titers of hepatitis B surface antigen in both the mother and the boy. Which of the following statements regarding the infant's condition is most accurate?
content_preview: Two months after giving birth to a boy, a 27-year-old woman comes to the physician with her infant for a well-child examination. She was not seen by a physician during her pregnancy. Physical examination of the mother and the boy shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show elevated titers of hepatitis B surface antigen in both the mother and the boy. Which of the following statements regarding the infant's condition is most accurate?
hint: Elevated titers of HbsAg in both the mother and the infant suggest vertical transmission of the hepatitis B virus (HBV).
learning_objective: Recognize vertical transmission of hepatitis B, and recall the expected transaminase levels in the infant.

answers.content: Hepatitis B e antigen titer is likely undetectable
answers.explanation_why: Hepatitis B e antigen (HBeAg) titer is readily detectable in neonates with HBV. This is consistent with the high transmission rates seen in the perinatal period. The risk of transmission is 80% to 90% from women seropositive for hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) and HBeAg. Mothers without the e antigen or with anti-HBe transmit the infection only in 5% to 20 % of cases.
Without treatment, chronic course of infection is very common in neonatal hepatitis from vertical transmission. Up to 90% of infants infected perinatally will develop chronic infection.

answers.content: Lifetime risk of hepatocellular carcinoma is low
answers.explanation_why: The risk of hepatocellular carcinoma is significant in neonatal hepatitis. Perinatal infection with HBV carries an approximately 90 % chance of the infant becoming a chronic carrier, with an estimated 15 % to 25 % risk of dying in adulthood from cirrhosis or liver cancer.

answers.content: The viral replication rate is low
answers.explanation_why: HBV replicates rapidly upon entering the newborn because of the inability of the infantile immune system to mount a HBV-specific immune response. Therefore, the viral replication rate would be expected to be high, not low.

answers.content: Significant elevation of transaminases is not expected
answers.explanation_why:
Transaminases are usually normal or only mildly elevated in cases of vertical transmission of HBV. Because HBV is not cytopathic itself and newborns lack mature cytotoxic T-cells that mediate damage to infected hepatocytes, the degree of hepatic tissue damage will be limited. Rarely, infected neonates may develop acute hepatitis B.

Newborns of mothers with unknown HBV status should receive vaccine within 12 hours of birth. If the mother tests positive for HBsAg, hepatitis B immune globulin should be administered as soon as possible. Newborns of HBsAg negative mothers should be given the hepatitis B vaccine series before hospital discharge.

Breastfeeding should be recommended to all patients with maternal HBV, as HBV infection is not a contraindication to breastfeeding. Women with HBV infection should be counseled that breastfeeding does not increase the likelihood of infection in their children. However, breastfeeding should be delayed until passive‑active postexposure prophylaxis has been given. Since, in this patient, vertical transmission of HBV has already occurred, there is no reason to delay breastfeeding.

question_text: A 28-year-old primigravid woman at 31 weeks' gestation comes to the physician because of fever, myalgia, abdominal pain, nausea, and diarrhea for 3 days. Her pregnancy has been uncomplicated. Her only medication is a prenatal vitamin. Her temperature is 39.4°C (102.9°F). Physical examination shows diffuse abdominal pain. Blood cultures incubated at 4°C (39.2°F) grow a gram-positive, catalase-positive organism. The pathogen responsible for this patient's presentation was most likely transmitted via which of the following modes?
content_preview: A 28-year-old primigravid woman at 31 weeks' gestation comes to the physician because of fever, myalgia, abdominal pain, nausea, and diarrhea for 3 days. Her pregnancy has been uncomplicated. Her only medication is a prenatal vitamin. Her temperature is 39.4°C (102.9°F). Physical examination shows diffuse abdominal pain. Blood cultures incubated at 4°C (39.2°F) grow a gram-positive, catalase-positive organism. The pathogen responsible for this patient's presentation was most likely transmitted via which of the following modes?
hint: The causal organism of this patient's condition was able to grow at refrigeration temperatures, which suggests infection with Listeria monocytogenes, a gram-positive, catalase-positive rod.
learning_objective: Recognize listeriosis in pregnancy, and recall its transmission through contaminated food.

answers.explanation_why: Blood transfusion is not a mode of transmission for L. monocytogenes. Hepatitis B and C, HIV, and Zika virus can be transmitted through contaminated blood.

Although sexual contact is a rare transmission mode of L. monocytogenes, another mode is much more likely. Sexually transmitted infections include chlamydia, hepatitis B, and gonorrhea, among others, none of which are gram-positive, catalase-positive organisms.

This clinical vignette is most consistent with listeriosis. L. monocytogenes is a gram-positive, catalase-positive organism that grows at refrigeration temperatures (4°C). Deli meats, poultry, and unpasteurized milk (often used for soft cheeses) are common sources. Listeriosis typically manifests with fever, malaise, abdominal pain, and diarrhea, most commonly in the third trimester. It is associated with higher rates of miscarriage, stillbirth, and preterm birth. Congenital listeriosis occurs via transplacental transmission, while neonatal listeriosis occurs following either transplacental infection or inoculation at birth from contaminated vaginal secretions. Symptoms vary based on the route and timing of infection, ranging from minor, self-limiting illness to sepsis and death.

Ingestion of cat feces is especially associated with the transmission of Toxoplasma gondii, which is a parasite and not a gram-positive organism as seen in this patient. Toxoplasmosis is usually asymptomatic, including in pregnant patients. Congenital toxoplasmosis can, however, lead to serious complications for the fetus and newborn.

Drinking contaminated water is a mode of transmission for multiple illnesses (e.g., cholera, legionellosis, typhoid fever) and although L. monocytogenes may be transmitted via this route, another source is much more likely.

Droplet transmission is a common mode of many infections, but not a mode by which listeriosis is spread. Varicella is a viral infection spread by droplets that is especially clinically relevant during pregnancy. A varicella blood culture would, however, not show the gram-positive organisms seen in this patient.

question_text:
A 28-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 32 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a prenatal visit. She has had no prenatal care. She emigrated from China 5 years ago and cannot recall all of her vaccinations. She appears well. Physical examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 32-week gestation. Serum studies show:

Anti-HAV IgM
negative

Anti-HAV IgG
positive

HBsAg
negative

Anti-HBs
positive

Anti-HBc IgM
negative

Anti-HBc IgG
negative

Which of the following is the most appropriate initial action by the physician?
content_preview: A 28-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 32 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a prenatal visit. She has had no prenatal care. She emigrated from China 5 years ago and cannot recall all of her vaccinations. She appears well. Physical examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 32-week gestation. Serum studies show: Anti-HAV IgM negative Anti-HAV IgG positive HBsAg negative Anti-HBs positive Anti-HBc IgM negative Anti-HBc IgG negative Which of the following is the most appropriate initial action by the physician?
hint: Anti-HBs antibodies usually appear within 3 months of infection or vaccination.
learning_objective: Recognize evidence of successful hepatitis B vaccination, and choose the appropriate delivery plan for the patient.

answers.explanation_why: This patient can proceed with vaginal delivery of her baby because her serum studies show successful vaccination against hepatitis B virus (positive anti-HBs, negative anti-HBc IgM and IgG, and negative HBsAg results). Her positive anti-HAV IgG and negative anti-HAV IgM results indicate a history of either HAV vaccination or infection. Even if the patient had active HAV or HBV, spontaneous vaginal delivery rather than cesarean delivery would be recommended.

answers.content: Determine the hepatitis B e antigen serum level
answers.explanation_why: Determining HBeAg serum levels can be helpful for assessing the risk of vertical transmission during birth. Newborns of birthing parents who are seropositive for HBsAg and HBeAg are at a 70–90% risk of HBV transmission during delivery. Determining HBeAg serum level in this patient is not necessary because her laboratory studies indicate successful immunization for HBV.

answers.content: Plan to give hepatitis B immunoglobulin to the newborn
answers.explanation_why: The HBV vaccine is part of the routine vaccine regimen and is recommended for all individuals at birth. However, hepatitis B immunoglobulin (HBIG) is only indicated for newborns of birthing parents who are HBsAg-positive (i.e., those with an active hepatitis B infection). This patient is HBsAg-negative, so administering HBIG to her newborn is unnecessary.

answers.content: Administer hepatitis B vaccine to the mother
answers.explanation_why: Administering the HBV vaccine is not necessary in this patient because she is already immune, as indicated by her positive anti-HBs, negative HBsAg, and negative anti-HBc IgM and IgG. HBV vaccination is recommended during pregnancy to all individuals without immunity (i.e., those with negative anti-HBs) to protect the birthing parent and reduce the risk of future transmission.

answers.content: Advise the patient to avoid breastfeeding
answers.explanation_why: Breastfeeding is not contraindicated and should be recommended to all patients with an HBV infection. However, as a precaution, if the patient has cracked or bleeding nipples, breastfeeding from the affected side should be avoided until the skin has healed. All newborns of patients with HBV infection must receive immunoprophylaxis with hepatitis B immunoglobulin and the HBV vaccine. This patient's serum studies show successful immunization to HBV.

question_text: A 3255-g (7-lb) female newborn is delivered at term. Pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. On the day of her birth, she is given a nonconjugated routine childhood vaccine that contains a noninfectious glycoprotein. This vaccine will most likely help prevent infection by which of the following pathogens?
content_preview: A 3255-g (7-lb) female newborn is delivered at term. Pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. On the day of her birth, she is given a nonconjugated routine childhood vaccine that contains a noninfectious glycoprotein. This vaccine will most likely help prevent infection by which of the following pathogens?
hint: The antigen in this vaccine protects against two pathogens simultaneously.
learning_objective: Recall the prevention of hepatitis D virus infection through hepatitis B vaccination.

answers.explanation_why: The Haemophilus influenzae type b vaccine contains a capsular polysaccharide conjugated to an immunogenic protein (conjugate vaccine). The Hib vaccine is generally administered at 2, 4, and 6 months after birth; it is not administered on the first day of life.
The inactivated poliovirus vaccine, which contains noninfectious virions, is given at 2, 4, and 6 months after birth. It is not administered on the first day of life.

The acellular pertussis vaccine is part of the DTaP vaccine, which is composed of the Corynebacterium diphtheriae toxoid, Clostridium tetani toxoid, and subunits (e.g., toxoid, adhesins) of Bordetella pertussis. Children receive the DTaP series at the age of 2, 4, and 6 months, with boosters at the age of 15-18 months and 4–6 years. The DTaP vaccine would not be administered at birth.

The rotavirus vaccine, which is a live attenuated vaccine, contains virions that are able to replicate within the host's body, not a noninfectious glycoprotein. Moreover, the rotavirus vaccine is administered at 2, 4, and 6 months after birth; it is not administered on the first day of life.

Infection by hepatitis D virus (HDV) can be prevented by hepatitis B vaccination. On its own, HDV is “defective” and unable to cause disease. HDV requires the hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) for replication (viral complementation). HBsAg, a noninfectious glycoprotein, is the antigen used to make the hepatitis B vaccine. Hepatitis B is spread through sexual activity, via needle sharing, or at birth from the mother to child.

The Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) currently recommends that all infants should receive the hepatitis B vaccination within 24 hours of birth, and subsequently at 1–2 months and 6–18 months of age.

question_text: A 42-year-old woman comes to the physician because of an episode of coughing with bloody sputum. Over the past 5 months, she has had a persistent nonproductive cough, excessive fatigue, and a 5.6-kg (12.3-lb) weight loss. She does not smoke. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. An x-ray of the chest shows a 2.0-cm nodule with irregular borders at the upper lobe of the left lung. A CT-guided biopsy of the lung nodule is performed. Pathologic examination of the biopsy specimen is most likely to show which of the following?
content_preview: A 42-year-old woman comes to the physician because of an episode of coughing with bloody sputum. Over the past 5 months, she has had a persistent nonproductive cough, excessive fatigue, and a 5.6-kg (12.3-lb) weight loss. She does not smoke. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. An x-ray of the chest shows a 2.0-cm nodule with irregular borders at the upper lobe of the left lung. A CT-guided biopsy of the lung nodule is performed. Pathologic examination of the biopsy specimen is most likely to show which of the following?
hint: This lung cancer subtype is the most common type of pulmonary malignancy overall.
learning_objective: Recognize adenocarcinoma of the lung.

answers.explanation_why: Small cell lung carcinoma is common, accounting for approximately 15% of all lung cancers. However, small cell lung carcinoma typically occurs in the central airways and is seen as a hilar mass on chest x-ray, unlike the peripheral mass that is seen here. In addition, this type of carcinoma is extremely rare in patients who have never smoked.

images.title: Small cell lung carcinoma
images.description: Photomicrograph of lung tissue (H&E stain; high magnification)There are sheets of small, dark blue, cells with hyperchromic, pleomorphic nuclei, and minimal cytoplasm (enterochromaffin cells).These findings are consistent with small cell lung carcinoma.Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

answers.explanation_why: Large cell lung carcinoma is usually found in the periphery, as in this case. However, large cell lung carcinoma only accounts for approximately 5–10% of all lung cancers and is therefore not the most likely diagnosis.
Bronchial carcinoid tumors are rare, accounting for 1–2% of all lung cancers. In addition, these tumors typically occur in the central airways, not in the periphery as seen in this patient.

Squamous cell lung carcinoma is common, accounting for approximately 20–25% of all lung cancers. While this type of carcinoma is the most common lung cancer among smokers, only 5% of such cases occur in those who have never smoked. In addition, squamous cell lung carcinoma typically occurs in the central airways and is seen as a hilar mass on chest x-ray, unlike the peripheral lesion that is seen in this patient.

images.title: Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung
images.description: Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

answers.explanation_why: Adenocarcinoma is the most common type of lung cancer and accounts for approximately 40% of all cases. Additionally, as in this patient, adenocarcinoma is more common in women, is usually found in the periphery, and is the most common lung cancer among those who have never smoked.

images.title: Adenocarcinoma of the lung
images.description: Photomicrograph of a lung tissue sample (H&E stain; 400x magnification)Several confluent tubular glands lined by atypical epithelium (examples indicated by green outline) and surrounded by desmoplastic hypercellular stroma are visible. There is nuclear stratification (nuclei located at different heights within the epithelium rather than basally only), nuclear hyperchromasia (darker stained nuclei), and pleomorphism (different sizes of cells and nuclei).These are typical findings in acinar adenocarcinoma of the lung.
