question_text: A 37-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, at 37 weeks' gestation, is scheduled for elective cesarean section. The night before the procedure, she informs the night shift resident physician that she would like to undergo a postpartum tubal ligation. The night shift resident physician obtains informed consent for the procedure and adds the patient's request to the patient's electronic chart. The next morning, the night shift resident, who has been at the hospital for 22 hours, forgets to update the gynecologic resident covering the day shift with this information. The surgical nurse only recently started working at the hospital. The surgical team does not review the added note in the patient's chart before the procedure. Cesarean delivery is carried out by the gynecologic resident along with an attending physician without complications, but the postpartum tubal ligation is not performed. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the error?
content_preview: A 37-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, at 37 weeks' gestation, is scheduled for elective cesarean section. The night before the procedure, she informs the night shift resident physician that she would like to undergo a postpartum tubal ligation. The night shift resident physician obtains informed consent for the procedure and adds the patient's request to the patient's electronic chart. The next morning, the night shift resident, who has been at the hospital for 22 hours, forgets to update the gynecologic resident covering the day shift with this information. The surgical nurse only recently started working at the hospital. The surgical team does not review the added note in the patient's chart before the procedure. Cesarean delivery is carried out by the gynecologic resident along with an attending physician without complications, but the postpartum tubal ligation is not performed. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the error?
hint: The additional clinical information regarding postpartum tubal ligation was not passed on to all health care personnel involved.
learning_objective: Recognize the role of effective communication in preventing medical errors.

answers.explanation_why: Improper documentation (e.g., incomplete entry of clinically relevant information, use of nonstandardized abbreviations) can cause medical errors. Because the night shift resident physician added the patient's request to the electronic chart, improper documentation does not seem to be the cause of error here.

Inadequate patient assessment is a possible source of medical errors (e.g., misdiagnosis or inappropriate treatment), especially among physicians who are still in training, such as the resident physician here. Medical assessment usually consists of a focused medical history, a careful physical examination, and appropriate diagnostic studies and aims to establish an accurate diagnosis and a personalized treatment plan. There is no evidence of misassessment or inappropriate indication for the surgical procedure; instead, the error is more likely related to the execution of the planned procedure.
Alert fatigue is the desensitization of health care providers to alarms as a result of repeated exposure to false and/or nonactionable alarms. There is no evidence of alert fatigue in this scenario.

Poor communication is a common cause of medical error and typically encompasses issues such as failure to review medical records, communication failures among medical personnel, inadequate communication with the patient or patient's family, and lack of standardized terminology or the use of jargon. In this case, the surgical team failed to review the patient’s medical record, which contained the note about postpartum tubal ligation. Moreover, the resident physician covering the night shift failed to communicate the additional intervention to the gynecologic resident. Measures to prevent communication-related errors include the implementation of standardized handoffs, the use of standardized medical terminology and abbreviations in documentation, signouts, read-backs, timeouts, a safety culture, flat authority gradients, and teamwork training.

Inexperienced health care personnel is a risk factor for nescient errors. Although the surgical nurse only recently started working at the hospital, preprocedural verification of the patient’s chart, including the planned surgical procedure, involves the entire surgical team. There is no evidence that the error was directly related to a lack of experience in the surgical team. Instead, the error was likely due to the absence of a standardized handoff.

question_text: A 68-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital because of a 1-week history of worsening shortness of breath. She has hypertension treated with lisinopril. Crackles are heard at both lower lung fields. She is diagnosed with acute congestive heart failure. When the physician responsible for the patient's care enters intravenous furosemide in the patient's orders, a clinical decision support system message appears on the computer saying that furosemide in combination with lisinopril may result in significant hypotension and decreased kidney function. The message also has a recommendation for dose adjustment and more frequent monitoring of vital signs and electrolytes when the patient is on both medications. The physician does not follow the recommendation and dismisses the message as one of the many inconsequential warnings that he encounters during his work. Two days after admission, the patient develops dizziness, severe hypotension, and chest pain. She is transferred to the cardiac intensive care unit and diagnosed with type 2 myocardial infarction secondary to hypotension. It is determined that a medication error occurred and personnel interviews are performed as part of a root cause analysis. These interviews reveal that the physician responsible for the patient's care has to take care of several complicated cases during the course of his shift and he has a high level of engagement with patients and a strong sense of personal accomplishment from his work. A fishbone diagram is most likely to reveal which of the following as the root cause of the error that occurred in this scenario?
content_preview: A 68-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital because of a 1-week history of worsening shortness of breath. She has hypertension treated with lisinopril. Crackles are heard at both lower lung fields. She is diagnosed with acute congestive heart failure. When the physician responsible for the patient's care enters intravenous furosemide in the patient's orders, a clinical decision support system message appears on the computer saying that furosemide in combination with lisinopril may result in significant hypotension and decreased kidney function. The message also has a recommendation for dose adjustment and more frequent monitoring of vital signs and electrolytes when the patient is on both medications. The physician does not follow the recommendation and dismisses the message as one of the many inconsequential warnings that he encounters during his work. Two days after admission, the patient develops dizziness, severe hypotension, and chest pain. She is transferred to the cardiac intensive care unit and diagnosed with type 2 myocardial infarction secondary to hypotension. It is determined that a medication error occurred and personnel interviews are performed as part of a root cause analysis. These interviews reveal that the physician responsible for the patient's care has to take care of several complicated cases during the course of his shift and he has a high level of engagement with patients and a strong sense of personal accomplishment from his work. A fishbone diagram is most likely to reveal which of the following as the root cause of the error that occurred in this scenario?
hint: Measures designed to improve patient safety can sometimes unintentionally result in medical errors.
learning_objective: Recognize the concept of alert fatigue as a cause of medical errors.

answers.explanation_why: An adverse drug reaction is an unintended and unpreventable drug event that occurs even though medication is administered appropriately. This patient, however, experienced a preventable drug interaction as a result of a medical error.

Physician burnout is a reaction to occupational stressors, and it can cause medical errors. Symptoms include detachment, emotional exhaustion, and a decreased sense of accomplishment at work. Contrastingly, the interviews conducted as part of the root cause analysis revealed that the physician has a high level of engagement with patients and a strong sense of personal accomplishment from his work.

Latent conditions (or latent errors) are usually caused by system design or organizational issues, which is not the case in this scenario. Moreover, in this case, the medical error seems to be an active error because it is the result of direct contact between the physician and an aspect of the system, with an immediate impact on the patient.

Alert fatigue is the phenomenon of clinician desensitization to alarms. Although computerized alerts were created to improve patient safety, the high number of alarms encountered has led healthcare personnel to become desensitized to such warnings. This desensitization is worsened by the high proportion of alarms that are clinically inconsequential. As a result, physicians often ignore these warnings or do not react appropriately. In turn, as physicians start to ignore both meaningless and critical alarms, there are negative implications for patient safety because medical errors occur, like the one seen here where the physician ignored a computerized clinical alarm regarding a drug interaction.

Hindsight bias, in the context of safety analysis, is the tendency to judge events that led to an outcome as having been more predictable than they actually were. In this case, the physician did not make a decision based on events that, at the time, could have been perceived as leading to a negative outcome.

question_text: A 36-year-old man is admitted to the hospital because of a cocaine overdose. At the time of admission, he is agitated and his blood pressure is 210/150 mm Hg. The physician writes an order in the patient's paper chart for “5.0 mg phentolamine” and “2.5 mg diazepam” to be administered intravenously every 15 minutes. Three hours later, the patient loses consciousness. His blood pressure is 70/50 mm Hg. The physician determines that the patient received ten times the prescribed dose of one of the medications as a result of an error. Which of the following measures would have most likely prevented the medication error?
content_preview: A 36-year-old man is admitted to the hospital because of a cocaine overdose. At the time of admission, he is agitated and his blood pressure is 210/150 mm Hg. The physician writes an order in the patient's paper chart for “5.0 mg phentolamine” and “2.5 mg diazepam” to be administered intravenously every 15 minutes. Three hours later, the patient loses consciousness. His blood pressure is 70/50 mm Hg. The physician determines that the patient received ten times the prescribed dose of one of the medications as a result of an error. Which of the following measures would have most likely prevented the medication error?
hint: Medication errors can occur at the stages of ordering (prescribing), transcribing, dispensing, and administering a drug. This patient's medication error is most likely due to faulty transcribing and led to the misinterpretation of a trailing zero.
learning_objective: Recognize the role of computerized provider order entry in preventing medication errors.

answers.explanation_why: Medication reconciliation is a measure used to prevent ordering errors during a transition of care and helps to avoid inconsistencies between the patient's previous medication and the new medication prescribed. In this case, the medication error occurred at the transcribing stage and led to the misinterpretation of a trailing zero, which would not have been prevented by medication reconciliation.

Tall man lettering is a strategy used to prevent dispensing errors related to medications that look or sound alike (e.g., buPROPion vs. busPIRone). In this case, the medication error occurred at the transcribing stage and led to the misinterpretation of a trailing zero, which would not have been prevented by tall man lettering.

Paper-based systems, in which medication orders are handwritten, are prone to transcribing errors, which can result in the recipient of the order not being able to properly read and interpret the prescription. In this case, as the physician determined that the patient received ten times the prescribed dose, the transcribing error was most likely due to the misinterpretation of a trailing zero after a decimal point. Trailing zeros are part of the Joint Commission's “Do Not Use” list, which provides recommendations on information management. To prevent transcribing errors, most hospitals have adopted computerized provider order entry (CPOE) systems, which also have the advantage of helping to prevent ordering errors because they are usually combined with a clinical decision support system. If a CPOE system has not been adopted and the health care facility maintains a paper-based system, the usage of standardized abbreviations/writing styles and having an intermediary (like a clinical pharmacist or a pharmacy technician) read and interpret the prescriptions can also help to prevent transcribing errors.

A multicompartment medication device is recommended for patients in ambulatory settings taking multiple medications to help prevent administration errors and improve medication safety and adherence. In this case, the medication error occurred at the transcribing stage and led to the misinterpretation of a trailing zero, which would not have been prevented by a multicompartment medication device.

A clinical decision support system (CDSS) generates computerized recommendations or alerts based on patient information to prevent ordering errors. Examples of ordering errors include prescribing a drug that is contraindicated (e.g., due to drug interactions or drug allergies) and a failure to prescribe the correct dose based on weight, renal dysfunction, or hepatic dysfunction. In this case, the medication error occurred as a result of a trailing zero during transcribing, which would not have been prevented by a CDSS.

question_text: A 72-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. He has nontremor-dominant Parkinson disease that was diagnosed at the age of 68 after developing progressive bradykinesia and rigidity. He lives alone following the death of his wife 2 years ago. The patient's son, daughter-in-law, and grandchildren live nearby and help him with daily activities. Current medications include levodopa, carbidopa, and entacapone. He appears well. Neurologic examination shows mild hypomimia, bradydiadochokinesia, shortened steps, and mild gait shuffling. During the examination, the patient mentions that he drove himself to his appointment today because he does not want to feel like a burden on his son. The physician is concerned that the patient's illness and medications potentially impair his driving skills. The patient stresses that he has never had an accident in his life and is a very safe driver. He also states that he has felt isolated since his wife's passing and likes to meet up with old friends at a local bar. Which of the following is the most appropriate reaction by the physician?
content_preview: A 72-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. He has nontremor-dominant Parkinson disease that was diagnosed at the age of 68 after developing progressive bradykinesia and rigidity. He lives alone following the death of his wife 2 years ago. The patient's son, daughter-in-law, and grandchildren live nearby and help him with daily activities. Current medications include levodopa, carbidopa, and entacapone. He appears well. Neurologic examination shows mild hypomimia, bradydiadochokinesia, shortened steps, and mild gait shuffling. During the examination, the patient mentions that he drove himself to his appointment today because he does not want to feel like a burden on his son. The physician is concerned that the patient's illness and medications potentially impair his driving skills. The patient stresses that he has never had an accident in his life and is a very safe driver. He also states that he has felt isolated since his wife's passing and likes to meet up with old friends at a local bar. Which of the following is the most appropriate reaction by the physician?
hint: The physician must balance responsibility to public safety with the welfare of the individual patient.
learning_objective: Recognize the physician's responsibility regarding a patient's driving capacity and public safety.

answers.content: "You should not feel that you are a burden on your son. I'm sure he will be happy to drive you."
answers.explanation_why: A physician should encourage patients to communicate with their family members and seek help when necessary. However, it is inappropriate for the physician to presume that the patient's son would be willing to drive for the patient. The physician should instead explore the patient's reasons for feeling like a burden on his son, rather than simply instructing him not to feel this way. Moreover, in this case, it is critical to inform the patient that his current condition impairs his ability to drive safely; a different reaction would, therefore, be appropriate.

answers.content: "I understand that you need your car to stay mobile, but without an official evaluation of your driving capacity, you should not be driving anywhere."
answers.explanation_why:
Irrespective of state laws, if a physician believes that a patient cannot drive safely, the physician must share their concerns with the patient and ask them to stop driving until they have been evaluated and treated by a driver rehabilitation specialist. Alternatively, the patient can be recleared for driving by the state licensing authority (e.g., Department of Motor Vehicles). However, the laws for reporting impaired drivers differ between states.

Most states have voluntary reporting laws, under which a physician is not required to disclose a patient's driving impairment to the state licensing authority but are protected from a breach of patient confidentiality if they do so. Some states have mandatory reporting laws, which require physicians to report any patient with driving impairment to the state licensing authority. In states with voluntary or mandatory reporting laws, the physician can be held liable for a motor vehicle accident involving the impaired driver if the physician does not report the driving impairment. A few states do not have any reporting laws and require the physician to obtain the patient's consent before disclosing driving impairment to the authorities. In these states, the physician cannot be held liable for a motor vehicle accident involving the impaired driver if the physician does not have consent to disclose driver impairment.

answers.content: "I have a duty to public safety and unfortunately, I must inform the police that you are still driving."
answers.explanation_why: In states with mandatory reporting laws, the physician has an obligation to report patients with conditions that impair driving ability. However, the state licensing authority (e.g., Department of Motor Vehicles) rather than the police should be informed in this scenario. The physician needs to inform the police only if the patient divulges a criminal act to the physician (e.g., hit-and-run, alcohol-related car accident).

answers.content: "I would advise you to stop driving, but I cannot tell you what to do. Just be aware that it is solely your responsibility if something bad happens."
answers.explanation_why: When the patient has a condition that limits their ability to drive safely, the physician must advise the patient to stop driving. However, in most states, if the patient continues to drive against medical advice and the physician does not report the patient to state licensing authorities, the physician can also be held liable for injuries that occur from a motor vehicle accident involving the patient.

answers.content: "I understand this is a difficult situation for you, but I have to ask you to surrender your driver's license now."
answers.explanation_why: The physician cannot ask a patient to surrender their driver's license. The state licensing authorities (e.g., Department of Motor Vehicles) rather than a physician should determine the patient's inability to drive safely.

question_text: A 52-year-old woman with atrial fibrillation comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of bright red anal bleeding. Her current medications include warfarin and metoprolol. One month ago, her primary care physician increased the dose of warfarin because of subtherapeutic coagulation studies. A repeat coagulation study was ordered for the following week. Today, the physician realizes that the test results were sent back to the office 18 days ago and show a prothrombin time of 43 seconds (INR = 4.0). Which of the following actions is most likely to have prevented this patient's current condition?
content_preview: A 52-year-old woman with atrial fibrillation comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of bright red anal bleeding. Her current medications include warfarin and metoprolol. One month ago, her primary care physician increased the dose of warfarin because of subtherapeutic coagulation studies. A repeat coagulation study was ordered for the following week. Today, the physician realizes that the test results were sent back to the office 18 days ago and show a prothrombin time of 43 seconds (INR = 4.0). Which of the following actions is most likely to have prevented this patient's current condition?
hint: The delay in the follow-up of the patient's test results lead to a delay in the dose-adjustment of warfarin and, subsequently, a preventable adverse drug event. This medical error can be prevented by standardization, a principle of human factors engineering.
learning_objective: Recognize the importance of standardization to prevent delays in test result follow-up.

answers.content: Instruct the office front staff to label all abnormal test results as "urgent."
answers.explanation_why: Critical test results, which require an immediate review by a physician (e.g., high PT/INR, derangements in potassium levels), can be labeled as “urgent” in order to bring these results to the attention of the caregiver sooner and thereby help prevent a delay in follow-up. However, this measure can only be implemented successfully by trained personnel (e.g., physicians, laboratory technicians, nurses); office front staff are not trained to identify critical test results; if they are instructed to label all abnormal test results as “urgent,” alert fatigue can occur and cause the physician to ignore the “urgent” label.

answers.content: Provide the patient with a visual medication schedule for warfarin use.
answers.explanation_why: The use of a visual medication schedule (VMS) for patients receiving warfarin has been shown to decrease the time needed to reach an optimal PT/INR level. However, a VMS is used to prevent communication errors (e.g., patient-physician discordance) and improve patient compliance rather than to prevent an error caused by a delay in follow-up.

answers.content: Maintain a record of therapeutic drug monitoring tests that need reviewing.
answers.explanation_why:
Standardization of protocols for the follow-up of test results (e.g., maintaining a record of therapeutic drug monitoring tests that need to be reviewed, or a record of tests with pending results) can help prevent medical errors that occur as a result of a delay in follow-up by the physician. Protocols help ensure a consistent level of quality and increase efficiency (e.g., reduce the variation in follow-up time and increase the likelihood of the physician reviewing critical test results as soon as they arrive). By using a standardized protocol, the physician would have been notified that the patient's INR was too high earlier, could have adjusted the warfarin dose in time, and thereby have prevented the anal bleeding.

Further examples of standardization include the introduction of checklists and guidelines as well as standardized equipment and terminology.

answers.content: Ask the patient to sign up for online access to her diagnostic test results.
answers.explanation_why: The involvement of the patient in safety efforts can act as a check to prevent medical errors (multilayered safety system of a swiss cheese model); an online portal that provides patients access to their test results can reduce the risk of a delay in follow-up because patients are likely to contact their physician in the case of an abnormal result. However, several patient-related factors (e.g., lack of internet access, low literacy level, low motivation, inability to interpret test results), and design-related factors (e.g., poor ease-of-use) can limit the usefulness of these portals. Moreover, this step does not address the physician's responsibility to follow up on the patient's results in a timely manner and lays this responsibility squarely on the patient.

answers.content: Administer an initial bridging therapy with low-molecular-weight heparin.
answers.explanation_why: Initial bridging therapy with low-molecular-weight heparin is used to prevent thromboembolic events associated with the initiation of warfarin (e.g., warfarin-induced skin necrosis) rather than to prevent bleeding.

question_text: A 35-year-old man calls the physician because his wife was diagnosed one day ago with an infection caused by a particular virus strain. He feels well but is currently quarantined. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. His wife has a history of rheumatoid arthritis treated with hydroxychloroquine. He does not drink alcohol, smoke, or use illicit drugs. The patient has read that hydroxychloroquine is an effective means of preventing infections with the virus strain and asks the physician if it would be appropriate to use his wife's medication for postexposure prophylaxis. A review of which of the following types of clinical studies is most appropriate to provide a recommendation to the patient?
content_preview: A 35-year-old man calls the physician because his wife was diagnosed one day ago with an infection caused by a particular virus strain. He feels well but is currently quarantined. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. His wife has a history of rheumatoid arthritis treated with hydroxychloroquine. He does not drink alcohol, smoke, or use illicit drugs. The patient has read that hydroxychloroquine is an effective means of preventing infections with the virus strain and asks the physician if it would be appropriate to use his wife's medication for postexposure prophylaxis. A review of which of the following types of clinical studies is most appropriate to provide a recommendation to the patient?
hint: In order to provide an appropriate treatment recommendation, it is important to review studies that evaluate the effect of an intervention.
learning_objective: Recall the hierarchy of clinical study designs to determine treatment efficacy.

answers.explanation_why: A case report is an observational study that describes the clinical course of a disease in a single patient case (e.g., one patient taking hydroxychloroquine after exposure to the new virus strain) and can help establish a hypothesis. However, case reports have limited generalizability and do not establish causality, because they do not test hypotheses. Therefore, case reports do not provide the best possible evidence for devising a treatment strategy.

In a case-control study, study participants are first selected from a population based on a given outcome – individuals with the outcome (e.g., infection with the new virus strain) are assigned to a comparison group, and those without it are assigned to a control group. The frequency of exposure to a modifier (e.g., hydroxychloroquine use) is then analyzed for each group. Case-control studies can test a hypothesis and establish some degree of causal inference, so they can be used to devise a treatment strategy. However, case-control studies are observational, analytical studies that do not manipulate the modifier; other study designs have a higher level of evidence.

A cross-sectional study evaluates the point prevalence of an exposure and/or outcome using data assessed individually from all participants (e.g., assessment of hydroxychloroquine use and infection status through a survey). Cross-sectional studies can show associations and help establish a hypothesis. However, as these studies do not test hypotheses, they do not establish causality. Therefore, cross-sectional studies do not provide good evidence to devise a treatment strategy.

An ecological study evaluates the point prevalence of an exposure and/or outcome using population-based data (e.g., evaluation of hydroxychloroquine use for postexposure prophylaxis and assessment of active infections with the new virus strain in different states using data from local health authority reports). Ecological studies can show associations and help establish a hypothesis. However, these studies do not test hypotheses, so they do not establish causality. Therefore, ecological studies do not provide the best possible evidence for devising a treatment strategy.

In a prospective cohort study, individuals with similar characteristics are categorized into groups based on their exposure to a modifier (e.g., hydroxychloroquine use), and these groups are followed over a period of time to determine the incidence of a given outcome (e.g., infection with the new virus strain). Prospective cohort studies can test a hypothesis and establish a certain level of causal inference, so they can be used to devise treatment strategies. However, prospective cohort studies are observational, analytical studies that do not manipulate the modifier; other study designs have a higher level of evidence.

A case series report is an observational study that describes the clinical course of a disease by aggregating similar patient cases (e.g., several patients taking hydroxychloroquine after exposure to the new virus strain). Case series reports can help establish a hypothesis, but have limited generalizability and do not establish causality, as they do not test hypotheses. Therefore, case series reports do not provide the best possible evidence for devising a treatment strategy.

Randomized controlled trials (RCTs), which compare different treatment options against each other (e.g., hydroxychloroquine vs. placebo), are appropriate to ascertain the efficacy and safety of a treatment for a particular condition. RCTs establish causality through hypothesis testing; study participants are randomly allocated to either the new treatment/intervention group or the control group and subsequently evaluated for the outcome of interest. Randomization reduces bias and confounding and confers a high level of evidence to these studies. The highest level of evidence is attributed to systematic reviews with meta-analysis of RCTs, followed by individual RCTs.

See “Levels of evidence” table.

images.title: Temporal aspects of different study types
images.description: Cross-sectional studies (prevalence studies, snapshot studies) are used to determine the prevalence of exposure (e.g., a risk factor) and outcome (e.g., disease) at a specific point in time.Case-control studies are used to determine whether an exposure that happened in the past is associated with a present outcome. Researchers begin by selecting patients with the disease (cases) and individuals without the disease (controls). The two groups are then compared with regard to exposure to a risk factor in the past.In prospective cohort studies, participants are divided into an exposed (e.g., to a risk factor) and an unexposed group and then followed over the course of time to determine whether there is a difference in the rate of outcome (disease) between the two groups.Retrospective cohort studies begin after the exposure and outcome of interest have already occurred. Medical records previously collected about the participants are compared to determine whether there was a difference in the rate at which the exposed and unexposed groups developed the outcome of interest in the past.In experimental studies, researchers introduce an intervention and study its effects.Randomized controlled trials aim to determine the possible effect of a specific intervention on a given population. People are randomly allocated into an intervention and control group and monitored over the course of time for outcomes of interest.

question_text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She feels well. She has no history of serious illness. She works as a flight attendant. She is sexually active with one male partner. Menses occur at regular 28-day intervals with a normal flow; her last menstrual period was 10 days ago. She had a normal Pap smear 1 year ago. She does not have any children. Her mother was diagnosed with ovarian cancer at the age of 63 years. She does not smoke cigarettes or use illicit drugs. She does not wish to have any children and uses oral contraceptive therapy. She has no known allergies, and her immunizations are up-to-date. She appears healthy. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 72/min, and blood pressure is 124/76 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The patient is concerned about her risk for ovarian cancer. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 40-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She feels well. She has no history of serious illness. She works as a flight attendant. She is sexually active with one male partner. Menses occur at regular 28-day intervals with a normal flow; her last menstrual period was 10 days ago. She had a normal Pap smear 1 year ago. She does not have any children. Her mother was diagnosed with ovarian cancer at the age of 63 years. She does not smoke cigarettes or use illicit drugs. She does not wish to have any children and uses oral contraceptive therapy. She has no known allergies, and her immunizations are up-to-date. She appears healthy. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 72/min, and blood pressure is 124/76 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The patient is concerned about her risk for ovarian cancer. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: The recommendation for this patient would be the same if she had a personal history of breast cancer.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate next step in assessing ovarian cancer risk.

answers.content: Perform familial risk assessment using a questionnaire
answers.explanation_why:
Screening recommendations in the context of cancer susceptibility due to BRCA mutations vary. The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force recommends that women with a personal history of breast, ovarian, tubal, or peritoneal cancer or with a positive family history for these types of cancer undergo familial risk assessment with a standardized questionnaire (e.g., Ontario Family History Assessment Tool, referral screening tool for ovarian cancer). Risk factors for ovarian cancer evaluated by the risk assessment tools include personal or family history of ovarian, breast cancer, and certain other types of cancer (e.g., bowel cancer), age at diagnosis, number of relatives affected, and Ashkenazi Jewish descent. If the result of the risk assessment tool is positive, genetic counseling and, if indicated after counseling, genetic testing for BRCA mutations should follow.

Screening for ovarian cancer is not routinely recommended for women who do not have a personal or family history of the above-mentioned types of cancer because of a lack of evidence that supports such screening. Patients who are known BRCA mutation carriers and do not wish to undergo preventive bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy may be offered periodic screening for ovarian cancer (e.g., annual transvaginal ultrasound and CA-125 levels).

Risk-reducing salpingo-oophorectomy may be recommended for individuals who have a hereditary cancer syndrome (e.g., BRCA1 mutation, BRCA2 mutation, Lynch syndrome) and are not planning any future pregnancies. This patient's risk for ovarian cancer has not yet been evaluated yet.

answers.content: Recommend barrier contraception instead of oral contraceptive therapy
answers.explanation_why: Long-term combined oral contraceptive therapy decreases the risk of developing ovarian cancer and therefore should be continued in this patient. There are contraindications to this therapy (e.g., high risk for cardiovascular disease, known thrombogenic mutations, history of migraines with aura), but none of them are present in this patient.

answers.content: Recommend annual transvaginal ultrasonography and measurement of serum CA-125 concentration
answers.explanation_why: Annual transvaginal ultrasonography (TVUS) and measurement of serum CA-125 concentration were previously recommended to screen for ovarian cancer. However, most guidelines no longer endorse these screening tests because of their low specificity and lack of survival benefit in the general population. In patients who are known BRCA mutation carriers and do not wish to undergo preventive surgery, annual screening with TVUS and serum CA-125 may be offered.

answers.content: Perform genetic testing for BRCA1 and BRCA2 mutations
answers.explanation_why: According to U.S. Preventive Services Task Force recommendations, genetic screening for BRCA1 and BRCA2 mutations should be considered in patients with a positive family history of ovarian cancer associated with BRCA mutations. Although this patient's mother developed ovarian cancer, it is not known whether she also had an associated BRCA mutation. Another step in management is more appropriate before proceeding to genetic testing.

question_text: A 20-year-old woman is being prepared to undergo orthodontic bracket placement for a dental overbite. She feels well. Three years ago, she underwent splenectomy for traumatic splenic rupture. She does not have any known allergies and has no family history of serious illness. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Her immunizations are up-to-date. Her only medication is a multivitamin. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 124/88 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Cardiac auscultation shows a normal S_1 and S_2 and no murmurs. The patient is concerned about her asplenic state and asks the physician if she needs to take any antibiotics to decrease her risk of infection. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation by the physician?
content_preview: A 20-year-old woman is being prepared to undergo orthodontic bracket placement for a dental overbite. She feels well. Three years ago, she underwent splenectomy for traumatic splenic rupture. She does not have any known allergies and has no family history of serious illness. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Her immunizations are up-to-date. Her only medication is a multivitamin. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 124/88 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Cardiac auscultation shows a normal S1 and S2 and no murmurs. The patient is concerned about her asplenic state and asks the physician if she needs to take any antibiotics to decrease her risk of infection. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation by the physician?
hint: This would also be the most appropriate recommendation for this patient if she did not have asplenia.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate antibiotic prophylaxis for asplenic patients undergoing low-risk dental procedures.

answers.content: Administration of oral amoxicillin 60 minutes prior to the procedure
answers.explanation_why: Administration of oral amoxicillin 60 minutes prior to the procedure is the first-line therapy for infective endocarditis prophylaxis, which is indicated in high-risk patients undergoing procedures with a significant risk of bacteremia. Orthodontic bracket placement is not considered a dental procedure with a high risk of bacteremia.

answers.content: Following the procedure, daily administration of oral penicillin V for one year
answers.explanation_why: Daily administration of oral penicillin V for one year is indicated after splenectomy in children under 5 years of age to prevent infections with encapsulated bacteria. However, daily antibiotic therapy for one year is not recommended in adult patients after splenectomy, and it is not indicated after dental procedures in asplenic patients.

answers.content: Administration of intravenous cefazolin 30 minutes prior to the procedure
answers.explanation_why: Administration of intravenous cefazolin 30 minutes prior to the procedure is indicated for endocarditis prophylaxis in patients who are unable to take oral penicillin (first-line). Endocarditis prophylaxis is indicated in high-risk patients undergoing procedures with a significant risk of bacteremia. Orthodontic bracket placement is not considered a dental procedure with a high risk of bacteremia. Furthermore, this patient does not have nausea or vomiting and has no history of a condition that impairs deglutition.

answers.content: Administration of oral azithromycin 30 minutes prior to the procedure
answers.explanation_why: Administration of oral azithromycin 30 minutes prior to the procedure is indicated for endocarditis prophylaxis in patients who are allergic to penicillin. Endocarditis prophylaxis is indicated in high-risk patients undergoing procedures with a significant risk of bacteremia. Orthodontic bracket placement is not considered a dental procedure with a high risk of bacteremia. Furthermore, this patient does not have a history of allergy to penicillin.

Antibiotic prophylaxis should be considered in patients with asplenia who are undergoing procedures that increase the risk of infection with encapsulated bacteria (i.e., procedures involving the paranasal sinuses and respiratory tract). In addition, asplenic patients may receive antibiotic prophylaxis for infective endocarditis (IE) if they undergo procedures with a high risk of bacteremia, e.g., tooth extraction. These procedures, however, do not include orthodontic bracket placement. This patient will undergo a dental procedure with a low risk of infection with encapsulated bacteria or bacteremia and she has no other indications for endocarditis prophylaxis (e.g., history of IE); therefore, no antibiotic prophylaxis is indicated.

IE prophylaxis is recommended for dental procedures that involve manipulation of the gingiva (e.g., tooth extraction, professional dental cleaning) in patients with the following heart defects: history of IE; prosthetic material used for cardiac valve repair/replacement; unrepaired cyanotic congenital heart disease (CHD); repaired CHD with residual defects; repaired CHD during the first 6 months after the procedure; history of cardiac transplant with cardiac valvulopathy.

answers.content: Following the procedure, monthly administration of intramuscular penicillin G for 5 years
answers.explanation_why: Monthly administration of intramuscular penicillin G for 5 years or until the patient reaches 21 years of age is used as secondary prevention of rheumatic heart disease in patients with a history of rheumatic fever without carditis. This patient does not have a history of rheumatic fever.

question_text: A 1-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for a scheduled immunization visit. The patient's father reports that the patient had continual crying, increased irritability, and fever for the past 2 days. He has noticed that the patient keeps tugging at his left ear. The patient was born at 32 weeks' gestation but has been otherwise healthy and has no history of serious illness. At the fourth well-child visit, the third dose of diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis, Hemophilus influenza type b (Hib), pneumococcal conjugate (PCV15), inactivated poliovirus, and hepatitis B (HepB) vaccines were administered. He is at the 25^th percentile for length and weight with respect to chronological age; when corrected for gestational age, he is at the 40^th percentile for length and weight. His temperature is 37.8°C (100.1°F); the remainder of his vital signs are within normal limits. Otoscopic examination of the left ear shows an erythematous, bulging tympanic membrane; examination of the right ear shows no abnormalities. Treatment with ibuprofen and amoxicillin is initiated. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation by the physician regarding immunization?
content_preview: A 1-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for a scheduled immunization visit. The patient's father reports that the patient had continual crying, increased irritability, and fever for the past 2 days. He has noticed that the patient keeps tugging at his left ear. The patient was born at 32 weeks' gestation but has been otherwise healthy and has no history of serious illness. At the fourth well-child visit, the third dose of diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis, Hemophilus influenza type b (Hib), pneumococcal conjugate (PCV15), inactivated poliovirus, and hepatitis B (HepB) vaccines were administered. He is at the 25th percentile for length and weight with respect to chronological age; when corrected for gestational age, he is at the 40th percentile for length and weight. His temperature is 37.8°C (100.1°F); the remainder of his vital signs are within normal limits. Otoscopic examination of the left ear shows an erythematous, bulging tympanic membrane; examination of the right ear shows no abnormalities. Treatment with ibuprofen and amoxicillin is initiated. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation by the physician regarding immunization?
hint: If there are no absolute contraindications, immunizations indicated at 12 months include the fourth Hib dose; fourth PCV15 dose; first measles, mumps, and rubella dose; and first varicella dose.
learning_objective: Choose the appropriate immunization recommendation for a child with mild acute illness.

answers.content: Administer standard doses of all vaccines due at this visit
answers.explanation_why:
This patient should receive the standard doses of all vaccines due at this visit. Neither mild acute illness (e.g., upper respiratory tract infection, otitis media, low-grade fever, mild diarrhea) nor current antibiotic therapy are contraindications for vaccination (except for oral live typhoid vaccine, because antibiotics might compromise the immune response to this vaccine). All children must be immunized with the standard doses of vaccines according to their chronological age; doses should not be adjusted to weight or gestational age.

The only vaccine that depends on the child's birth weight is the first dose of HepB vaccine; infants with a birth weight < 2 kg should receive the first dose of the vaccine at 1 month of age or at hospital discharge, whichever occurs first.

answers.content: Administer weight-adjusted doses of all due vaccines after the illness resolves
answers.explanation_why: Valid contraindications for vaccination include previous severe allergic reactions related to vaccination (e.g., anaphylaxis) and severe allergies to components of a vaccine. Moderate to severe acute illness with or without fever is a precaution for vaccine administration. Mild illnesses, such as otitis media and low-grade fever are not contraindications for vaccination. Adjusting the dosage based on weight is not recommended for the vaccines indicated in this patient (Hib vaccine, PCV15, varicella vaccine, and measles, mumps, and rubella vaccine).

answers.content: Administer standard doses of all due vaccines after 5 weeks
answers.explanation_why: Preterm infants should be vaccinated at the same chronological age, according to the same schedule, and using the same precautions as full-term infants. Correction for gestational age is not recommended.

answers.content: Administer weight-adjusted doses of all vaccines due at this visit
answers.explanation_why: Vaccination is contraindicated in patients who have experienced a severe allergic reaction to a prior dose or component of a vaccine, which is not seen here. However, adjusting the dosage based on weight is not recommended for the vaccines indicated in this patient (Hib vaccine, PCV15, varicella vaccine, and measles, mumps, and rubella vaccine).

answers.content: Administer standard doses of inactivated vaccines at this visit and live vaccines after the illness resolves
answers.explanation_why: Live attenuated vaccines are not recommended in pregnant and/or immunocompromised individuals (e.g., those receiving immunosuppressive therapy, patients with congenital immunodeficiencies, severely immunocompromised patients with HIV). In such cases, the standard doses of inactivated vaccines might be indicated, but the administration of live vaccines should be postponed until after delivery or until the patient is no longer considered immunocompromised. This patient has neither of these contraindications, so another approach would be more appropriate.

question_text: A 31-year-old homeless and uninsured man is brought to the emergency department because he was found agitated and yelling for help. He is well known to the emergency department and has been in and out of the hospital 6 times in the past month for various issues. He has used up his allotted health care assistance program limit and has an outstanding debt to the hospital. When the physician speaks to him, the man states that he just used some drugs that his friend gave him and now has chest pain. Except for illicit drug use, his past medical history is unknown. He appears unkempt. He is diaphoretic and malodorous but oriented to time, place, and person. Which of the following is the most appropriate statement by the physician?
content_preview: A 31-year-old homeless and uninsured man is brought to the emergency department because he was found agitated and yelling for help. He is well known to the emergency department and has been in and out of the hospital 6 times in the past month for various issues. He has used up his allotted health care assistance program limit and has an outstanding debt to the hospital. When the physician speaks to him, the man states that he just used some drugs that his friend gave him and now has chest pain. Except for illicit drug use, his past medical history is unknown. He appears unkempt. He is diaphoretic and malodorous but oriented to time, place, and person. Which of the following is the most appropriate statement by the physician?
hint: This patient with chest pain and diaphoresis might have acute coronary syndrome (ACS), which is a potentially life-threatening condition.
learning_objective: Recognize the obligations under EMTALA to screen and stabilize emergency medical conditions.

answers.content: "We will need to set up health insurance coverage for you with the county healthcare assistance program before treating you."
answers.explanation_why: According to the Emergency Medical Treatment and Labor Act (EMTALA), any hospital with an emergency department is legally obligated to evaluate and stabilize an acute medical emergency (e.g., ACS), regardless of the patient's health insurance coverage. Once the patient is stabilized, it would be appropriate to assist him in finding additional healthcare coverage (e.g., through a county healthcare assistance program for low-income patients).

answers.content: "We will treat you to the best of our ability, but we will not be liable in the event of medical negligence."
answers.explanation_why: According to the Emergency Medical Treatment and Labor Act (EMTALA), any hospital with an emergency department is legally obligated to evaluate and stabilize an acute medical emergency (e.g., ACS). The hospital and/or treating physician may still be held liable in the event of medical negligence.

answers.content: "We will check your vital signs and do a workup of your chest pain, but we will have to deny further treatment if the cause of your chest pain is not a medical emergency."
answers.explanation_why: According to the Emergency Medical Treatment and Labor Act (EMTALA), any hospital with an emergency department is obligated to screen for emergency medical conditions if requested and, if such a condition exists, provide treatment until that condition is stabilized. Failure to diagnose and treat ACS would endanger this patient's life. The EMTALA defines an emergency medical condition as a medical condition that manifests with acute symptoms (including pain and labor contractions) that are sufficiently severe to (i) place the health of the individual or unborn child in serious jeopardy, (ii) seriously impair bodily functions, or (iii) cause serious dysfunction of an organ or body part.

answers.content: "We will help you get transferred to the nearest hospital, but we cannot treat you since you have used up your allotted health care assistance program limit at our hospital."
answers.explanation_why: According to the Emergency Medical Treatment and Labor Act (EMTALA), any hospital with an emergency department is legally obligated to evaluate and stabilize an acute medical emergency (e.g., ACS), regardless of the patient's financial limitations. Transferring the patient to another hospital is appropriate if the hospital is not equipped or staffed to properly evaluate and treat a patient's condition.

answers.content: "We will treat you only if you commit to enrolling in a drug rehabilitation program."
answers.explanation_why: According to the Emergency Medical Treatment and Labor Act (EMTALA), any hospital with an emergency department is legally obligated to evaluate and stabilize an acute medical emergency (e.g., ACS), regardless of the patient's willingness to participate in a drug rehabilitation program. Once the patient is stabilized, it is appropriate to assist him in enrolling in such a program.

question_text: Before starting a new job at a large health care organization, a 29-year-old physician speaks to a representative in the human resources department regarding the health care payment model used by the organization. When the physician asks how prices are negotiated between the health insurance company and the health care organization, the representative explains that the organization is compensated a fixed amount for each episode of care. The representative explains that the fixed amount is distributed among all health care providers that provided care for the patient for that specific episode. This arrangement best describes which of the following health care payment models?
content_preview: Before starting a new job at a large health care organization, a 29-year-old physician speaks to a representative in the human resources department regarding the health care payment model used by the organization. When the physician asks how prices are negotiated between the health insurance company and the health care organization, the representative explains that the organization is compensated a fixed amount for each episode of care. The representative explains that the fixed amount is distributed among all health care providers that provided care for the patient for that specific episode. This arrangement best describes which of the following health care payment models?
hint: This payment model encourages the cost-effective provision of care.
learning_objective: Recognize the characteristics of a bundled payment health care model.

answers.explanation_why: In a per diem payment model, a health care organization is compensated a fixed amount per patient and per day of care for a specific care service provided, regardless of the actual costs involved in providing services for any particular patient. This model does not reflect the scenario described here, in which the organization is compensated a fixed amount for the entire clinically defined episode of care. A per diem payment model is often used for the reimbursement of inpatient services and can provide a perverse incentive for prolonging the duration of hospital stay.

In a fee-for-service payment model, health care organizations are compensated for each individual service provided (e.g., individual laboratory tests, imaging studies, procedures). This model does not reflect the scenario described here, in which the organization receives a fixed amount for each clinically defined episode of care that is then distributed among all the health care providers involved. A fee-for-service payment model can be a perverse incentive against efficiency and risks patients being overtreated because compensation is based on the quantity of services provided.

In a capitation payment model, health care providers receive a set amount of compensation per patient during each payment period, regardless of the actual amount of health care utilized by the patient. This model does not reflect the scenario described here, in which the organization receives a fixed amount for each clinically defined episode of care. Capitation incentivizes health care providers to promote efficient use of health care resources (e.g., cost-effective preventive health care to avoid larger downstream costs) and increases accountability and transparency through reporting of quality metrics. Risks of capitation include provision of substandard care as a method of cost reduction and rejection of medically complex patients from patient panels by providers to reduce negative impacts on the ability to meet quality metrics.

Value-based care or pay-for-performance (P4P) comprises payment models in which compensation also depends on the quality of care physicians provide. Although P4P uses the fee-for-service system, it includes financial incentives or disincentives that depend on the health care provider's performance, which is assessed through the analysis of metric-driven outcomes, clinical practices, and patient satisfaction. This model does not reflect the scenario described here, in which the organization receives a fixed amount for each clinically defined episode of care, irrespective of the quality of care provided.

The arrangement describes a bundled payment model in which a health care organization is compensated a fixed amount based on the expected costs for all services provided for each clinically defined episode of care (e.g., hip replacement, cholecystectomy), irrespective of the ultimate cost. Payment is then distributed to all the health care providers involved in the care of the patient for that specific episode. This payment model incentivizes cost-effective provision of care and increases accountability and transparency through reporting of quality metrics. Risks include provision of substandard care as a method of cost reduction. For example, physicians may be pressured to prematurely discharge patients from the hospital because the compensation received for each admission does not increase with a prolonged duration of hospital stay.

question_text: A 41-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She has a history of atrial fibrillation and underwent a total hysterectomy for a severe postpartum hemorrhage 4 years ago. The results of her last high-risk HPV/Pap smear cotest from 5 years ago were negative. Current medications include propranolol, warfarin, and a vitamin supplement. She is married and has two children. She works as an elementary school teacher. Her temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 84/min, and blood pressure is 126/72 mm Hg; her BMI is 26 kg/m^2. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The physician recommends stopping high-risk HPV testing and Pap smears in this patient. Which of the following considerations best explains the physician's recommendation?
content_preview: A 41-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She has a history of atrial fibrillation and underwent a total hysterectomy for a severe postpartum hemorrhage 4 years ago. The results of her last high-risk HPV/Pap smear cotest from 5 years ago were negative. Current medications include propranolol, warfarin, and a vitamin supplement. She is married and has two children. She works as an elementary school teacher. Her temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 84/min, and blood pressure is 126/72 mm Hg; her BMI is 26 kg/m2. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The physician recommends stopping high-risk HPV testing and Pap smears in this patient. Which of the following considerations best explains the physician's recommendation?
hint: Another application of this system-based concept is the recommendation to stop all cancer screening protocols in patients with end-stage kidney disease.
learning_objective: Recognize the concept of resource stewardship in healthcare.

answers.explanation_why: Therapeutic privilege refers to a situation in which a physician withholds relevant health information from the patient if disclosure may cause severe psychological harm to the patient. In this case, therapeutic privilege does not apply because the physician did not withhold any information from the patient.

Resource stewardship refers to the concept of managing the distribution of limited health care resources in order to avoid unnecessary testing and procedures. This means that more resources will be directed to the individuals who need them the most and patients will be spared from undergoing unnecessary procedures that may be more harmful than beneficial. For example, this patient, who underwent a total hysterectomy, is no longer at risk for cervical cancer and therefore does not require further Pap smears or screening for human papillomavirus. One way of improving resource stewardship is the lean process improvement method, in which factors that use time, energy, and resources but do not improve patient outcomes (also referred to as “waste”) are continuously identified and eliminated.

Shared decision-making is a communication principle in which patients and physicians decide on the best treatment option together. In this case, the physician made a recommendation without first consulting with the patient, which means this was not a shared decision-making process.

Healthcare ergonomics refers to the concept of creating a work environment that provides optimal working conditions for health care workers, which reduces injuries, ensures safety, and optimizes efficiency. This concept can be applied to the design of medical equipment, new medical technologies, and optimizing processes, but it does not apply to this scenario.

Medication reconciliation is the process of a physician comparing the patient's current prescribed medications to the ones actually taken in order to avoid medication errors (e.g., drug interactions, dosing errors, duplications, omissions). The physician's recommendation to stop Pap smears and HPV testing does not count as medical reconciliation.

question_text: A 37-year-old woman comes to the office for a routine health maintenance examination. She feels well. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Her mother died of lung cancer at the age of 55 years. She is sexually active in a monogamous relationship with a female partner. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 13 years. She does not drink alcoholic beverages or use illicit drugs. She is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 75 kg (165 lb); BMI is 24 kg/m^2. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Screening for which of the following conditions is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 37-year-old woman comes to the office for a routine health maintenance examination. She feels well. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Her mother died of lung cancer at the age of 55 years. She is sexually active in a monogamous relationship with a female partner. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 13 years. She does not drink alcoholic beverages or use illicit drugs. She is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 75 kg (165 lb); BMI is 24 kg/m2. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Screening for which of the following conditions is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Most adults only need to be screened for this condition once.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate condition for routine health screening in adults.

answers.explanation_why: Asymptomatic bacteriuria screening with urine culture is recommended for all pregnant persons during the first trimester. Screening is not otherwise recommended for healthy, nonpregnant individuals.

Colorectal cancer (CRC) screening (e.g., with complete colonoscopy or a fecal occult blood test) is recommended for adults ≥ 45 years of age. Individuals with a history of CRC or adenomatous polyps, a first-degree relative with CRC, or a hereditary syndrome associated with increased risk of CRC (e.g., familial adenomatous polyposis) are at increased risk and should receive more frequent screening. This 37-year-old patient has no identified risk factors for CRC and, therefore, does not require screening for this condition at this time.

Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) screening with abdominal ultrasonography can be considered in individuals < 65 years of age who have multiple risk factors or a positive family history for AAA, neither of which applies to this patient.

All individuals ≥ 18 years of age should be screened for hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection at least once in their lifetime. More frequent screening is recommended for individuals with risk factors for HCV infection, such as a history of injection drug use, solid-organ transplantation, long-term hemodialysis, or HIV infection. Screening is performed by testing the serum for anti-HCV antibodies; if screening is positive, the diagnosis can be confirmed with polymerase chain reaction testing for HCV RNA. With direct-acting antiviral treatment, the rate of complete cure with sustained virological response is over > 90%.

Atrial fibrillation screening (e.g., with ECG) is not recommended by the United States Preventive Services Task Force because of a lack of evidence assessing the benefits and potential harm related to screening. The American Heart Association and the American Stroke Association recommend screening in adults > 65 years of age. This 37-year-old patient does not require screening for atrial fibrillation at this time.

Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease screening is not recommended by the United States Preventive Services Task Force, as early detection does not change the course of the disease or improve patient outcomes.

question_text: A 42-year-old man comes to the office as a new patient. He recently moved to the area. He feels well. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. His mother has type 2 diabetes mellitus, and his paternal uncle had prostate cancer at the age of 73 years. The patient does not smoke cigarettes. He drinks three glasses of wine weekly. He works as a scriptwriter for a film production company and runs marathons to raise money for charity organizations in his free time. He has been monogamous with his wife for 15 years. He is 185 cm (6 ft 1 in) tall and weighs 77 kg (170 lb); BMI is 22 kg/m^2. Blood pressure is 123/72 mm Hg. Examination shows no abnormalities. Screening for which of the following is most appropriate at this time?
content_preview: A 42-year-old man comes to the office as a new patient. He recently moved to the area. He feels well. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. His mother has type 2 diabetes mellitus, and his paternal uncle had prostate cancer at the age of 73 years. The patient does not smoke cigarettes. He drinks three glasses of wine weekly. He works as a scriptwriter for a film production company and runs marathons to raise money for charity organizations in his free time. He has been monogamous with his wife for 15 years. He is 185 cm (6 ft 1 in) tall and weighs 77 kg (170 lb); BMI is 22 kg/m2. Blood pressure is 123/72 mm Hg. Examination shows no abnormalities. Screening for which of the following is most appropriate at this time?
hint: Screening for this disorder is recommended by the American Heart Association and various other expert groups for the primary prevention of atherosclerotic cardiovascular diseases (ASCVD).
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate screening for a middle-aged adult male with no additional ASCVD risk factors.

answers.explanation_why:
Early detection and treatment of hyperlipidemia is crucial to prevent ASCVD events like stroke or myocardial infarction. The guidelines for hyperlipidemia screening differ slightly among various expert groups. The current consensus is to screen all individuals aged 20–75 years using a fasting or nonfasting serum lipid profile test every 4–6 years in patients without additional ASCVD risk factors and at more frequent intervals in those with additional ASCVD risk factors. 

See “Screening recommendations for men by age” table.

Chlamydia and gonorrhea are the most common causes of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). Although PID is most often asymptomatic, it can result in severe complications, including infertility and ectopic pregnancy. Therefore, both the USPSTF and CDC recommend annual screening with a nucleic acid amplification test for chlamydia and gonorrhea in sexually active women < 25 years and women ≥ 25 years with certain risk factors (e.g., new or multiple sex partners, a sex partner with an STI). The CDC also recommends annual screening for both sexually active HIV-positive men and men who have sex with men because of the higher incidence of gonorrhea and chlamydia infections in these populations. Routine chlamydia and gonorrhea screening is not currently recommended for sexually active, HIV-negative men in monogamous, heterosexual relationships, such as this patient.
The AHA and other expert groups do recommend screening for a certain disease in this patient's age group.

The guidelines for prostate cancer screening differ slightly among various expert groups but the USPSTF recommends screening men aged 55–69 years with a life expectancy of at least 10 years after informing the patient of the benefits as well as risks of prostate cancer screening (e.g., relatively high false-positive rate, additional unnecessary procedures), i.e., by employing a shared decision-making strategy. Prostate cancer screening is most commonly performed using a serum prostate-specific antigen test every 2 years. Screening can be initiated earlier at 40 years for patients with a first-degree relative who developed early-onset prostate cancer (i.e., before 65 years). This 42-year-old patient with a second-degree relative who developed prostate cancer at the age of 73 years does not require prostate cancer screening at this visit.

There is insufficient evidence to recommend routine screening for osteoporosis in men, but screening can be considered in men with strong risk factors for osteoporosis (e.g., long-term corticosteroid use; androgen deprivation therapy for prostate cancer) and in men ≥ 70 years of age. In this 42-year old man without such risk factors, screening for osteoporosis is not recommended.

question_text: A 30-year-old man comes to a free clinic because of a 2-year history of a growing mass on his back. It is occasionally painful and has discharged malodorous cheeselike material. He has no history of serious illness and receives no medications. He has been unemployed for the past 9 months, and his only source of income comes from unemployment benefits. Examination shows a 1.4-cm, nontender, mobile nodule with a central punctum. A diagnosis of an epidermal inclusion cyst is made, and the patient is recommended to undergo surgical excision. The physician notes that the patient has no health insurance. Which of the following health insurance plans is the most appropriate recommendation for this patient?
content_preview: A 30-year-old man comes to a free clinic because of a 2-year history of a growing mass on his back. It is occasionally painful and has discharged malodorous cheeselike material. He has no history of serious illness and receives no medications. He has been unemployed for the past 9 months, and his only source of income comes from unemployment benefits. Examination shows a 1.4-cm, nontender, mobile nodule with a central punctum. A diagnosis of an epidermal inclusion cyst is made, and the patient is recommended to undergo surgical excision. The physician notes that the patient has no health insurance. Which of the following health insurance plans is the most appropriate recommendation for this patient?
hint: This patient's unemployment status makes him eligible for this health insurance program.
learning_objective: Recognize when a patient is eligible for Medicaid.

answers.explanation_why: A health maintenance organization (HMO) plan consists of a network of doctors, specialists, and hospitals that enrollees must choose from to obtain health care. No coverage is provided for out-of-network doctors, specialists, or hospitals, except in an emergency. Although the costs of an HMO plan are often low, this patient is eligible for another insurance program that can cover all of his medical costs because he is unemployed.

A point of service (POS) plan consists of a network of doctors, specialists, and hospitals that enrollees can choose from to obtain health care. Enrollees have coverage for out-of-network providers, and a referral is needed from the primary care physician to see a specialist. Although the costs of in-network care in a POS plan can be low, this patient is eligible for another insurance program that can cover all of his medical costs because he is unemployed.

An exclusive provider organization (EPO) plan consists of a network of doctors, specialists, and hospitals that enrollees must choose from to get health care. No coverage is provided for out-of-network doctors, specialists, or hospitals, except in an emergency. Enrollees can be seen in-network without a referral from a primary care physician. Although member costs of an EPO plan are often low, this patient is eligible for another insurance program that can cover all of his medical costs because he is unemployed.

Medicare is government-funded health insurance that consists of 4 parts, each of which provide coverage for different services. To be eligible for Medicare, patients must meet one of three criteria: be ≥ 65 years old, have end-stage renal failure or amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or have permanent disabilities (regardless of age). This patient does not meet any of the criteria for Medicare coverage.

A preferred provider organization (PPO) plan consists of a network of doctors, specialists, and hospitals that enrollees can choose from to get health care. PPO enrollees also have coverage for out-of-network providers and can see specialists without a referral from a primary care physician. PPO plans often have high member costs, so a PPO would not be the most appropriate insurance plan for this uninsured patient.

Medicaid is a government-funded health insurance plan that provides comprehensive coverage for hospital care, laboratory tests, diagnostic tests, and doctors visits. To be eligible for Medicaid, patients must be under 65 years of age and meet the income eligibility based on the modified adjusted gross income (MAGI) threshold set by the state's health insurance marketplace. Federal eligibility also extends to pregnant women, children, and individuals receiving supplemental security income. Those who are eligible for Medicaid must be US citizens (or qualify in other ways, e.g., lawful permanent residents) and live in the same state where Medicaid is received. Individual states have the additional option to modify eligibility.
