question_text: A 17-year-old primigravid girl at 30 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a routine prenatal visit. She reports some tiredness but has otherwise been well. She has attended all of her prenatal screening appointments so far, which showed no abnormalities. Immunizations are up-to-date. She takes prenatal supplements. She has no history of serious illness and takes no other medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a fundal height consistent with a 30-week gestation. Just before leaving the consulting room, she mentions that she does not intend to come for any more prenatal appointments because she lives too far away. The patient should be counseled that refusing further prenatal screening increases the risk of which of the following complications?
content_preview: A 17-year-old primigravid girl at 30 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a routine prenatal visit. She reports some tiredness but has otherwise been well. She has attended all of her prenatal screening appointments so far, which showed no abnormalities. Immunizations are up-to-date. She takes prenatal supplements. She has no history of serious illness and takes no other medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a fundal height consistent with a 30-week gestation. Just before leaving the consulting room, she mentions that she does not intend to come for any more prenatal appointments because she lives too far away. The patient should be counseled that refusing further prenatal screening increases the risk of which of the following complications?
hint: Think about the prenatal screening tests that women usually undergo after 30 weeks' gestation.
learning_objective: Recognize the importance of prenatal screening for Group B streptococcus, and choose the appropriate intervention to reduce the risk of neonatal sepsis.

answers.explanation_why: Myelomeningocele is a type of neural tube defect (NTD), which is the most common congenital malformation of the central nervous system. Prenatal screening for NTDs includes measurement of maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein at 16–18 weeks' gestation or ultrasound examination between 18–20 weeks' gestation. Since this patient is at 30 weeks of gestation and all of her previous prenatal visits were normal, discontinuing prenatal checkups now will not increase the risk of myelomeningocele.

Fetal macrosomia can result from maternal gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM). All pregnant women are initially screened for GDM with an oral glucose challenge test between 24–28 weeks of gestation. Since this patient is currently at 30 weeks' gestation and all of her previous prenatal visits were normal, the likelihood of her having GDM is very low. Therefore, discontinuing further prenatal care is unlikely to increase the risk of macrosomia in this fetus.

Congenital rubella syndrome is caused by the transplacental transfer of the rubella virus from an infected mother to her fetus. All pregnant women (unless there is evidence of immunity) are screened for rubella antibodies at the initial prenatal visit. Since this patient's immunizations are up to date and all of her previous prenatal visits showed no abnormalities, discontinuing further prenatal visits after 30 weeks of gestation is unlikely to increase the risk of congenital rubella infection.

Neonatal sepsis can result from infection with Group B streptococcus (GBS), which colonizes the maternal genital tract in 15–40% of pregnant women. Transmission to the fetus can occur after the rupture of membranes or during labor (i.e., passage through the birth canal). Therefore, prenatal screening for GBS is performed in all pregnant women between 36 0/7 and 37 6/7 weeks of gestation via culture and gram staining of vaginal and rectal swabs. If this patient refuses further prenatal screening after 30 weeks' gestation, she will not be screened for GBS, thus increasing her child's risk of neonatal sepsis. Moreover, GBS can lead to urinary tract infections, cystitis, pyelonephritis, and chorioamnionitis during pregnancy, all of which can be avoided by screening and treatment. Patients with a positive screening test for GBS should receive intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis with IV penicillin G or ampicillin.

Hemolytic disease of the fetus and newborn (HDFN) most commonly results from a Rhesus (Rh) or ABO incompatibility between the mother and fetus. Rh incompatibility is more likely to cause severe symptoms in the newborn. Therefore, screening Rh-negative mothers for anti-D antibodies takes place at the initial prenatal visit with further anti-D antibody testing at 28 weeks' gestation. Since this patient is already at 30 weeks of gestation and all of her previous prenatal visits showed no abnormalities, discontinuing prenatal visits at this point would not increase the risk of HDFN.

question_text: A 28-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 5-day history of a painful rash in the genital area. She also developed mild nausea and decreased appetite during the last 4 weeks. She has not seen a physician in several years; her immunization records are unavailable. Her menstrual cycle is irregular, and she does not recall when her last menstrual period was. She drinks two to three beers daily and occasionally smokes cigarettes. She has several male sexual partners and uses condoms inconsistently. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 71/min, and blood pressure is 112/70 mm Hg. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 79 kg (174 lb); BMI is 28 kg/m^2. Pelvic examination shows a group of small vesicles on an erythematous base over the labia majora and minora with tender, bilateral inguinal lymphadenopathy. A urine pregnancy test is positive. Ultrasonography discloses an intrauterine pregnancy consistent with 14 weeks' gestation with no detectable heartbeat. The fetal cranial vault is absent, there is no visible brain tissue, and there is mild polyhydramnios. Which of the following is most likely to have prevented the defect in this fetus?
content_preview: A 28-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 5-day history of a painful rash in the genital area. She also developed mild nausea and decreased appetite during the last 4 weeks. She has not seen a physician in several years; her immunization records are unavailable. Her menstrual cycle is irregular, and she does not recall when her last menstrual period was. She drinks two to three beers daily and occasionally smokes cigarettes. She has several male sexual partners and uses condoms inconsistently. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 71/min, and blood pressure is 112/70 mm Hg. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 79 kg (174 lb); BMI is 28 kg/m2. Pelvic examination shows a group of small vesicles on an erythematous base over the labia majora and minora with tender, bilateral inguinal lymphadenopathy. A urine pregnancy test is positive. Ultrasonography discloses an intrauterine pregnancy consistent with 14 weeks' gestation with no detectable heartbeat. The fetal cranial vault is absent, there is no visible brain tissue, and there is mild polyhydramnios. Which of the following is most likely to have prevented the defect in this fetus?
hint: An absent cranial vault and no visible brain tissue on fetal ultrasonography indicate anencephaly, a neural tube defect (NTD).
learning_objective: Recognize anencephaly as a neural tube defect, and choose the appropriate prenatal intervention to prevent this condition.

answers.explanation_why: Maternal alcohol consumption during pregnancy can lead to teratogenic damage in the fetus and cause fetal alcohol syndrome (FAS). FAS is associated with certain central nervous system abnormalities, such as microcephaly and holoprosencephaly, but it does not cause NTDs.

Maternal smoking during pregnancy is associated with intrauterine growth restriction, stillbirth, and congenital malformations (e.g., cleft lip, gastroschisis, anal atresia, cardiac defects, renal hypoplasia). Although smoking is associated with a slight increase in the risk of NTDs, another cause is more likely responsible for the anencephaly seen in this fetus.

Folate is an essential coenzyme required for DNA synthesis and cell division. In the setting of increased metabolic demand from pregnancy, folate supplementation is often necessary to prevent deficiency, which can result in NTDs (e.g., spina bifida, meningomyelocele, encephalocele, anencephaly). This patient's lack of prenatal care resulted in folate deficiency and subsequent fetal anencephaly. The United States Preventive Services Task Force recommends daily supplementation of 0.4–0.8 mg oral folic acid for all individuals capable of pregnancy for at least ≥ 4 weeks before trying to conceive, and supplementation should be continued until 12 weeks' gestation.

Acyclovir therapy is used to treat genital herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection, which typically manifests with painful genital vesicles and tender inguinal lymphadenopathy, both of which are seen in this patient. Acyclovir therapy also prevents vertical transmission of HSV. Though congenital HSV infection can manifest with central nervous system defects, such as microcephaly and hydrocephalus, it does not cause NTDs, including anencephaly.

Penicillin therapy is used to treat syphilis, which typically manifests with genital lesions, lymphadenopathy, and mild fever. This patient's history of multiple sexual partners with inconsistent condom use increases her risk of syphilis. However, the genital lesions and lymphadenopathy associated with syphilis are painless. In addition, congenital syphilis typically manifests with hepatomegaly, placentomegaly, and polyhydramnios on fetal ultrasonography; it is not associated with NTDs.

question_text: A 17-year-old boy comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of frequent and painful urination and urethral discharge. He has not had scrotal pain or swelling. He has no history of similar symptoms. He is sexually active with one male partner, who is the same age, and uses condoms inconsistently. He is in his junior year at a local high school and lives with his parents and his older sister. Vital signs are within normal limits. Genitourinary examination shows yellow-green urethral discharge. The testes are symmetrical without tenderness or masses. A diagnosis of gonococcal infection is made. The patient requests treatment. The physician informs the patient that antibiotic therapy will be necessary. He encourages the patient to talk to his parents, but the patient says that he does not wish to inform them about the infection. When the physician asks the patient about his reasons for not wanting to do so, the patient says “They don't even know about my boyfriend and would be extremely angry if they found out. Would you be able to prescribe me antibiotics without informing my parents?” Which of the following is the most appropriate response by the physician?
content_preview: A 17-year-old boy comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of frequent and painful urination and urethral discharge. He has not had scrotal pain or swelling. He has no history of similar symptoms. He is sexually active with one male partner, who is the same age, and uses condoms inconsistently. He is in his junior year at a local high school and lives with his parents and his older sister. Vital signs are within normal limits. Genitourinary examination shows yellow-green urethral discharge. The testes are symmetrical without tenderness or masses. A diagnosis of gonococcal infection is made. The patient requests treatment. The physician informs the patient that antibiotic therapy will be necessary. He encourages the patient to talk to his parents, but the patient says that he does not wish to inform them about the infection. When the physician asks the patient about his reasons for not wanting to do so, the patient says “They don't even know about my boyfriend and would be extremely angry if they found out. Would you be able to prescribe me antibiotics without informing my parents?” Which of the following is the most appropriate response by the physician?
hint: In the United States, adolescents are able to provide consent for the treatment of sexually transmitted infections (STIs).
learning_objective: Recognize adolescents' rights to consent for STI treatment and confidentiality, and choose the appropriate management for gonococcal infection.

answers.content: "I can prescribe you antibiotics without informing your parents, but they can still legally request records about your diagnosis."
answers.explanation_why: This patient's information is confidential and should not be shared with his parents unless he gives consent. Informing this patient's parents without his consent would constitute a breach of confidentiality.

answers.content: "I can prescribe you antibiotics without informing your parents only if you are legally emancipated."
answers.explanation_why: Laws regarding consent in adolescent health care differ by state, but all states allow minors to consent to the evaluation and management of STIs; legal emancipation is not required.

answers.content: "I can prescribe you antibiotics without informing your parents, but I am obligated to inform your partner of your diagnosis."
answers.explanation_why: Laws regarding consent in adolescent health care differ by state, but all states allow minors to consent to the evaluation and management of STIs; parental consent is not required. Furthermore, all individuals who have had sexual contact with patients diagnosed with Neisseria gonorrhea in the 60 days preceding the diagnosis should be evaluated and treated. However, these individuals should be notified via a public health official or by the index patient, not by the physician. In most states, expedited partner therapy for gonococcal infection treatment is allowed to facilitate partner management and prevent further infection.

answers.content: "I can prescribe you antibiotics only if one of your parents consents."
answers.explanation_why: Laws regarding consent in adolescent health care differ by state, but all states allow minors to consent to the evaluation and management of STIs. Thus, parental consent is not required. Informing this patient's parents without his consent would constitute a breach of confidentiality.

answers.content: "I can prescribe you antibiotics without informing your parents, and I recommend that your partner get tested."
answers.explanation_why:
Laws regarding consent in adolescent health care differ by state, but all states allow minors to consent to the evaluation and management of addiction and care related to sexual behavior (e.g., STIs, contraception, pregnancy); parental consent is not required. This patient does not want his parents to know that he is sexually active or has an STI. Accordingly, the physician is ethically and legally obliged to keep his medical information confidential from his parents (although minors should, in general, be counseled to have open discussions about health with their parents or legal guardians). However, since Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection is a reportable disease, the physician is required to report the case to a public health official. Ideally, all of the patient's sexual partners within the past 60 days should be informed (either by the patient or by the public health official, but not by the physician!), evaluated for gonococcal infection, and treated if positive. Alternatively, the physician could provide expedited partner therapy (EPT), especially if the likelihood of follow-up is low.

Intramuscular injection of ceftriaxone is used both for targeted and empirical therapy for gonococcal infection. If chlamydial coinfection is present or has not been ruled out, oral doxycycline is added. If EPT is required, a single dose of oral cefixime can be administered instead of ceftriaxone. If chlamydial infection is present or has not been excluded in the patient's partner, doxycycline (preferred) or azithromycin should be added.

question_text:
A 54-year-old man comes to the office as a new patient. He feels well. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus treated with metformin. Routine colonoscopy screening from 2 months ago showed diverticulosis. His maternal aunt died from myocardial infarction at the age of 63 years. He does not smoke cigarettes and drinks three to four 12-oz beers weekly. He is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 70 kg (154 lb); BMI is 24 kg/m^2. His blood pressure is 124/68 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:

Hemoglobin
15.2 g/dL

Leukocyte count
6000/mm^3

Hemoglobin A_1C

6.2%

Serum

Total cholesterol
185 mg/dL

HDL cholesterol
45 mg/dL

LDL cholesterol
122 mg/dL

Triglycerides
140 mg/dL

The patient's estimated 10-year risk of cardiovascular disease is 9.1%. In addition to counseling on lifestyle modifications, which of the following health maintenance recommendations is most appropriate at this time?
content_preview: A 54-year-old man comes to the office as a new patient. He feels well. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus treated with metformin. Routine colonoscopy screening from 2 months ago showed diverticulosis. His maternal aunt died from myocardial infarction at the age of 63 years. He does not smoke cigarettes and drinks three to four 12-oz beers weekly. He is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 70 kg (154 lb); BMI is 24 kg/m2. His blood pressure is 124/68 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 15.2 g/dL Leukocyte count 6000/mm3 Hemoglobin A1C 6.2% Serum Total cholesterol 185 mg/dL HDL cholesterol 45 mg/dL LDL cholesterol 122 mg/dL Triglycerides 140 mg/dL The patient's estimated 10-year risk of cardiovascular disease is 9.1%. In addition to counseling on lifestyle modifications, which of the following health maintenance recommendations is most appropriate at this time?
hint: This patient with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) and an intermediate atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease risk (7.5%–20%) requires intervention for primary prevention of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD).
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate health maintenance recommendation for primary prevention of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus.

answers.explanation_why: Low-dose aspirin therapy is indicated for patients who have ASCVD (for secondary prevention) and can be considered for patients aged 40–59 years with a 10-year ASCVD risk ≥ 10% and a low risk of bleeding (for primary prevention). At this time, a different drug should be prescribed for this patient who does not yet have ASCVD but has an estimated 10-year ASCVD risk of 9.1%.

The indications for statins for primary prevention of ASCVD vary slightly between guidelines. The American College of Cardiology (ACC) and the American Heart Association (AHA) recommend initiating statin therapy (e.g., atorvastatin, rosuvastatin) in patients 40–75 years of age with T2DM regardless of their 10-year ASCVD risk. The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) considers it beneficial to initiate statin therapy in patients with ≥ 1 modifiable traditional ASCVD risk factor (e.g., diabetes) and a 10-year ASCVD risk of ≥ 7.5%. According to both guidelines, there is a benefit to initiating statin therapy in this patient. See the “Indications for statins for primary ASCVD prevention” table.

For reference, see the 2019 ACC/AHA guidelines https://www.ahajournals.org/doi/10.1161/CIR.0000000000000678 and the USPSTF recommendations https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/2795521.

Dapagliflozin is an oral antidiabetic agent that can be added to the drug regimen of a patient with T2DM if monotherapy with metformin has not achieved the HbA_1C target of < 7%. This patient, however, has good glycemic control (HbA_1C of 6.2%) on metformin alone and, thus, does not require a second antidiabetic drug.
Patients 40–75 years of age with T2DM and a 10-year ASCVD risk ≥ 7.5% should be prescribed a specific drug for health maintenance.

Niacin is used in the treatment of hypertriglyceridemia, which this patient does not have. In addition, niacin should be avoided in patients with diabetes since it can negatively impact glycemic control. A different drug should be prescribed to this patient.

Ezetimibe is a second-line lipid-lowering agent that can be used for additional ASCVD risk reduction in patients who do not achieve target LDL reduction with the maximally tolerated dose of first-line therapy. This patient's LDL cholesterol is within the reference range.

question_text: A 47-year-old man returns to the office for a follow-up appointment 1 week after he was evaluated for high blood pressure. He works as an investment banker. He says, “I am married to my work” and does not have time for regular physical activity. He mostly orders take-out and fast food. He does not smoke cigarettes or use illicit drugs. He drinks two to three 12-oz beers daily. He has no personal or family history of serious illness and takes no medications. He is 186 cm (6 ft 1 in) tall and weighs 84 kg (185 lb); BMI is 24 kg/m^2. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.2°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 143/87 mm Hg in the right arm and 140/90 mm Hg in the left arm. The patient says that he wants to avoid medication and asks which single lifestyle modification would most effectively lower his blood pressure. Which of the following is the most appropriate response by the physician?
content_preview: A 47-year-old man returns to the office for a follow-up appointment 1 week after he was evaluated for high blood pressure. He works as an investment banker. He says, “I am married to my work” and does not have time for regular physical activity. He mostly orders take-out and fast food. He does not smoke cigarettes or use illicit drugs. He drinks two to three 12-oz beers daily. He has no personal or family history of serious illness and takes no medications. He is 186 cm (6 ft 1 in) tall and weighs 84 kg (185 lb); BMI is 24 kg/m2. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.2°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 143/87 mm Hg in the right arm and 140/90 mm Hg in the left arm. The patient says that he wants to avoid medication and asks which single lifestyle modification would most effectively lower his blood pressure. Which of the following is the most appropriate response by the physician?
learning_objective: Choose the most effective lifestyle modification to lower blood pressure in patients with hypertension.

answers.content: “Lifestyle modifications without pharmacotherapy cannot sufficiently reduce high blood pressure”
answers.explanation_why: Nonpharmacological measures (i.e., lifestyle changes) should be pursued in every patient with a systolic blood pressure > 130 mm Hg or a diastolic blood pressure > 90 mm Hg and have been shown to effectively reduce blood pressure. Lifestyle modifications can be initiated with or without pharmacotherapy, as not all patients with high blood pressure require antihypertensive drugs right away. The decision of whether to initiate pharmacological treatment depends on the patient's blood pressure, comorbidities, and preference. This patient wishes to avoid pharmacological therapy.

answers.content: "Losing approximately 10% of your current body weight would be the most effective measure"
answers.explanation_why: Weight loss is an effective way to reduce blood pressure in overweight and obese patients. Systolic blood pressure is thought to rise in obesity because of peripheral insulin resistance, which results in hyperinsulinemia, triggering increased reabsorption of sodium and fluid. Approximately 1 mm Hg reduction in systolic blood pressure is expected for every 1 kg of weight loss. This patient, however, has a normal body weight and would most likely benefit from a different lifestyle modification at this time.

answers.content: "Reducing your alcohol consumption to a maximum of one drink per day would be the most effective measure"
answers.explanation_why: Decreasing alcohol consumption to a maximum of one drink per day is a healthy lifestyle modification that should be encouraged in all patients. However, moderating alcohol consumption has only been shown to lead to a reduction in systolic blood pressure of up to 4 mm Hg. There are other lifestyle modifications that can result in a more significant reduction.

answers.content: "Reducing your sodium intake to less than 1500 mg per day would be the most effective measure"
answers.explanation_why: Reducing sodium intake to less than 1500 mg per day has been shown to reduce systolic blood pressure by approximately 5–6 mm Hg and could be offered as complementary lifestyle modification. Additionally, a low-sodium diet improves vascular structure and function and may help reduce the risk of gastric cancer, nephrolithiasis, and osteoporosis. However, there are other lifestyle modifications that can result in a more significant reduction of systolic blood pressure.

answers.content: “Adopting a DASH diet would be the most effective measure”
answers.explanation_why:
All patients with newly diagnosed hypertension should implement lifestyle modifications to reduce their blood pressure. The DASH diet has been shown to reduce systolic blood pressure by approximately 11 mm Hg and should be recommended to all patients with hypertension who do not have a balanced diet. The DASH diet has also been shown to reduce levels of LDL cholesterol, which leads to improved cardiovascular health.

See the “Lifestyle changes for managing hypertension” table.

answers.content: "Walking for 30 minutes, 5 days a week would be the most effective measure"
answers.explanation_why: Walking for 30 minutes, 5 days per week has been shown to successfully reduce systolic blood pressure by approximately 5–8 mm Hg, and could be offered to this patient as a complementary therapy. Regular aerobic exercise also has additional health benefits, including the potential to reduce total cholesterol and raise HDL cholesterol as well as reduce mortality due to cardiovascular disease. However, there are other lifestyle modifications that can result in a more significant reduction of systolic blood pressure.

question_text: A 66-year-old man comes to the physician for a health maintenance examination. He feels well. His last visit to the office was 6 years ago. He has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and carotid artery stenosis for which he takes metformin, lisinopril, simvastatin, and aspirin. His father died from an ischemic stroke at the age of 74 years. He smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years but stopped 25 years ago. He drinks two 12-oz beers weekly. Immunizations are up-to-date and a colonoscopy performed 8 years ago was unremarkable. He is 173 cm (5 ft 8 in) tall and weighs 80 kg (176 lb); BMI is 27 kg/m^2. His pulse is 76/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 135/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Screening for which of the following is most appropriate at this time?
content_preview: A 66-year-old man comes to the physician for a health maintenance examination. He feels well. His last visit to the office was 6 years ago. He has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and carotid artery stenosis for which he takes metformin, lisinopril, simvastatin, and aspirin. His father died from an ischemic stroke at the age of 74 years. He smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years but stopped 25 years ago. He drinks two 12-oz beers weekly. Immunizations are up-to-date and a colonoscopy performed 8 years ago was unremarkable. He is 173 cm (5 ft 8 in) tall and weighs 80 kg (176 lb); BMI is 27 kg/m2. His pulse is 76/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 135/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Screening for which of the following is most appropriate at this time?
hint: The United States Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommends screening for this condition in men 65–75 years of age who are current or former smokers.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate screening for a 66-year-old former smoker.

answers.explanation_why: The USPSTF recommends screening for colorectal cancer in all asymptomatic adults between 45 and 75 years of age who have an average risk (e.g., no inflammatory bowel disease, no adenomatous polyps, no family history of an inherited cancer syndrome). The previously recommended age to start screening was 50 years. Colonoscopy every 10 years is an appropriate strategy. Because this patient had his last colonoscopy 8 years ago, which was normal, and lacks symptoms suggestive of colorectal cancer (e.g., weight loss, hematochezia), a colonoscopy is not indicated at this time.

This patient's hypertension, history of smoking, and advanced age increase the risk of developing an intracranial aneurysm. However, screening in asymptomatic patients is not indicated in the general population because it is not cost-effective, owing to the prevalence being too low and these aneurysms having a low risk of rupture. Screening may be considered in patients with genetic conditions associated with a higher incidence of intracranial aneurysms (e.g., autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease, Ehlers-Danlos syndrome) and in patients with first-degree relatives with a history of intracranial aneurysms, neither of which is seen here.

The USPSTF recommends annual screening with a low-dose CT scan of the chest in patients 50–80 years of age who have at least a 20 pack-year smoking history and who are current smokers or have stopped within the past 15 years. This patient has a 20 pack-year smoking history, but he stopped smoking 25 years ago. A low-dose CT scan of the chest is, therefore, not recommended at this time.

The USPSTF recommends that men 65–75 years of age who are current or former smokers should receive a one-time screening with ultrasonography for an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). Ultrasonography can determine the presence and size of an aneurysm, as well as the presence of a blood clot in an aneurysm. It is also the modality of choice for monitoring patients with small, asymptomatic AAAs.

The USPSTF recommends osteoporosis screening with bone densitometry scan every 10 years for women aged 65 years or older. Although some suggest a one-time screening for men older than 70 years of age, there is insufficient evidence to suggest that screening is beneficial in younger men. Therefore, screening for osteoporosis is not indicated in this patient.

question_text: A 19-year-old woman comes to the physician for an annual health maintenance examination. She feels well. She has a history of recurrent urinary tract infections. Menses occur at regular 28-day intervals. Her last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago. She is sexually active with her boyfriend. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive. Her mother had ovarian cancer at the age of 52 years. The patient does not drink alcohol or take illicit drugs. Vaccinations are up-to-date. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 72 kg (159 lb); BMI is 26 kg/m^2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate health maintenance recommendation at this time?
content_preview: A 19-year-old woman comes to the physician for an annual health maintenance examination. She feels well. She has a history of recurrent urinary tract infections. Menses occur at regular 28-day intervals. Her last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago. She is sexually active with her boyfriend. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive. Her mother had ovarian cancer at the age of 52 years. The patient does not drink alcohol or take illicit drugs. Vaccinations are up-to-date. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 72 kg (159 lb); BMI is 26 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate health maintenance recommendation at this time?
hint: The United States Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommends screening for a condition that is common in sexually active women < 25 years of age.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate health maintenance recommendation for sexually active women under 25 years of age.

answers.explanation_why: This woman meets the criteria identified by the USPSTF for the screening of a condition that is common among individuals in her age group and should receive testing at this time.

In asymptomatic patients, urine culture is only recommended by the USPSTF for the screening of asymptomatic bacteriuria in pregnant individuals. Asymptomatic bacteriuria does not usually result in symptomatic infection, so the USPSTF recommends against this screening in nonpregnant adults. Screening may result in overtreatment, increasing the risk of patients developing adverse effects from antibiotic therapy and raising the risk of emergence of antibiotic-resistant bacteria.

Serum CA-125 concentration can be used in the evaluation of a patient with an adnexal mass or to monitor disease progression or recurrence of treatment in patients with ovarian cancer. Although this patient has a first-degree relative with ovarian cancer, which thereby increases her risk of developing ovarian cancer, serum CA-125 concentration measurement is not recommended for screening of ovarian cancer in asymptomatic patients. Patients with a high-risk family history should rather be referred to genetic counseling.

The USPSTF recommends cervical cancer screening with high-risk HPV testing (hrHPV test) every 5 years in all women > 30 years of age; the American Cancer Society recommends primary HPV testing every 5 years for women 25–65 years of age. In young women, HPV infections tend to be transient and resolve without treatment, and testing in this age group results in a considerable false-positive rate, which can lead to unnecessary invasive procedures (e.g., cervical biopsy, loop excision, conization). In women younger than 21 years old, such as this patient, the USPSTF recommends against cervical cancer screening as the harms outweigh the benefits.

answers.content: Perform nucleic acid amplification testing for chlamydia and gonorrhea
answers.explanation_why: The USPSTF recommends screening for N. gonorrhoeae and C. trachomatis infections in all sexually active women < 25 years of age and in women ≥ 25 years of age with specific risk factors (e.g., women with new or multiple sex partners). N. gonorrhoeae and C. trachomatis infections are often asymptomatic in women but can result in complications such as pelvic inflammatory disease and infertility. Screening consists of nucleic acid amplification tests of the urine, which have both high sensitivity and specificity for these infections. Although there is not a defined screening interval, it is reasonable to annually repeat the screening in women with new or persistent risk factors.

The USPSTF recommends cervical cancer screening by PAP smear every 3 years for all women between 21 and 65 years of age. In women younger than 21 years old, such as this patient, cervical cancer is rare and screening might result in false-positive results, which may lead to unnecessary invasive procedures (e.g., cervical biopsy, loop excision, conization). Some of these procedures increase the risk of adverse pregnancy outcomes (e.g., preterm delivery). Because evidence shows that the harms of cervical cancer screening in women younger than 21 years of age outweigh the benefits, the USPSTF recommends against screening in this age group.

question_text:
A 65-year-old woman comes to the physician because of painless reddening and swelling of her right foot. The swelling of the foot started several months ago, but the redness along with warmth only appeared last week, after a strenuous hike with her husband. She does not recall any recent trauma, fever, or chills. She has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Her mother had rheumatoid arthritis. Current medications include metformin, losartan, and atorvastatin. She has not seen a physician for 1 year. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 78/min, and blood pressure is 144/80 mm Hg. Examination shows a severely swollen, erythematous, right foot and ankle with collapse of the midfoot; range of motion is decreased but not painful. There is no focal tenderness. Peripheral pulses are palpable. Sensation to pinprick, light touch, and vibration is decreased over the soles of both feet. Laboratory studies show:

Hemoglobin
14.1 g/dL

Leukocyte count
9500/mm^3

Erythrocyte sedimentation rate
22 mm/h

Serum

 Glucose

135 mg/dL

 Uric acid
4.5 mg/dL

An x-ray of the right foot is shown. Which of the following measures is most likely to have prevented this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 65-year-old woman comes to the physician because of painless reddening and swelling of her right foot. The swelling of the foot started several months ago, but the redness along with warmth only appeared last week, after a strenuous hike with her husband. She does not recall any recent trauma, fever, or chills. She has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Her mother had rheumatoid arthritis. Current medications include metformin, losartan, and atorvastatin. She has not seen a physician for 1 year. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 78/min, and blood pressure is 144/80 mm Hg. Examination shows a severely swollen, erythematous, right foot and ankle with collapse of the midfoot; range of motion is decreased but not painful. There is no focal tenderness. Peripheral pulses are palpable. Sensation to pinprick, light touch, and vibration is decreased over the soles of both feet. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 14.1 g/dL Leukocyte count 9500/mm3 Erythrocyte sedimentation rate 22 mm/h Serum Glucose 135 mg/dL Uric acid 4.5 mg/dL An x-ray of the right foot is shown. Which of the following measures is most likely to have prevented this patient's condition?
hint: The x-ray shows deformity, malalignment, and severe degenerative changes of the second and third metatarsal heads. These findings, in conjunction with unilateral, painless swelling of the foot and symmetrical decreased sensation in the distal lower extremities in a patient with diabetes mellitus suggest diabetic neuropathic arthropathy, also known as Charcot foot.
learning_objective: Recognize diabetic neuropathic arthropathy, and choose the most effective measure to prevent this condition.

answers.explanation_why: Smoking is a known risk factor for rheumatoid arthritis (RA), which can manifest with recurrent joint swelling, decreased range of motion, and joint deformities. This patient's positive family history is also a risk factor for developing RA. However, RA typically manifests with symmetrical pain and swelling of metacarpophalangeal and/or proximal interphalangeal joints; unilateral involvement of foot joints is very rare. Furthermore, patients with RA typically have an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate.

Diabetes mellitus is often complicated by vascular and neuropathic changes that most commonly affect the distal extremities. These changes are an important cause of morbidity in patients with diabetes because they usually result in complications like diabetic foot ulcers and foot deformities, including Charcot foot. Regular foot examination should be routinely performed on every patient with diabetes to assess for possible complications (e.g., ulcers, deformities) or possible risk factors for complications (e.g., poor nail care, infections, calluses, inappropriate footwear) and must include inspection, monofilament testing, and assessment of pedal pulses. Regular monofilament testing allows the early detection of diabetic neuropathy and thereby reduces the likelihood of further complications.

Calcium and vitamin D supplementation might be indicated for osteoporosis prophylaxis, especially in postmenopausal women and older adults, such as this patient. However, calcium and vitamin D supplementation has no role in the prevention of diabetic arthropathy.

Reducing meat intake is one of the measures to prevent an acute gout flare, which can manifest with redness, swelling, warmth, and decreased range of motion of the affected joint. Furthermore, recurrent gout attacks can result in chronic gouty arthritis, in which degenerative changes similar to those in this patient can be seen on x-ray. However, acute gout flares are typically accompanied by severe acute pain, and affected individuals typically have elevated serum uric acid levels. Moreover, this patient has no history of recurrent gouty arthritis.

Prophylactic antibiotic therapy is indicated in recurrent cellulitis, which can manifest with tissue swelling, erythema, and warmth. This patient has type 2 diabetes mellitus, which is a known risk factor for recurrent cellulitis. However, cellulitis is associated with pain, tenderness, systemic symptoms (e.g., fever, malaise), and leukocytosis. Moreover, this patient has no history of episodes of cellulitis.

images.title: Diabetic neuropathic arthropathy
images.description: X-ray forefoot (dorsoplantar view) of a patient with diabetes mellitusThere is marked deformity of the second metatarsal head and malalignment at the second and third metatarsal-phalangeal (MTP; green circle) and interphalangeal (IP) joints. The proximal phalanges show lateral subluxation. Additional findings include metatarsus varus and hallux valgus with bunion formation (arrow).

question_text: A 39-year-old woman comes to the physician for a regular health checkup 1 year after establishing care at the office. She feels well. She has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and coronary heart disease. Her current medication includes metformin, enalapril, and aspirin. She has brought laboratory results from a screening examination performed 2 weeks ago prior to donating blood. Laboratory studies from the blood bank show a nonreactive HIV-1/2 combination immunoassay and a nonreactive HIV-1/2 antibody differentiation immunoassay. While reviewing the patient's chart, the physician notices that an HIV-1/2 combination immunoassay, which was performed at last year's office visit by a colleague, was reactive. During the consultation, the physician realizes that the patient is not aware of the results of the HIV test that was performed a year ago. Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the physician?
content_preview: A 39-year-old woman comes to the physician for a regular health checkup 1 year after establishing care at the office. She feels well. She has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and coronary heart disease. Her current medication includes metformin, enalapril, and aspirin. She has brought laboratory results from a screening examination performed 2 weeks ago prior to donating blood. Laboratory studies from the blood bank show a nonreactive HIV-1/2 combination immunoassay and a nonreactive HIV-1/2 antibody differentiation immunoassay. While reviewing the patient's chart, the physician notices that an HIV-1/2 combination immunoassay, which was performed at last year's office visit by a colleague, was reactive. During the consultation, the physician realizes that the patient is not aware of the results of the HIV test that was performed a year ago. Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the physician?
hint: The failure to provide full disclosure in a timely manner constitutes a medical error. The right action in this scenario is grounded in the principles of professional respect and a systems-based approach toward medical error.
learning_objective: Recognize the importance of addressing medical errors through professional communication, and choose the appropriate steps to disclose such errors to the patient.

answers.content: Request that the patient contact the colleague who ordered the initial HIV test
answers.explanation_why: A medical error should be promptly disclosed to the patient, regardless of whether it has caused any immediate harm. The clinician should explain the error and any consequences and allow time for further discussion and questions. Requesting that the patient contact the colleague who ordered the initial HIV test is inappropriate because it would unnecessarily delay patient notification.

answers.content: Speak to the colleague who ordered the initial HIV test
answers.explanation_why:
When a clinician suspects a medical error, they must speak privately and nonjudgmentally with the responsible colleague to determine whether an error occurred and why (e.g., misunderstanding or laboratory error). To help reduce the risk of future errors, the clinician should encourage their colleague to report the incident using standard protocol. Most medical errors are caused by failures in health care systems, and incident reporting can contribute to the identification and improvement of systemic issues. If there is no longer a patient-physician relationship with the colleague, the clinician must comply with HIPAA regulations by initially obtaining the patient’s permission to contact the physician.

Additionally, the clinician should inform the patient of the previous test result and discuss its implications, ensuring transparency and prioritizing care. In this scenario, the patient does not have HIV, and no further testing is needed.

answers.content: Report the colleague who ordered the initial HIV test to the state medical board
answers.explanation_why: The physician should report the colleague directly to the state medical board if the colleague is suspected of committing gross misconduct (e.g., billing fraud, bullying, sexual harassment). At this point, this action is inappropriate.

answers.content: Disclose to the patient that a colleague forgot to follow up on the results of the initial HIV test
answers.explanation_why: It is inappropriate to make assumptions about a colleague's actions. Without investigating, the physician cannot definitively know the reason for the error (e.g., lack of follow-up or laboratory error). A different action is more appropriate.

answers.content: Do not inform the patient since the error did not cause harm
answers.explanation_why: Clinicians must inform patients about a medical error regardless of whether it has caused any immediate harm.

question_text: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother 20 days after a laparoscopic appendectomy because of severe lower abdominal pain. His temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), pulse is 118/min, and respirations are 20/min. Physical examination shows tenderness, erythema, and warmth at the surgical wound, with purulent discharge from the incision. Results of initial wound cultures are pending. The patient is diagnosed with a surgical site infection (SSI) and empiric antibiotic treatment is started. The physician on duty recalls that she saw a different patient with similar symptoms earlier this week, and she decides to look at the hospital statistics for SSI incidence. She notes that at least five patients developed SSI in the pediatric unit during the last month and that all of them received a lower dose of preoperative cefazolin than is recommended by current guidelines. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to prevent recurrence of such a mistake in the future?
content_preview: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother 20 days after a laparoscopic appendectomy because of severe lower abdominal pain. His temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), pulse is 118/min, and respirations are 20/min. Physical examination shows tenderness, erythema, and warmth at the surgical wound, with purulent discharge from the incision. Results of initial wound cultures are pending. The patient is diagnosed with a surgical site infection (SSI) and empiric antibiotic treatment is started. The physician on duty recalls that she saw a different patient with similar symptoms earlier this week, and she decides to look at the hospital statistics for SSI incidence. She notes that at least five patients developed SSI in the pediatric unit during the last month and that all of them received a lower dose of preoperative cefazolin than is recommended by current guidelines. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to prevent recurrence of such a mistake in the future?
hint: A retrospective method of error analysis would help identify the cause of the medical error and help prevent future recurrence.
learning_objective: Recognize the role of root cause analysis in preventing recurrence of medical errors.

answers.explanation_why: A multilayered safety system, which references the Swiss cheese model, can help prevent potential mistakes by ensuring that if a hazard passes through a safeguard (hole), a subsequent layer (slice of cheese) can prevent its further passage through the system. In this case, the error has already occurred. A retrospective review is needed to first identify the cause to evaluate how a multilayered safety system should be structured or if it is even appropriate in this scenario.

A root cause analysis (RCA) is a retrospective method that has the goal to prevent the recurrence of medical errors. The first step of this method is the identification of the medical error (e.g., lower dose of preoperative cefazolin administered than is recommended by current guidelines), followed by the investigation of individual factors (sharp-end errors) and systemic factors (blunt-end errors) that contributed to the error (e.g., through a fishbone diagram of causes leading to patients developing SSI). After this, possible measures for the prevention (e.g., staff education on new policies) are determined. The final step in an RCA is the implementation of these measures.

A retrospective cohort study is used to investigate the association between exposure and outcome and to calculate the relative risk of exposure. In this case, the association between the exposure (receiving a lower dose of preoperative antibiotics) and the outcome (SSI) could be studied retrospectively in two cohorts (i.e., exposed and not exposed). This analysis would help determine whether there is an association between receiving low dose antibiotics and developing an SSI, and could be an important step in evaluating what went wrong. However, this method does not address the question of how to prevent similar errors in the future, so a different analysis would be more appropriate.

answers.content: Perform a failure mode and effects analysis
answers.explanation_why: A failure mode and effects analysis (FMEA) can help prevent future mistakes from occurring, but this is a prospective method (i.e., has the goal of anticipating potential future risks). In this case, the medical error has already occurred, so a prospective analysis would not be appropriate.

question_text: A group of emergency medicine residents has recently submitted a proposal to the hospital's board of physicians to replace their paging system with smartphones for internal communication. The residents have experienced multiple technical issues with their pagers during the last 6 months that resulted in miscommunication and delays in patient care. They find this unacceptable in such a fast-paced environment as the emergency department. After reviewing the proposal, the chairperson opens a discussion on the topic during one of the hospital's management meetings. Several members of the committee raise their concerns regarding potential security and privacy breaches. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to evaluate the potential risks of this initiative?
content_preview: A group of emergency medicine residents has recently submitted a proposal to the hospital's board of physicians to replace their paging system with smartphones for internal communication. The residents have experienced multiple technical issues with their pagers during the last 6 months that resulted in miscommunication and delays in patient care. They find this unacceptable in such a fast-paced environment as the emergency department. After reviewing the proposal, the chairperson opens a discussion on the topic during one of the hospital's management meetings. Several members of the committee raise their concerns regarding potential security and privacy breaches. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to evaluate the potential risks of this initiative?
hint: A prospective method of analysis would help identify the possible benefits and risks of this initiative.
learning_objective: Recognize the use of failure mode and effects analysis to evaluate potential risks of healthcare initiatives.

answers.content: Plan a randomized controlled trial with residents
answers.explanation_why: A randomized controlled trial (RCT) is a prospective, experimental, analytical study to determine the effect of an intervention on a given population. In this scenario, an RCT would likely require half the doctors to use pagers and the other half to use smartphones. The outcomes on patient care and medical error would then be compared in the two groups. RCTs are considered the gold standard for clinical trials. However, RCTs are costly and time-consuming. Additionally, RCTs involve the practical implementation of an intervention that could potentially be harmful to the patient. This study design would therefore expose patients to the real risks of a smartphone system, and not just evaluate for potential risks.

A root cause analysis is a retrospective analysis and only analyzes medical errors that have already taken place. Since the smartphone system still needs to be implemented, a root cause analysis would not be beneficial in assessing the potential benefits and risks of such a system. This analysis could be used to assist in analyzing the current paging system's technical issues and the resulting miscommunication and delays in patient care. The results of the root cause analysis can then be used to plan interventions to address specific problems within the paging system.

answers.content: Perform a systematic review of smartphone use in hospitals
answers.explanation_why: A systematic review (SR) provides a detailed and qualitative assessment of a specific question by reviewing the results of multiple studies. This analysis could be done to review the results of previous studies of smartphone systems in hospitals. However, an SR would not provide the benefit of assessing this hospital's situation specifically. Moreover, limited good-quality studies might be available to perform a comprehensive review. An SR would therefore not be the best method to assess the risks and benefits of a smartphone system for this hospital.

answers.content: Perform a failure mode and effects analysis
answers.explanation_why: A failure mode and effects analysis (FMEA) is a prospective medical error analysis used to evaluate the potential risks and failures of an initiative, and the impact that these failures might have. In this specific scenario, an FMEA would explore any potential security and privacy breaches that might take place when using smartphones for internal communication (failure mode). After that, the reasons for failure (failure causes) and the outcomes of potential failures (failure effects) would be identified. An additional benefit of an FMEA is that it would aid in the design of measures to prevent these breaches from occurring, should the new smartphone system be implemented.

question_text: A 53-year-old woman comes to the office to establish care after moving to the area from a different state with her husband and 3 children. She has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), hypertension, and constipation. Her current medication includes valsartan, salmeterol, and a fiber supplement for constipation. She entered menopause last year. Four years ago, she underwent hemorrhoidectomy; a sigmoidoscopy at that time showed no abnormalities. Her mother died of breast cancer at the age of 66 years; the patient's last mammogram from 6 months ago was normal. Her last primary HPV test taken 3 years ago was negative. She does not drink alcohol. She smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years but quit 8 years ago when she was diagnosed with COPD. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows varicose veins in the lower extremities. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable for her age. Which of the following screening studies is most appropriate at this time?
content_preview: A 53-year-old woman comes to the office to establish care after moving to the area from a different state with her husband and 3 children. She has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), hypertension, and constipation. Her current medication includes valsartan, salmeterol, and a fiber supplement for constipation. She entered menopause last year. Four years ago, she underwent hemorrhoidectomy; a sigmoidoscopy at that time showed no abnormalities. Her mother died of breast cancer at the age of 66 years; the patient's last mammogram from 6 months ago was normal. Her last primary HPV test taken 3 years ago was negative. She does not drink alcohol. She smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years but quit 8 years ago when she was diagnosed with COPD. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows varicose veins in the lower extremities. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable for her age. Which of the following screening studies is most appropriate at this time?
hint: This screening study is recommended by the United States Preventative Services Task Force (USPSTF) in adults aged 50 to 80 years.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate screening study for lung cancer in a former smoker with a significant smoking history.

answers.content: Low-dose CT scan of the chest
answers.explanation_why:
Annual low-dose CT scan of the chest is indicated for lung cancer screening in adults aged 50 to 80 years who have a smoking history ≥ 20 pack years. Screening recommendations for former smokers vary. Although the American Cancer Society supports screening regardless of time since last smoked, some organizations (e.g., USPSTF) recommend limiting screening to individuals who have smoked within the past 15 years.

See “Screening for cancer” and “Screening recommendations for nonpregnant women by age” tables.

The USPSTF recommends screening for colorectal cancer in all asymptomatic adults between 45 and 75 years of age who have an average risk (e.g., no inflammatory bowel disease, adenomatous polyps, or family history of an inherited cancer syndrome). The previously recommended age to start screening was 50 years. Sigmoidoscopy every 5 years is an appropriate strategy. Because this patient had her last sigmoidoscopy 4 years ago, which was normal, and lacks symptoms suggestive of colorectal cancer (e.g., weight loss, hematochezia), sigmoidoscopy is not indicated at this time.

Mammography is indicated for the screening of breast cancer in women aged 40–74 years. According to the latest 2024 USPSTF recommendation, mammography should be repeated every 2 years. This patient had a mammogram 6 months ago with normal findings and does not require any further testing right now.

According to the USPSTF recommendation, Pap smear is indicated for the screening of cervical cancer in women aged 21 to 65 years. Pap smear should be performed every 3 years if done alone, or every 5 years when performed as co-testing. Alternatively, in patients aged 30 to 65 years, the FDA-approved primary HPV tests performed every 5 years are sufficient for cervical cancer screening. This patient had HPV testing 3 years ago and does not require any further testing at this time.

Abdominal ultrasonography is used to screen for abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) and is recommended in men 65–75 years of age who have a smoking history. Screening can also be considered in women 65–75 years of age who have a smoking history, in individuals < 65 years of age with multiple risk factors for AAA and/or a family history of AAA, and in individuals 65–75 years of age with a positive family history for AAA in a first-degree relative. Based on this patient's sex, age, and risk factors, screening for a different condition with another modality is indicated at this time.

question_text: Three days after admission to the intensive care unit for treatment of major trauma sustained during a motor vehicle accident, a 65-year-old woman develops respiratory distress. She has hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Preadmission medications include candesartan, salmeterol, budesonide, and pravastatin. Upon admission, she was intubated and mechanically ventilated because she was unconscious. Over the past 12 hours, her end-expiratory airway pressure was increased to ensure adequate oxygenation. Her current temperature is 39.1°C (102.4°F), pulse is 114/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 140/92 mm Hg. An x-ray of the chest shows new alveolar infiltrates and air bronchograms in the right lower lobe. Which of the following measures is most likely to have prevented this patient's current condition?
content_preview: Three days after admission to the intensive care unit for treatment of major trauma sustained during a motor vehicle accident, a 65-year-old woman develops respiratory distress. She has hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Preadmission medications include candesartan, salmeterol, budesonide, and pravastatin. Upon admission, she was intubated and mechanically ventilated because she was unconscious. Over the past 12 hours, her end-expiratory airway pressure was increased to ensure adequate oxygenation. Her current temperature is 39.1°C (102.4°F), pulse is 114/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 140/92 mm Hg. An x-ray of the chest shows new alveolar infiltrates and air bronchograms in the right lower lobe. Which of the following measures is most likely to have prevented this patient's current condition?
hint: Tachycardia, tachypnea, fever, and new infiltrates on chest x-ray after being intubated for more than 48 hours indicate ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), which is most often caused by microaspiration of bacterial flora from the oral cavity or stomach.
learning_objective: Recognize ventilator-associated pneumonia, and choose the most effective measure to prevent this condition.

answers.explanation_why: Routine oropharyngeal and subglottic suctioning prevents the pooling of secretions above the endotracheal tube cuff. Avoiding routine oropharyngeal suctioning would increase rather than decrease the risk of VAP.

Biofilms of bacteria can adhere to the ventilator circuit and lead to VAP. Therefore, a change in the ventilator circuit is recommended if it is visibly soiled, malfunctioning, or if a new patient is ventilated. However, frequent changes of the ventilator circuit for the same patient increase rather than decrease the risk of VAP because manipulation of the ventilator circuit increases the risk of microaspiration of subglottic secretions.

Sedatives are used in mechanically ventilated patients to relieve discomfort and anxiety and, if a spontaneous ventilatory mode is unavailable, to prevent complications arising from patient-ventilator asynchrony. However, excessive sedation impairs the patient's airway protective reflexes and allows oropharyngeal secretions or gastric reflux to pass beyond the glottis. In intubated patients, these collections can pool in the subglottic region and drain around the endotracheal tube cuff, as microaspirates, into the lower respiratory tract. Using sedation assessment tools and daily titration of the patient's depth of sedation to the minimum necessary level (sedation vacation) can prevent the subglottic pooling of secretions and subsequent VAP. Sedation vacations also prevent VAP by facilitating spontaneous breathing trials and early ventilator weaning.

VAP can also be prevented by measures that decrease oropharyngeal or gastrointestinal bacterial colonization (e.g., oral chlorhexidine rinses, avoiding unnecessary acid suppression therapy), decrease subglottic pooling (e.g., oropharyngeal and subglottic suctioning, semirecumbent positioning of the patient), and decrease the risk of microaspiration (e.g., minimizing patient transport, avoiding frequent ventilator circuit changes for the same patient).

answers.content: Avoiding overinflation of the endotracheal tube cuff
answers.explanation_why: Adequate inflation of the endotracheal tube cuff (to a pressure of 20–30 mm H_2O) is required to minimize the risk of VAP. While avoiding overinflation of the endotracheal tube cuff prevents airway injury (e.g., ischemia, ulceration, and necrosis of the tracheal wall), it does not prevent VAP.

answers.content: Starting proton pump inhibitor therapy early
answers.explanation_why: Acid suppression (e.g., proton pump inhibitor) therapy is used for stress ulcer prophylaxis in critically ill patients with certain risk factors (e.g., traumatic brain injury, prolonged mechanical ventilation and/ or stay in intensive care unit). However, acid suppression also promotes bacterial colonization of the gastrointestinal tract, which increases rather than decreases the risk of VAP.

question_text: A 52-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes mellitus is admitted to the hospital for glycemic control. She recently emigrated from Russia. She does not speak English and asks her bilingual adult daughter to translate. Her hemoglobin A_1C is 9.1%. A physician notices that the average hemoglobin A_1C of patients with diabetes mellitus and limited English proficiency in the hospital is significantly higher when compared to patients proficient in English. The hospital conducts an inpatient study, which finds a statistically significant correlation between scores on a standardized verbal English proficiency test and scores on standardized medication adherence scales and patient-physician concordance scales. Based on the results of a subsequent root cause analysis, the hospital management renegotiates health care payment contracts with their insurance provider to allow for reimbursement of professional medical interpreter services. This intervention best addresses which of the following barriers to high-quality health care?
content_preview: A 52-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes mellitus is admitted to the hospital for glycemic control. She recently emigrated from Russia. She does not speak English and asks her bilingual adult daughter to translate. Her hemoglobin A1C is 9.1%. A physician notices that the average hemoglobin A1C of patients with diabetes mellitus and limited English proficiency in the hospital is significantly higher when compared to patients proficient in English. The hospital conducts an inpatient study, which finds a statistically significant correlation between scores on a standardized verbal English proficiency test and scores on standardized medication adherence scales and patient-physician concordance scales. Based on the results of a subsequent root cause analysis, the hospital management renegotiates health care payment contracts with their insurance provider to allow for reimbursement of professional medical interpreter services. This intervention best addresses which of the following barriers to high-quality health care?
hint: The intervention (i.e., resource allocation) for patients with limited English proficiency (LEP) was undertaken by the hospital to prevent poor health outcomes as a result of inequitable access to care.
learning_objective: Recognize the healthcare disparity caused by inequitable allocation of healthcare resources.

answers.explanation_why: Information bias is a systemic research error caused by inconsistencies in measurement and/or classification between sample groups. This bias can be corrected by using standardized data collection techniques. Information bias is not a barrier to high-quality health care in this scenario, and it cannot be addressed by allowing for reimbursement of professional medical interpreter services.

Distributive injustice, a result of inequitable access to care, is a barrier to high-quality health care. Patients with LEP are at high risk of experiencing distributive injustice, which can cause patient-physician discordance and medication nonadherence, as seen here. Allowing for reimbursement of professional medical interpreter services facilitates equitable access to care, which contributes to the correction of distributive injustice.

Health illiteracy, which is primarily due to the complexity of health care information and health care systems, is a barrier to high-quality health care but is distinct from LEP. Patients of all ethnicities, languages, and cultures can be affected by health illiteracy. Conversely, a patient with LEP can have a high level of health literacy in their native language. The use of professional medical interpreter services helps patients with LEP to receive information from health care providers in their native language but it does not address health illiteracy per se since the translated information can still be complex. Simplifying information (e.g., avoiding technical medical jargon, breaking down instructions into simple steps) is an intervention to improve health literacy.

Identity devaluation (i.e., relational injustice) is a barrier to high-quality health care. Patients with LEP may experience identity devaluation due to incorrect assumptions by caregivers (e.g., about the patient's intelligence) or broader cultural incongruities. Identity devaluation can be corrected by systemic changes that increase intercultural understanding, such as hiring more bilingual physicians. Allowing for reimbursement of professional medical interpreter services does not increase intercultural understanding per se because it does not improve health care providers' intercultural competence.

The availability heuristic, a type of cognitive bias, is the tendency to consider past events perceived as significant or readily recalled information as more representative of the truth than events perceived as insignificant or information that comes to mind less promptly. Availability heuristics can be a barrier to high-quality health care because they result in diagnostic errors by health care providers and in medication nonadherence by patients. The availability heuristic is unrelated to a patient's English proficiency, and allowing for reimbursement of professional medical interpreter services will not address this cognitive bias.

question_text: Sixteen hours after admission to the hospital for the treatment of multiple bilateral lower extremity and pelvic fractures sustained during a motor vehicle collision, a 43-year-old woman develops pulseless electrical activity. A code is called and cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) is initiated. Despite several cycles of CPR, the patient dies. A medicolegal autopsy reveals a massive pulmonary embolism and hemorrhage within the pons, thalami, and putamen. A subsequent investigation reveals that, during CPR, a health care provider in the code team administered boluses from a prefilled syringe containing 1:1000 epinephrine, which is used for intramuscular injections in the case of anaphylaxis, instead of the 1:10,000 preparation, which is used for intravenous boluses in the case of cardiac arrest. Which of the following actions at the hospital is most likely to prevent repeat incidents of this medication error?
content_preview: Sixteen hours after admission to the hospital for the treatment of multiple bilateral lower extremity and pelvic fractures sustained during a motor vehicle collision, a 43-year-old woman develops pulseless electrical activity. A code is called and cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) is initiated. Despite several cycles of CPR, the patient dies. A medicolegal autopsy reveals a massive pulmonary embolism and hemorrhage within the pons, thalami, and putamen. A subsequent investigation reveals that, during CPR, a health care provider in the code team administered boluses from a prefilled syringe containing 1:1000 epinephrine, which is used for intramuscular injections in the case of anaphylaxis, instead of the 1:10,000 preparation, which is used for intravenous boluses in the case of cardiac arrest. Which of the following actions at the hospital is most likely to prevent repeat incidents of this medication error?
hint: In this scenario, the medication error occurred at the stage of administration; the patient received the wrong dose via the intravenous route and subsequently suffered a hypertensive intracerebral hemorrhage. The action hierarchy of human factors engineering (HFE) categorizes actions aimed at preventing medical errors into stronger, intermediate, and weaker actions, depending on how much they rely on human effort.
learning_objective: Recognize the use of forcing functions to prevent medication errors.

answers.content: Storing epinephrine preparations for intramuscular injection in autoinjectors
answers.explanation_why:
This action is an example of a forcing function, which is considered a stronger action according to the action hierarchy of HFE. The storage of 1:1000 preparations of epinephrine (only used in anaphylaxis and for intramuscular injection) in epinephrine autoinjectors guarantees the correct route of administration of this highly concentrated epinephrine preparation. This forcing function would have prevented the medication error that resulted in a lethal complication in this scenario (i.e., a never event) by making it impossible to administer this epinephrine preparation via the intravascular route.

Other examples of forcing functions include design features that only allow one health care record to be open on a computerized physician order entry system to prevent wrong-patient errors and providing different hub fits for intravenous injections of high-risk medications (e.g., opiates) to prevent administration of the wrong drug.

images.title: Epinephrine autoinjector
images.description: This epinephrine autoinjector (EpiPen) contains 0.3 mg of epinephrine (1:1000 dilution). It is intended for intramuscular injection into the anterolateral thigh in the case of anaphylaxis.The autoinjector is stored in a carrier tube (not shown in this image). The blue safety release cap requires removing before application. The orange tip is then jabbed firmly into the anterolateral thigh to release the needle (until it clicks) and held in place for 3 seconds to allow the injection to complete.

answers.content: Training medical personnel on the indications for various epinephrine concentrations
answers.explanation_why: Training medical personnel is useful for preventing knowledge deficiency errors. However, error prevention strategies such as training, double checks, and warnings are considered weaker actions according to the action hierarchy of HFE because they rely strongly on human effort for error mitigation and are subject to workarounds.

answers.content: Labeling prefilled epinephrine syringes with the correct indication instead of concentration
answers.explanation_why: This action is an example of a visual cue that could have helped to prevent the medication error in this scenario, since it is easier to distinguish words than concentrations that almost look alike (e.g., 1:1000 can easily be misread as 1:10,000 or vice versa). However, visual cues are considered a weaker to intermediate action according to the action hierarchy of HFE. Moreover, there is more than one indication for 1:10,000 epinephrine (e.g., infusions during septic shock).

answers.content: Creating separate crash carts for cardiac arrest and anaphylaxis
answers.explanation_why: Separate crash carts are often used for children and adults because the size of devices and doses of medication differ for pediatric and adult patients. However, when an emergency code is called, the underlying condition causing the patient's symptoms may not be apparent. Moreover, this error prevention strategy is subject to human error (e.g., picking the wrong cart by accident) and workarounds can easily be found. It also unnecessarily increases the use of resources.

answers.content: Mandating code teams to perform a time-out before epinephrine injections
answers.explanation_why: Time-outs are an example of standardization and double checks that are commonly used before invasive surgeries to prevent never events (e.g., wrong-site surgery). However, this form of error prevention is not appropriate in an emergency setting, since it unnecessarily delays the onset of medical treatment. Moreover, time-outs are considered a weaker to intermediate action according to the action hierarchy of HFE.

answers.content: Initiating disciplinary action against the healthcare provider who committed the error
answers.explanation_why: Active errors by healthcare providers, as seen here, are commonly the result of latent errors in the health care system and punitive actions against an individual are more likely to undermine the safety culture of the organization than rectify the underlying issue. Disciplinary actions (e.g., informing the state medical licensing board or firing the physician) should be pursued in the case of gross misconduct, reckless actions, or repeated violations.
