question_text: A 72-year-old man is admitted to the hospital because of a 1-day history of worsening cough, shortness of breath, and fever. The patient lives with his wife, who was diagnosed with COVID-19 1 week ago. He has no history of major medical illness and takes no medications. His temperature is 38.7°C (101.6°F), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 115/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 91%. A chest x-ray shows bilateral reticular opacities. A reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction of a nasopharyngeal specimen is positive for severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2). Which of the following infection control measures is most appropriate for preventing transmission?
content_preview: A 72-year-old man is admitted to the hospital because of a 1-day history of worsening cough, shortness of breath, and fever. The patient lives with his wife, who was diagnosed with COVID-19 1 week ago. He has no history of major medical illness and takes no medications. His temperature is 38.7°C (101.6°F), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 115/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 91%. A chest x-ray shows bilateral reticular opacities. A reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction of a nasopharyngeal specimen is positive for severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2). Which of the following infection control measures is most appropriate for preventing transmission?
hint: SARS-CoV-2 is most commonly transmitted by exposure to respiratory fluids.
learning_objective: Recognize the appropriate personal protective equipment for preventing SARS-CoV-2 transmission.

answers.content: Wearing a surgical mask within 6 feet of the patient
answers.explanation_why: Droplet precautions, such as wearing a surgical mask within 6 feet of the patient, are used to help prevent the spread of diseases that are transmitted through large particles of respiratory secretions (e.g., SARS-CoV-2). As SARS-CoV-2 can also be transmitted through smaller, aerosolized particles, surgical masks alone do not provide sufficient protection and do not prevent airborne transmission.

Hand hygiene is used to help prevent the transmission of infections. Halogen-releasing agents are sporicidal and are mostly used for surface disinfection. To prevent the spread of SARS-CoV-2, alcohol-based hand rubs (for unsoiled hands) or handwashing with soap and water (for soiled hands) are preferred.

answers.content: Transferring the patient to a positive pressure room
answers.explanation_why: Positive pressure rooms can be used for immunocompromised patients because they help to keep potentially infectious air outside of the room. A ventilation system that creates positive pressure allows air to flow out and prevents contaminated air from entering the room. In order to prevent the transmission of SARS-CoV-2, however, contaminated air should be contained in the patient's room using airborne infection isolation rooms, which provide negative pressure and prevent contaminated air from flowing out.

answers.content: Wearing gloves and gown even if direct contact with the patient is not expected
answers.explanation_why: Wearing gloves and gown even if direct contact with the patient is not expected is part of contact precautions. While gloves and gown are required standard precautions, direct contact with secretions or fomites is not a major mode of transmission of SARS-CoV-2 and an additional measure is more appropriate for prevention.

answers.content: Wearing an N95 respirator when entering the patient's room
answers.explanation_why: COVID-19 is caused by SARS-CoV-2, a virus primarily spread by airborne and droplet transmission. Wearing an N95 respirator when entering a patient's room is part of airborne precautions to prevent transmission. In addition to airborne and standard precautions, which include wearing complete personal protective equipment (i.e., gloves, gown, eye protection), droplet precautions should also be adopted. The patient should be kept in isolation or in patient cohorts and should wear a mask when being transported out of their room.

question_text: A 64-year-old woman comes to the office as a new patient to refill her prescription for hydrocodone. She recently moved to the city. Three years ago, she was diagnosed with shingles and subsequently developed postherpetic neuralgia. She was treated with capsaicin cream, pregabalin, and lamotrigine. She says that none of the medications provided sufficient pain relief until she started taking hydrocodone 1 year ago. Additional medical history is remarkable for major depressive disorder, for which she takes sertraline. She does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 74/min, and blood pressure is 124/82 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Urine immunoassay screening is negative for opioids but positive for benzodiazepines. Upon discussing the results with the patient, she claims that she has not taken any benzodiazepines. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 64-year-old woman comes to the office as a new patient to refill her prescription for hydrocodone. She recently moved to the city. Three years ago, she was diagnosed with shingles and subsequently developed postherpetic neuralgia. She was treated with capsaicin cream, pregabalin, and lamotrigine. She says that none of the medications provided sufficient pain relief until she started taking hydrocodone 1 year ago. Additional medical history is remarkable for major depressive disorder, for which she takes sertraline. She does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 74/min, and blood pressure is 124/82 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Urine immunoassay screening is negative for opioids but positive for benzodiazepines. Upon discussing the results with the patient, she claims that she has not taken any benzodiazepines. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Urine drug screening is performed in all patients who receive chronic opioid therapy to monitor adherence and ensure patient safety. Urine immunoassay (UIA), a qualitative test, is the most commonly used screening method but it has several limitations.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate next step after unexpected urine drug screening results.

answers.explanation_why: Discontinuation of opioid therapy by cross-tapering to a nonopioid pain medication (e.g., naproxen) may be considered if the patient has a substance use disorder that would make concomitant opioid use dangerous or if opioid diversion is suspected. However, a negative result for opioids on UIA alone is insufficient evidence of drug diversion, and conclusions about a substance use disorder cannot be made from UIA alone.

answers.content: Discontinue hydrocodone until the urine drug test is negative for benzodiazepines
answers.explanation_why: Concomitant use of benzodiazepines and opioids can lead to severe CNS and respiratory depression and should generally be avoided. UIA has several limitations, as false positive results for benzodiazepines can occur due to the intake of a drug with a similar structure, such as sertraline. Unexpected results should therefore be discussed with the patient and further investigated before making therapeutic decisions.

UIA has a high incidence of false negatives as it may not reliably identify synthetic (e.g., fentanyl) and semisynthetic opioids (e.g., hydrocodone), and cross-reactivity with other medications and foods can cause false positive results (e.g., sertraline for benzodiazepines, poppy seeds for opioids). Therefore, unexpected results should be discussed with the patient to find possible explanations before drawing presumptive conclusions about treatment nonadherence, recreational substance use, or drug diversion and before making any therapeutic decisions. Results may also be discussed with laboratory personnel who can aid with interpretation. If no explanation is found, confirmatory testing with urine chromatography is necessary to reliably detect and quantify concentrations of specific drugs and their metabolites.

answers.content: Refer the patient to an addiction specialist
answers.explanation_why: Referral to an addiction specialist is indicated in patients who have a substance use disorder with recreational or prescription drugs. UIA can detect certain drugs in urine (suggesting recent use) but it cannot diagnose substance use disorder, which is why unexpected results should be discussed with the patient and further investigated before making therapeutic decisions.

answers.content: Report the patient to the law enforcement authorities
answers.explanation_why: Reporting a patient to law enforcement may be considered if there is a high suspicion of drug diversion or theft. However, a negative result for opioids on UIA alone is insufficient evidence of drug diversion. Because of the limitations of UIA, unexpected results should be discussed with the patient and further investigated before drawing conclusions.

question_text: The head of a private surgical daycare clinic is evaluating the results of a recent cost-benefit analysis. The results indicate that it may be more economical to purchase multidose vials instead of individual prefilled syringes for injectable drugs. To reduce costs, the clinic pharmacy decides to transition from buying injectable operating room drugs in prefilled single-dose syringes to bulk packages of multidose vials that have to be prepared for single-use injection. An anesthesiologist raises the concern that multidose vials increase the risk of perioperative medication errors. If the clinic continues to purchase multidose vials, which of the following actions is most likely to maximize patient safety?
content_preview: The head of a private surgical daycare clinic is evaluating the results of a recent cost-benefit analysis. The results indicate that it may be more economical to purchase multidose vials instead of individual prefilled syringes for injectable drugs. To reduce costs, the clinic pharmacy decides to transition from buying injectable operating room drugs in prefilled single-dose syringes to bulk packages of multidose vials that have to be prepared for single-use injection. An anesthesiologist raises the concern that multidose vials increase the risk of perioperative medication errors. If the clinic continues to purchase multidose vials, which of the following actions is most likely to maximize patient safety?
hint: The use of multidose vials instead of prefilled single-dose syringes increases the risk of medication dispensing errors and contamination.
learning_objective: Recognize the role of on-site pharmacy preparation and labeling in maximizing patient safety with multidose vials.

answers.content: Drawing up and labeling of drugs in the on-site pharmacy before surgery
answers.explanation_why: Drugs that are commonly required during surgery should be prepared beforehand and should always be readily available. Involving the on-site pharmacist is a key step to prevent drug dispensing errors. If multiple patients receive doses from the same vial (as seen in multidose vials), drug dispensing for the operating room should take place in a clean area reserved for medication preparation (e.g., a satellite pharmacy) and in an aseptic manner (e.g., using sterile syringes, disinfecting the septum before piercing the vial). Preparing drug trays with prefilled syringes in conjunction with clear labeling (e.g., with the drug's generic name and drug concentration) using standardized printed labels maximizes patient safety by reducing the risk of product mix-ups and dispensing errors. The label may also include the date, time, pharmacist's name, and the patient's name and date of birth.

answers.content: Drawing up of drugs by the circulating nurse during surgery based on instructions by the anesthetist
answers.explanation_why: Circulating nurses have a number of responsibilities during surgery, such as providing additional equipment when needed, and are often responsible for more than one surgical team. Therefore, there would be an increased risk of attentional capture and skill-based errors if the circulating nurse prepared the drugs; a different person should be designated for drug dispensing. In addition, drugs that are commonly required during surgery should be prepared prior to surgery and always readily available.

answers.content: Drawing up of drugs by the anesthesiologist during surgery
answers.explanation_why: Anesthesiologists have a high cognitive workload and carry out multiple important tasks during surgery (e.g., administering and managing anesthesia, monitoring and controlling patients' vital functions and level of consciousness). Therefore, there would be an increased risk of attentional capture and skill-based errors if the anesthesiologist was responsible for drawing up drugs during surgery. Moreover, the anesthesiologist works in the immediate patient area, and dispensing drugs in this area is not recommended, as it increases the risk of contamination.

answers.content: Drawing up of drugs by a scrub nurse before surgery based on the patient's diagnosis
answers.explanation_why: Scrub nurses have a number of responsibilities prior to surgery, such as reviewing patients' records, adjusting surgical instruments, adhering to the universal protocol, and scrubbing up. The scrub nurse is not responsible for drawing up and labeling drugs. Additionally, in environments such as the operating room or the emergency department, the patient's diagnosis is often not the most crucial factor in determining what medications need to be prepared, as standardized protocols for specific situations are often used.

answers.content: Drawing up and labeling of drugs by the surgeon before surgery
answers.explanation_why: Before surgery, the surgeon is responsible for preparing the operation (e.g., reviewing the patient's records, confirming their diagnosis and thus the indication for the planned procedure). Additionally, the surgeon needs to scrub up and, as the leader of the surgical team, is also responsible for briefing the team and adherence to the universal protocol. The operating surgeon is not responsible for drawing up and labeling drugs.

question_text: A 58-year-old man comes to the oncologist for a follow-up examination 6 months after he underwent uncomplicated operative resection of the right colon and adjuvant chemotherapy for stage II colon cancer. Medical history is remarkable for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Medications include lisinopril, atorvastatin, and a daily multivitamin. His temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 86/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 128/88 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a well-healed surgical scar on the right abdomen. Results of laboratory studies, including carcinoembryonic antigen levels, are within the reference ranges. The patient reports that he generally feels fine and asks if the blood tests he undergoes during monthly visits to his primary care physician (PCP) are necessary. While reviewing the patient's electronic health record (EHR), the physician notices that the PCP has been ordering monthly complete blood counts and serum ferritin tests since the cancer diagnosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the physician?
content_preview: A 58-year-old man comes to the oncologist for a follow-up examination 6 months after he underwent uncomplicated operative resection of the right colon and adjuvant chemotherapy for stage II colon cancer. Medical history is remarkable for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Medications include lisinopril, atorvastatin, and a daily multivitamin. His temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 86/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 128/88 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a well-healed surgical scar on the right abdomen. Results of laboratory studies, including carcinoembryonic antigen levels, are within the reference ranges. The patient reports that he generally feels fine and asks if the blood tests he undergoes during monthly visits to his primary care physician (PCP) are necessary. While reviewing the patient's electronic health record (EHR), the physician notices that the PCP has been ordering monthly complete blood counts and serum ferritin tests since the cancer diagnosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the physician?
hint: This action is necessary to avoid health care fragmentation.
learning_objective: Recognize the need for interprofessional communication to address potential healthcare fragmentation.

answers.content: Report the PCP to the state medical licensing board
answers.explanation_why: A suspected violation of medical licensing provisions (e.g., billing fraud, sexual misconduct) should always be reported to the appropriate authority. In this scenario, reporting the PCP to the state medical licensing board is inappropriate because there is no evidence of a violation.

answers.content: Use the patient’s EHR to ask the PCP to stop ordering the tests
answers.explanation_why: EHRs can be used to share information (e.g., test results, treatment plans) among healthcare providers and organizations. However, the EHR is not an appropriate tool for addressing complex topics (e.g., unnecessary testing, patient discomfort) or situations that require a detailed discussion. Furthermore, because the PCP is often the coordinator of a patient's care, and there may be an indication for the monthly blood workups that the physician is unaware of, it would be inappropriate to request discontinuation of the tests.

answers.content: Contact the PCP directly and ask about the monthly tests
answers.explanation_why: In the absence of other indications, monthly CBCs and serum ferritin tests are not indicated for the follow-up of patients with colon cancer. However, the PCP is often the coordinator of a patient's care, and there may be an indication for the monthly blood workups that the oncologist is unaware of. Therefore, the oncologist should approach the PCP privately and inquire in a nonjudgmental manner about the reason for the monthly tests. Timely and effective communication between healthcare providers improves the quality of care, increases patient satisfaction, and reduces the incidence of medical errors. Moreover, it can help reduce unnecessary or repetitive therapeutic and diagnostic interventions, which can cause discomfort for patients, increase the risk of false positive results, and waste healthcare resources. If providers disagree because of differing processes, priorities, or levels of knowledge and training, a conflict resolution approach, such as collaboration (conflict management strategy), should be used to reach a consensus.

answers.content: Assure the patient that the tests are indicated
answers.explanation_why: In the absence of other indications, monthly CBCs and serum ferritin tests are not indicated for the follow-up of patients with colon cancer and it would be inappropriate to assure the patient. Furthermore, a physician should never lie to a patient, even to protect a colleague.

answers.content: Ask the patient to discuss the need for the tests with the PCP
answers.explanation_why: Although an individual has the right to refuse tests, it is not the patient's responsibility to convey the physician's concerns to his PCP. Furthermore, such requests may cause a breakdown in communication between the providers, which can increase the risks of medical errors.

question_text: A group of clinicians at a primary care clinic notices that many of their patients with hypertension do not seem to have adequate blood pressure control. They launch a quality improvement project to identify the causes and propose solutions. As part of the project, they review the medical charts of patients with hypertension and extract blood pressure readings as well as other medical and sociodemographic information. Their analysis reveals that patients with government-funded health insurance have much higher blood pressure readings on average than patients with commercial health insurance. The analysis also discloses that patients with government-funded health insurance have a higher prevalence of untreated or poorly controlled diabetes mellitus and heart disease. Which of the following is the most plausible explanation for these findings?
content_preview: A group of clinicians at a primary care clinic notices that many of their patients with hypertension do not seem to have adequate blood pressure control. They launch a quality improvement project to identify the causes and propose solutions. As part of the project, they review the medical charts of patients with hypertension and extract blood pressure readings as well as other medical and sociodemographic information. Their analysis reveals that patients with government-funded health insurance have much higher blood pressure readings on average than patients with commercial health insurance. The analysis also discloses that patients with government-funded health insurance have a higher prevalence of untreated or poorly controlled diabetes mellitus and heart disease. Which of the following is the most plausible explanation for these findings?
hint: Low income is a confounding factor when comparing patients with government-funded health insurance (public insurance) and commercial health insurance (private insurance) because several government-funded health insurance plans such as Medicaid, Children's Health Insurance Program, and Affordable Care Act subsidies are specifically designed to help low-income individuals with access to care.
learning_objective: Recognize social determinants of health as a major contributor to health disparities.

answers.content: Patients with government-funded health insurance are more likely to belong to racial groups with a genetic predisposition to hypertension.
answers.explanation_why: Although the racial composition of patients with public insurance may differ from the racial composition of those with private insurance, there is no evidence to support a race-based genetic predisposition to hypertension.

answers.content: Commercial health insurance is more likely to reimburse accurate home blood pressure monitors.
answers.explanation_why: Accurate blood pressure measurements are unlikely to have as much effect on a patient’s health as social determinants of health that influence access to nonpharmacological measures for treating hypertension.

answers.content: Patients with government-funded health insurance are less likely to have access to healthy food choices.
answers.explanation_why: Studies have found that patients with public insurance have more clinic visits and a higher number of medications prescribed on average than patients with private insurance. Despite access to care, patients with public insurance often have worse healthcare outcomes than those with private insurance. Health disparities based on race, ethnicity, socioeconomic status, gender identity, sexual orientation, and language are common and can account for these differences in outcomes. In many cases, the cause of the disparities involves social determinants of health that are beyond the control of individual patients and providers. In the case of hypertension, diabetes, and other conditions that respond to diet and exercise, health disparities between groups are frequently due to a lack of access to healthy foods and/or safe environments for exercising. Low-income individuals often live in food deserts where healthy foods are not as available or as affordable as unhealthy convenience store food or fast food. Low-income populations are also more likely to be targeted by the fast food and tobacco industries, which encourage unhealthy habits.

answers.content: Government-funded health insurance is more likely to reimburse generic medications than brand-name drugs.
answers.explanation_why: Although generic medications are often preferred by insurance companies (both public and private) because of their lower cost, this preference is not expected to affect blood pressure outcomes since generic medications are as effective as brand-name ones.

answers.content: Patients with government-funded health insurance are less likely to be truthful about their medication adherence.
answers.explanation_why: Overt or hidden biases on the part of healthcare providers (relational injustice) can result in incorrect assumptions about a patient’s medication adherence, and decrease the likelihood of patients seeking care or being up-front with their providers about medication adherence. There is no evidence, however, that patients with public health insurance are less likely to be truthful about medication adherence than those with private insurance.

question_text:
Researchers conducted a large randomized controlled trial comparing three treatments for infants hospitalized with respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) infection: an experimental product, hypertonic saline, and routine care. Each treatment arm included 48 infants. The goal and primary outcome of the trial was to reduce the duration of hospitalization. The findings are as follows:

Experimental product
Hypertonic saline
Routine care

P value for difference among the groups

Duration of hospitalization (days)
2.1
1.9
2.2
0.22

Time to sterilization of nasal passages (days)
1.1
4.3
5.2
< 0.001

Cost (dollars per hospital day)
1250
25
5
< 0.001

Clinically significant adverse effects
Vomiting in 4 subjects
Severe broncho­constriction in 2 subjects
None

Which of the following conclusions can be drawn from these data about the most appropriate intervention for an infant hospitalized with RSV infection?
content_preview: Researchers conducted a large randomized controlled trial comparing three treatments for infants hospitalized with respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) infection: an experimental product, hypertonic saline, and routine care. Each treatment arm included 48 infants. The goal and primary outcome of the trial was to reduce the duration of hospitalization. The findings are as follows: Experimental product Hypertonic saline Routine care P value for difference among the groups Duration of hospitalization (days) 2.1 1.9 2.2 0.22 Time to sterilization of nasal passages (days) 1.1 4.3 5.2 < 0.001 Cost (dollars per hospital day) 1250 25 5 < 0.001 Clinically significant adverse effects Vomiting in 4 subjects Severe broncho­constriction in 2 subjects None Which of the following conclusions can be drawn from these data about the most appropriate intervention for an infant hospitalized with RSV infection?
learning_objective: Distinguish statistical significance from clinical importance.

answers.content: Hypertonic saline and the experimental product are equally appropriate interventions
answers.explanation_why: Although the experimental product was statistically superior in sterilizing the nasal passages, such differences were not reflected in length of hospital stay, a more clinically relevant outcome. Hypertonic saline appears to be associated with several complications, and the experimental product is very expensive.

answers.content: Routine care is the most appropriate intervention
answers.explanation_why: Statistically significant outcome differences in a clinical trial are not necessarily clinically important if the difference between treatment groups is very small, the outcomes studied are not relevant to clinical practice, or both. Analyzing the performance of a specific test or intervention should therefore include relevant parameters, such as adverse effects, costs, psychological impact, quality of life, and burden to individual patients and to society. In this case, data were complete and available for four outcomes of interest. Of these, routine care was not statistically superior in sterilizing the nasal passages, but was superior in costs and not associated with complications, the more clinically relevant outcomes. Therefore, routine care can be recommended over both the experimental product and hypertonic saline.

answers.content: The experimental product is the most appropriate intervention
answers.explanation_why: Although the experimental product was statistically superior in sterilizing the nasal passages, such differences were not reflected in length of hospital stay, a more clinically relevant outcome. Given that patients in all three groups were discharged after similar lengths of hospital stay, one can conclude that there are no differences in clinical effectiveness across the interventions. However, the experimental product is very expensive.

answers.content: Hypertonic saline is the most appropriate intervention
answers.explanation_why: Although the experimental product was statistically superior in sterilizing the nasal passages, such differences were not reflected in length of hospital stay, a more clinically relevant outcome. Hypertonic saline appears to be associated with several complications.

Given that patients in all three groups were discharged after similar lengths of hospital stay, one can conclude that there are no differences in clinical effectiveness across the interventions. However, the experimental product is very expensive, and hypertonic saline appears to be associated with several complications.

question_text:
A 45-year-old woman with recurrent urinary tract infections comes to the physician for advice on appropriate prevention. A review of the literature reveals five different approaches to preventing recurrence relative to placebo. Which set of results provides the most precise estimate of a protective effect?

Approach
Relative risk
95% Confidence interval

A
0.78
0.71–0.86

B
0.74
0.37–0.99

C
0.82
0.75–1.2

D
1.2
1.1–1.4

E
1.3
1.0–1.4
content_preview: A 45-year-old woman with recurrent urinary tract infections comes to the physician for advice on appropriate prevention. A review of the literature reveals five different approaches to preventing recurrence relative to placebo. Which set of results provides the most precise estimate of a protective effect? Approach Relative risk 95% Confidence interval A 0.78 0.71–0.86 B 0.74 0.37–0.99 C 0.82 0.75–1.2 D 1.2 1.1–1.4 E 1.3 1.0–1.4
hint: When evaluating a relative risk (RR) estimate, consider whether it is greater or less than 1.0. To evaluate a confidence interval (CI), consider whether it includes 1.0 and its width.
learning_objective: Recall the importance of a confidence interval in the interpretation of study results.

answers.explanation_why: The RR estimates the ratio of the probability of an outcome (e.g., recurrence of urinary tract infections) occurring in an exposed group (e.g., those receiving treatment) to the probability of the outcome occurring in an unexposed group (e.g., those receiving placebo). An RR < 1.0 indicates that a given treatment decreases the probability of an outcome. The CI provides a range of plausible values for the true RR based on the available data. A CI that does not include 1.0 indicates a statistically significant difference between the two groups. Finally, the width of the CI provides information about the precision of the estimate. If the RR estimate is 0.78 and the CI is 0.71–0.86, the intervention likely has a protective effect, and the magnitude of that effect (relative risk reduction) could be anywhere from 14–29%. The narrower the CI, the more precise the RR estimate. Therefore, approach A has the set of results that shows a protective effect (i.e., an RR <1.0 with a CI that does not include 1.0) with the most precision (i.e., the narrowest CI).

An RR < 1.0 with a CI that does not include 1.0 suggests a protective effect for this intervention. However, the width of the CI is 0.37–0.99, indicating a relative risk reduction anywhere from 1–63%, which makes this a less precise estimate.
An RR < 1.0 indicates a protective effect of this intervention. However, a CI that includes 1.0 suggests no statistically significant difference in outcomes between the exposed and unexposed groups.
An RR > 1.0 with a CI that does not include 1.0 indicates that this approach increases the risk of urinary tract infections rather than preventing their recurrence.

An RR > 1.0 indicates that the risk of recurrent urinary tract infection in the treatment group is higher than in the placebo group. In addition, a CI that includes 1.0 suggests no statistically significant difference in outcomes between the exposed and unexposed groups.

question_text: A 13-month-old girl is brought to the physician because of a 12-hour history of fever, irritability, decreased oral intake, and foul-smelling urine. A urinalysis is positive for white cells, leukocyte esterase, and nitrites. The physician prescribes a 10-day course of oral cefixime and discusses close follow-up with the family. One week later, the patient is afebrile, eating well, and in no distress. A voiding cystourethrogram shows grade 2 vesicoureteral reflux. The family asks how to proceed. In reviewing the literature, the physician finds a randomized controlled trial regarding the use of antibiotic prophylaxis to prevent subsequent urinary tract infections and renal scarring in young children with vesicoureteral reflux. Which of the following statements about this study’s design is correct?
content_preview: A 13-month-old girl is brought to the physician because of a 12-hour history of fever, irritability, decreased oral intake, and foul-smelling urine. A urinalysis is positive for white cells, leukocyte esterase, and nitrites. The physician prescribes a 10-day course of oral cefixime and discusses close follow-up with the family. One week later, the patient is afebrile, eating well, and in no distress. A voiding cystourethrogram shows grade 2 vesicoureteral reflux. The family asks how to proceed. In reviewing the literature, the physician finds a randomized controlled trial regarding the use of antibiotic prophylaxis to prevent subsequent urinary tract infections and renal scarring in young children with vesicoureteral reflux. Which of the following statements about this study’s design is correct?
hint: Randomized controlled trials (RCTs) are considered the gold standard for testing interventions.
learning_objective: Recognize the defining attributes and limitations of randomized controlled trials.

answers.content: The study design ensures that even adverse effects of prophylactic antibiotics can be identified.
answers.explanation_why: Although RCTs can identify common adverse effects, they are not optimal to identify rare adverse effects; these are usually better identified with larger observational studies.

answers.content: The statistical analyses performed in this type of study are different from those performed in other study types.
answers.explanation_why: The statistical analyses used for clinical trials are similar to those used in other study designs. Randomization in a clinical trial allows estimation of the causal effect, but the statistical approaches used are not different in this study design than in others.

answers.content: This study is designed to optimize the ability to make inferences about the effect of prophylactic antibiotics on the outcome.
answers.explanation_why:
The primary advantage of RCTs is high internal validity so that a causal inference can be made about the intervention (in this case, prophylactic antibiotics) and the outcome (urinary tract infections and renal scarring). Random allocation to the treatment groups (which leads to balancing of potential confounders between the groups) and blinding allow the investigators to attribute any observed differences in the primary outcome between treatment groups to the intervention and not to other causes. Thus, the advantage of the study identified is that it allows the researchers to determine whether prophylactic antibiotics are beneficial in preventing urinary tract infections and scarring.

Patients that sign up for RCTs tend to differ from people in the broader population, making generalizability of the results to the larger population difficult. RCTs are costly and time-consuming, so recruiting an adequate sample size to account for heterogeneity can be difficult. Therefore, the results of this trial may not apply to all children with vesicoureteral reflux, only those who match the characteristics of the trial participants.

answers.content: The study design allows the most accurate measurement of the outcome of urinary tract infections and renal scarring.
answers.explanation_why: The accuracy of the outcome metric is not affected by the study design. It is determined by the manner in which the researchers are able to measure or determine the outcome. An accurate measure of the outcome is important for a clinical trial, but it is equally important for any other research study design.

answers.content: This study is designed to optimize generalizability of the results to all children with vesicoureteral reflux.
answers.explanation_why: Patients that sign up for RCTs tend to differ from people in the broader population, making generalizability of the results to the larger population difficult. RCTs are costly and time-consuming, so recruiting an adequate sample size to account for heterogeneity can be difficult. Therefore, the results of this trial may not apply to all children with vesicoureteral reflux, only those who match the characteristics of the trial participants.

question_text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She is asymptomatic and has no significant medical history. She is married and has two children. Menses occur at regular 28-day intervals with a normal flow; her last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago. Her mother was diagnosed with breast cancer at age 38 years, and her maternal aunt died of ovarian cancer at age 45 years. She does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. She takes a daily multivitamin. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 58 kg (128 lb); BMI is 21 kg/m^2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The patient underwent genetic testing, which revealed a pathogenic BRCA1 mutation. The patient asks about the most appropriate cancer screening strategy for her situation. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She is asymptomatic and has no significant medical history. She is married and has two children. Menses occur at regular 28-day intervals with a normal flow; her last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago. Her mother was diagnosed with breast cancer at age 38 years, and her maternal aunt died of ovarian cancer at age 45 years. She does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. She takes a daily multivitamin. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 58 kg (128 lb); BMI is 21 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The patient underwent genetic testing, which revealed a pathogenic BRCA1 mutation. The patient asks about the most appropriate cancer screening strategy for her situation. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Early and intensive screening is critical due to the aggressive nature and early onset of BRCA-associated breast cancers.
learning_objective: Recognize appropriate cancer screening and surveillance strategies for patients with BRCA mutations.

answers.content: Begin annual breast ultrasound and pelvic examination now
answers.explanation_why: Pelvic examination may be performed annually in patients with high-risk conditions for ovarian cancer, such as BRCA mutations, as part of comprehensive ovarian cancer screening (including annual transvaginal ultrasound and CA-125 levels). However, in patients with a genetic predisposition for breast cancer (e.g., BRCA mutation), annual breast ultrasonography is not an appropriate screening strategy as this modality is not sensitive enough for detecting early-stage disease.

answers.content: Begin annual mammography and annual breast MRI immediately
answers.explanation_why: Individuals with a genetic predisposition to breast cancer (e.g., BRCA mutation) should begin screening from 25–29 years of age. For those aged ≤ 29 years, breast examination every 6–12 months and annual breast MRI are recommended. For those aged ≥ 30 years, annual MRI plus mammography is recommended.

answers.content: Begin annual mammography now and annual breast MRI at age 40
answers.explanation_why: Annual mammography alone is insufficient for high-risk BRCA1 carriers < 40 years of age because younger individuals have relatively dense breast tissue that reduces the test's sensitivity. Delaying annual MRI until 40 years of age risks missing early cancers that may develop in this high-risk group. A different screening approach is more appropriate for this patient.

answers.content: Begin mammography every 2 years starting at age 40
answers.explanation_why: Mammography every 2 years starting at 40 years of age is appropriate for individuals at average risk but not for those at high risk (e.g., BRCA mutation carriers). For high-risk individuals, starting mammography alone at 40 years of age is insufficient because it may miss early cancers and lacks the sensitivity needed to detect tumors.

answers.content: Begin annual transvaginal ultrasound and serum CA-125 at age 50
answers.explanation_why: Periodic ovarian cancer screening with transvaginal ultrasound and serum CA-125 levels may be considered in individuals at high risk for ovarian cancer (e.g., patients with BRCA mutations) who do not wish to undergo risk-reducing salpingo-oophorectomy. Ideally, the screening should start earlier, around 30 years of age. Additionally, early breast cancer screening is indicated in this patient.

question_text: A 72-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up appointment for his type 2 diabetes mellitus. He reports that his vision has been progressively worsening over the past several months, and he has also developed numbness and tingling in his feet. Medical history is significant for ischemic heart disease, peripheral neuropathy, and chronic lymphocytic leukemia. He is retired and lives in Texas with his wife. He served in the US Army during the Vietnam War. Current medications are metformin, atorvastatin, and clopidogrel. He does not smoke or drink alcohol and jogs outdoors almost daily for 20 minutes. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows bilateral retinopathy. Neurological examination shows decreased sensation in a stocking-glove distribution in both lower extremities. Which of the following is the most likely additional long-term health risk associated with this patient's history?
content_preview: A 72-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up appointment for his type 2 diabetes mellitus. He reports that his vision has been progressively worsening over the past several months, and he has also developed numbness and tingling in his feet. Medical history is significant for ischemic heart disease, peripheral neuropathy, and chronic lymphocytic leukemia. He is retired and lives in Texas with his wife. He served in the US Army during the Vietnam War. Current medications are metformin, atorvastatin, and clopidogrel. He does not smoke or drink alcohol and jogs outdoors almost daily for 20 minutes. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows bilateral retinopathy. Neurological examination shows decreased sensation in a stocking-glove distribution in both lower extremities. Which of the following is the most likely additional long-term health risk associated with this patient's history?
hint: This patient is at increased risk for conditions associated with Agent Orange exposure, which was used in the Vietnam War.
learning_objective: Recognize long-term health risks associated with Agent Orange exposure.

answers.explanation_why: The U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs recognizes several conditions associated with Agent Orange exposure, including cancers (e.g., chronic lymphocytic leukemia, Hodgkin lymphoma, non-Hodgkin lymphoma) and noncancer conditions (e.g., type 2 diabetes mellitus, ischemic heart disease, Parkinson disease, peripheral neuropathy). Epidemiological studies have demonstrated an increased incidence of Parkinson disease among soldiers exposed to Agent Orange, which is thought to be due to dioxin-induced neurotoxicity affecting dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra. Recognizing this association is essential for screening and early intervention.

Environmental factors associated with an increased risk of developing systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) include tobacco products and silica exposure. This patient has no smoking history or relevant silica exposure. His military service may have involved exposure to Agent Orange, which is not a risk factor for SLE.

While military service may increase the risk of respiratory diseases through exposure to, e.g., tobacco smoke or burn pits, this patient has no history of smoking or extensive exposure to air pollution or fine dusts. His military service is more likely to have involved exposure to Agent Orange, which is not a risk factor for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.

Environmental factors associated with multiple sclerosis include low vitamin D levels and tobacco products. As this patient exercises outdoors almost daily, vitamin D deficiency is unlikely. Furthermore, he has no smoking history. It is more likely that this patient's military service involved exposure to Agent Orange, which is not a risk factor for multiple sclerosis.

Environmental factors associated with an increased risk of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) include tobacco products and certain occupational or environmental exposures (e.g., lead, pesticides). This patient has no history of smoking or significant occupational exposures known to increase the risk of ALS. His military service may have involved exposure to Agent Orange, which is not a risk factor for ALS.

question_text: A 25-year-old woman comes to the clinic for a routine examination. She recently began a new job as a middle school science teacher. The patient has no significant medical history and takes no medications. She has never traveled outside the United States, has no known drug allergies, and has never smoked or used illicit drugs. She drinks alcohol socially. The patient is sexually active with her husband and is not pregnant. Her last tetanus-containing vaccine was at age 12 years. She received all childhood vaccinations, including the full series for measles, mumps, and rubella. She had chickenpox at 7 years of age and received the human papillomavirus vaccine series in her early 20s. Her last influenza vaccine was 2 years ago. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate vaccination recommendation at this visit?
content_preview: A 25-year-old woman comes to the clinic for a routine examination. She recently began a new job as a middle school science teacher. The patient has no significant medical history and takes no medications. She has never traveled outside the United States, has no known drug allergies, and has never smoked or used illicit drugs. She drinks alcohol socially. The patient is sexually active with her husband and is not pregnant. Her last tetanus-containing vaccine was at age 12 years. She received all childhood vaccinations, including the full series for measles, mumps, and rubella. She had chickenpox at 7 years of age and received the human papillomavirus vaccine series in her early 20s. Her last influenza vaccine was 2 years ago. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate vaccination recommendation at this visit?
learning_objective: Recognize appropriate vaccination recommendations for healthy adults.

answers.explanation_why: Routine hepatitis B immunization was implemented for all infants in the United States in 1991. This 25-year-old patient was born after universal childhood hepatitis B immunization became standard practice; therefore, she likely received the full hepatitis B vaccine series in early childhood and does not require catch-up vaccination. Hepatitis B vaccine boosters are indicated only in high-risk patients (e.g., occupational exposure, immunocompromise, those receiving hemodialysis) who are nonimmune according to HBV serology (HBsAb < 10 IU/mL).

Meningococcal vaccination is recommended for individuals at risk for meningococcal infections (e.g., those with asplenia or complement deficiencies, college students living in dormitories, military recruits). Middle school teachers do not require routine meningococcal vaccination unless they have other risk factors.

The recombinant zoster vaccine is recommended for adults ≥ 50 years of age and immunocompromised individuals ≥ 19 years of age, regardless of prior varicella infection or shingles history. This patient is only 25 years of age and is not immunocompromised, so zoster vaccination is not indicated at this time.

Pneumococcal vaccination is indicated for individuals ≥ 50 years of age and for those aged 19–49 years with risk factors for invasive pneumococcal disease (e.g., immunocompromise, asplenia). This is a healthy 25-year-old patient with no risk factors requiring pneumococcal vaccination.

answers.content: Administer tetanus, diphtheria, acellular pertussis vaccine
answers.explanation_why:
A single dose of tetanus, diphtheria, and acellular pertussis (Tdap) vaccine is recommended for all adults who have not previously received it or whose last dose was in adolescence. After initial Tdap vaccination, all patients should receive tetanus-diphtheria vaccine or Tdap boosters every 10 years. This patient’s last tetanus-containing vaccine was at 12 years of age, so she is overdue for a Tdap booster. As a middle school teacher, protection against pertussis is especially important to prevent transmission to vulnerable children. Tdap also maintains immunity against diphtheria, which can cause severe illness.

Annual influenza vaccination is also recommended for all adults, including this patient, but Tdap is the most urgent vaccination in this scenario.

question_text: A 23-year-old woman comes to the clinic for a routine check-up before starting a new job. She has no current concerns. Her last routine check-up was 3 years ago, and she has not seen a doctor since. She has no significant medical history and takes no medications. She exercises regularly and has a balanced diet. She is sexually active with one male partner and uses condoms consistently. Her father was diagnosed with hypertension at age 52. Her maternal grandmother was diagnosed with breast cancer at age 72. She has never smoked tobacco or used illicit drugs. She drinks alcohol socially. She is 167 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 64 kg (141 lb); BMI is 23 kg/m^2. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 116/74 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the next best step in management?
content_preview: A 23-year-old woman comes to the clinic for a routine check-up before starting a new job. She has no current concerns. Her last routine check-up was 3 years ago, and she has not seen a doctor since. She has no significant medical history and takes no medications. She exercises regularly and has a balanced diet. She is sexually active with one male partner and uses condoms consistently. Her father was diagnosed with hypertension at age 52. Her maternal grandmother was diagnosed with breast cancer at age 72. She has never smoked tobacco or used illicit drugs. She drinks alcohol socially. She is 167 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 64 kg (141 lb); BMI is 23 kg/m2. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 116/74 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the next best step in management?
hint: Screening recommendations for women differ by age and risk factors.
learning_objective: Recognize appropriate preventive health screenings for asymptomatic adults aged 20 to 35 years.

answers.explanation_why: While hypertension screening is recommended for all adults starting at 18 years of age, this is typically done with office-based blood pressure measurements rather than ambulatory monitoring, which is reserved for suspected white coat hypertension or masked hypertension. This 23-year-old patient with normal blood pressure (116/74 mm Hg) and no risk factors should have routine hypertension screening every 3–5 years using standard office measurements.

Screening for diabetes using fasting plasma glucose is recommended for adults aged 35–70 years with overweight or obesity, or for younger individuals with additional risk factors (e.g., a family history of diabetes, hypertension, or signs of insulin resistance). As this patient is 23 years of age, has a normal BMI, and no identifiable risk factors, fasting glucose screening is not currently indicated.

Pap smear and/or HPV testing detect precancerous and cancerous cervical changes, allowing early intervention to prevent progression to cervical cancer. Both the American Cancer Society (ACS) and the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommend screening, although their starting ages and intervals differ slightly. The USPSTF advises beginning at age 21 with Pap smear alone every 3 years until age 29, and for individuals aged 30–65 years, either primary HPV testing every 5 years, HPV/Pap cotesting every 5 years, or Pap smear alone every 3 years. In contrast, recent guidelines from the ACS, the American Society for Colposcopy and Cervical Pathology, and the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists recommend starting primary HPV testing every 5 years at age 25, with HPV/Pap cotesting every 5 years as an alternative, and Pap smear alone every 3 years if HPV testing is unavailable. As this patient is 23 years of age, asymptomatic, and up-to-date with other preventive screenings, she should undergo cervical cancer screening with a Pap smear.

Lipid panel testing is recommended for adults starting at 20 years of age for cardiovascular risk assessment. For individuals with a low risk and a normal lipid profile, repeat screening is generally advised every 4 to 6 years. As this patient had a routine check-up 3 years ago, is healthy, has a normal BMI, and has no cardiovascular risk factors, lipid testing is not currently indicated.

Mammography is recommended for breast cancer screening starting at age 40–50 years, depending on guidelines, and is not indicated for asymptomatic women under 40 years of age without high-risk conditions for breast cancer (e.g., BRCA mutation). For women with a family history of breast cancer, it is generally recommended to start breast cancer screening 10 years before the age of the earliest diagnosis in the family, but not before the age of 30 years.

Individuals with a genetic predisposition to breast cancer (e.g., BRCA mutation) should begin screening between the ages of 25 and 29 years. For individuals aged ≤ 29 years, breast examination every 6–12 months and annual breast MRI are recommended.

question_text: A 21-year-old woman comes to the gynecology clinic for her first cervical cancer screening. She reports no abnormal vaginal bleeding, pelvic pain, or dyspareunia. She became sexually active at age 16 years and has had two lifetime sexual partners. She uses oral contraceptive pills for birth control. She has no significant medical history. Her mother was treated for cervical cancer at age 45 years. The patient does not smoke or drink alcohol. She appears well. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows no cervical lesions or discharge. A photomicrograph of a cervical sample from a Pap smear is shown. HPV testing is negative for high-risk HPV. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 21-year-old woman comes to the gynecology clinic for her first cervical cancer screening. She reports no abnormal vaginal bleeding, pelvic pain, or dyspareunia. She became sexually active at age 16 years and has had two lifetime sexual partners. She uses oral contraceptive pills for birth control. She has no significant medical history. Her mother was treated for cervical cancer at age 45 years. The patient does not smoke or drink alcohol. She appears well. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows no cervical lesions or discharge. A photomicrograph of a cervical sample from a Pap smear is shown. HPV testing is negative for high-risk HPV. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: The photomicrograph shows a sheet of small abnormal epithelial cells with irregular nuclear contours, a high nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio, and irregular clumped chromatin. There is a dyskeratotic cell within the clump of abnormal cells. These findings are characteristic of high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL).
learning_objective: Recognize high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL) on Pap smear, and choose the most appropriate next step in management in a patient < 25.

answers.explanation_why:
Formerly, the management approach for abnormal cervical cancer screening was determined by test results alone. Recent recommendations have shifted to a risk-based approach. Risk calculators can be used to estimate the immediate risk of CIN3. If this risk is ≥ 4%, colposcopy and cervical biopsy or expedited treatment may be used. If this risk is < 4%, surveillance with HPV-based testing every 1–5 years is recommended.

However, certain patient groups (e.g., women < 25 years of age) should still be treated based on test results. In patients < 25 years of age with HSIL on cytology, colposcopy and biopsy are indicated. Expedited treatment (without a preceding colposcopic biopsy and histological confirmation) is not recommended at this age as most cervical abnormalities regress spontaneously. Low-grade lesions (LSIL or ASC-US) in patients < 25 years of age can be managed with cytology-alone screening annually for the next two years.
Endometrial sampling after Pap smear is indicated in postmenopausal women with benign endometrial cells on cytology but not for HSIL.

While observation with repeat cytology may be appropriate for certain low-grade lesions (e.g., ASC-US, LSIL) in women < 25 years of age, it is not recommended for HSIL. HSIL has a much higher risk of progression to invasive disease.

Expedited treatment (without a preceding colposcopic biopsy and histological confirmation), e.g., immediate loop electrosurgical excision, is not recommended in women < 25 years of age, even with an HSIL. Most cervical abnormalities at this age regress spontaneously. Excisional procedures carry risks (e.g., cervical incompetence, preterm birth) and are reserved for high-grade lesions that have been confirmed on biopsy or when colposcopic evaluation cannot rule out invasive disease.

HPV vaccination is recommended for the prevention of HPV infection and related cervical dysplasia and cancer but is not a treatment for cytological abnormalities. This patient already has HSIL, so vaccination is not a priority.

images.title: Papanicolaou test showing HSIL
images.description: Photomicrograph of a Papanicolaou test sample of squamous cells of the cervix (Papanicolaou stain; very high magnification)Multiple normal intermediate squamous cells (light blue cytoplasm, examples indicated by yellow overlay) and a neutrophil (arrowhead) can be seen. A sheet of smaller, abnormal, epithelial cells (dashed outline) is also present at the bottom of the image. These cells have irregular nuclear contours with a high nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio and irregular clumped chromatin. There is a dyskeratotic cell (red cytoplasm, arrow) within the clump of abnormal cells.These findings are characteristic of severe dysplasia, i.e., a high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL).

question_text: A 22-year-old man comes to the primary care clinic after it has officially closed for the evening. He approaches the only physician in the clinic just as she is leaving and asks to be examined because of a 3-week history of persistent dry cough and fatigue. He denies fever, chills, chest pain, weight loss, and shortness of breath. He is worried because he read online that a persistent cough could be a sign of cancer. He does not appear to be in acute distress. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 22-year-old man comes to the primary care clinic after it has officially closed for the evening. He approaches the only physician in the clinic just as she is leaving and asks to be examined because of a 3-week history of persistent dry cough and fatigue. He denies fever, chills, chest pain, weight loss, and shortness of breath. He is worried because he read online that a persistent cough could be a sign of cancer. He does not appear to be in acute distress. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate triage and follow-up for nonurgent symptoms in outpatient care.

answers.content: Write a prescription for an antitussive medication to provide symptom relief
answers.explanation_why: Prescribing medication without a clinical evaluation is not appropriate, as it may mask underlying pathology or lead to unnecessary adverse effects. A proper assessment is needed to determine the cause of the cough and guide management.

answers.content: Reassure the patient that his symptoms are unlikely to be caused by cancer
answers.explanation_why: Even though it is unlikely that this patient's symptoms are caused by cancer, reassurance should only be provided after a thorough clinical evaluation to ensure that no serious underlying condition is missed. In addition, dismissing this patient's concerns without an evaluation could damage the physician-patient relationship.

answers.content: Bring the patient to an examination room for a focused physical examination
answers.explanation_why: Performing a focused physical examination in an outpatient clinic after business hours for a patient with nonurgent symptoms is not recommended. Because access to support staff and equipment is limited, and the patient's complete electronic health record may be unavailable, there is an increased risk of medical errors, and patient safety may be compromised.

answers.content: Refer the patient to the nearest emergency department for evaluation
answers.explanation_why: To ensure the efficient use of health care resources, only patients with urgent conditions should be referred to the emergency department. This patient is not in acute distress and does not have any red flags for cough; therefore, he does not require immediate evaluation.

answers.content: Advise the patient to schedule an appointment for the next day
answers.explanation_why:
When an individual presents to an outpatient clinic after hours with nonurgent symptoms (e.g., subacute cough), the physician should balance patient safety with professional boundaries and efficient use of health care resources. This patient has a 3-week history of cough with no evidence of red flags for cough (e.g., hemoptysis, fever, chest pain, respiratory distress). The physician should acknowledge the patient’s worry about cancer, briefly confirm that no urgent features are present, and then advise a timely follow-up visit on the next business day. They should also give clear instructions for seeking urgent care if symptoms worsen. This approach is empathetic, avoids premature reassurance, and preserves trust while maintaining appropriate clinical boundaries and ensuring proper evaluation and appropriate documentation in a fully staffed setting.

In order to ensure the efficient use of health care resources and avoid overcrowding, only patients with urgent conditions should be referred to the emergency department.
